name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen! I have a sad duty to inform you that Mr Ransdorf died on 22 January at the age of 62. Mr Ransdorf has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2003. Mr Ransdorf was Vice-Chairman of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and a member of the EuroNest delegation and the delegation to the EU-Ukraine Parliamentary Association Committee. Dr. phil. Ransdorf was a well-known publicist who spoke publicly about the history of the Reformation, Karl Marx and the origins of American political culture, among other things. I would ask you to stand up for a minute's silence for our late colleague. (The House rose and observed a minute's silence)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Notis Marias on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the Annual Report of the European Central Bank 2014 (2015/2115(INI)) (A8-0012/2016). On this debate, I warmly welcome the President of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, to this House. Welcome, Mr President. First of all, the rapporteur, Mr Notis Marias, has the floor.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, today our Parliament is carrying out a top function provided for in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which is to exercise democratic control over the action of the European Central Bank. Because an independent European Central Bank does not mean an uncontrolled European Central Bank. The European Central Bank must therefore provide accountability to the European Parliament, the only EU body directly elected by the peoples of the Union.  In previous years, the process of discussing the European Central Bank's annual action report in the plenary session of the European Parliament has been limited to wishful thinking, with no criticism of the leadership of the European Central Bank and its actions. In this report we put the finger on the type of sun. Although a particular effort was made by specific political groups within the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, with joint compromise amendments, to remove important cutting-edge points contained in the report I drafted, although some have tried to round the corners, even though the 'Crown Heraklions' have proved to be more 'drags' than Mr Draghi, the key points at the top of the report remain.  The European Central Bank must take important steps to ensure that in the performance of its mission there is no conflict of interest due to the quadruple action that has turned the European Central Bank into a state in state. This is because the European Central Bank is supposed to be an independent monetary policy institution, while overseeing Europe's 130 largest systemic banks. At the same time, the European Central Bank is the big loaner of the countries of the Union, having bought bonds of the euro area states in the context of quantitative easing, and finally, it is a member of the Troika that has bankrupted and impoverished the countries of the Memorandum.  For this reason, the report recalls the important and at the same time innovative judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union C-62/14, which sets out the conditions and conditions under which the European Central Bank must carry out its quantitative easing programme. A court ruling that essentially calls for the European Central Bank to be evicted from the Troika. At the same time, our report calls for transparency and control of the Troika, and therefore of the European Central Bank, in the implementation of the so-called rescue programmes, namely the Memorandums. Mr Draghi, unemployment remains extremely high, especially for young people and the long-term unemployed, with rates particularly divergent, from 6.4% in Germany to 26.6% in Greece. All this, while the European Central Bank and the Member States have spent several trillion euros to deal with the crisis since 2009. At the same time, the ECB is particularly welcome in pursuing a tough fiscal and austerity policy, but has not been able to reduce unemployment or reduce public debt. The report even calls on the Member States to carry out a debt audit in accordance with the provisions of Regulation (EU) No 1782/2003. 472/2013. Furthermore, we believe that a policy is needed that will boost public and private investment and fuel growth. This requires increased liquidity and financing for small and medium-sized enterprises. Although the European Central Bank launched an ambitious quantitative easing programme of EUR 582 billion at the end of 2015, of which EUR 17 billion was spent by the Central Bank of impoverished Greece, however, Mr Draghi, neither deflation, unemployment nor underdevelopment was adequately addressed. In the face of the European Central Bank's obsessions with the deconstruction of the social state, the report recognises the limits of monetary policy and points out that the Union's economic problems can be addressed by structural reforms, but which must be socially balanced.  From then on, quantitative easing and low interest rates could not even contribute to the increase in private investment, while at the same time we saw problems arise in the insurance funds which saw their reserve yields be particularly low. The report assistes the European Commission's proposed pan-European deposit guarantee scheme, but also highlights the important steps taken towards the creation of a Single Banking Supervisory Authority.  In this context, it also needs to be examined whether the European Central Bank, and why, imposed a credit suffocation on Greece since the beginning of 2015 that eventually led to capital controls. Therefore, greater transparency is needed in the mode of operation of the Emergency Liquidity Facility. In conclusion, Mr President, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their positive contribution to this report.

name: Mario Draghi
text: President of the European Central Bank. – Mr President, we are undoubtedly at a point in time when the cohesion of Europe is being tested. Many of the challenges we must confront are European or even global in nature, and these challenges demand a strong European response. I am therefore grateful to be back in this assembly – a symbol of the need for European debates and European solutions. Today we are discussing the Annual Report of the European Central Bank for 2014. In that year, the Governing Council adopted a series of measures to respond to the impairment of our monetary policy transmission channels and to the low inflation environment. These measures included two reductions in key ECB interest rates, the announcement of targeted long-term refinancing operations, and two purchase programmes for asset-backed securities and covered bonds. 2014 was also marked by the start of the activities of the Single Supervisory Mechanism and the completion of the comprehensive assessment. But rather than looking backwards, allow me to focus on the challenges that still lie ahead of us. First, I will briefly explain our current monetary policy and why we will re-assess our stance at our March meeting. Second, I would like to discuss the economic challenges we face and what it takes to address them. I am acutely aware that the focus of policymakers lies elsewhere for the moment. But let me be quite clear: economic success is also part of the solution in other fields. Therefore, mitigating economic risks deserves to be high on the political agenda. It was about three years ago that inflation started moving away from the ECB’s medium-term inflation aim of below, but close to, 2%. Since October 2013, inflation has been below 1%. Throughout 2015, headline inflation in the euro area was very low or even negative, remaining under the influence of low commodity prices. Euro area annual HICP inflation was estimated at 0.4% in January this year. In parallel to this trend, we had to continually revise our outlook for inflation: while at the start of 2015 our staff was forecasting inflation to reach 1.5% in 2016 and 1.8% in 2017, in December they projected a rate of only 1% for this year, and 1.6% for 2017. Against this backdrop, the ECB decided in December to act again. Our assessment of the monetary policy stance had two parts. First, we noted that the measures put in place since the summer of 2014 had been very effective. The monetary stimulus that they introduced led to a broad-based easing of financing conditions, stimulated credit provision and has since provided substantial support to the euro area recovery. Without these measures, the euro area would have been in outright deflation last year and prices would have fallen at an even quicker pace this year. Growth would have been significantly lower. Second, while our measures were deemed effective, they were also judged to be insufficient in view of the deteriorating outlook for price stability. There was a concrete risk that without increasing the quantitative stimulus, the date by which inflation would settle around levels below, but close to, 2% would once more be pushed back beyond any relevant definition of medium-term. Therefore, we decided to recalibrate our monetary policy stance. We cut the deposit facility rate further to -0.3%; we extended the envisaged end-date for our monthly purchases to the end of March 2017, while maintaining its conditionality on the inflation outlook; and we announced that we would reinvest the principal payments of our purchased assets once they mature, for as long as necessary. We also decided to continue conducting the main refinancing operations and the three-month longer-term refinancing operations as fixed rate tender procedures with full allotment for as long as necessary, and at least until the end of the last reserve maintenance period of 2017. Since our meeting in early December, conditions have once more changed. A moderate recovery of the euro area economy is under way, driven mainly by domestic demand. But downside risks have increased again and there is heightened uncertainty about emerging market economies’ growth prospects, volatility in financial and commodity markets, and geopolitical risks. Inflation dynamics are also tangibly weaker than we expected in December. While the most recent wave of disinflation is mainly due to the renewed sharp fall in oil prices, weaker than anticipated growth in wages together with declining inflation expectations call for careful analysis of the channels by which surprises to realised inflation may influence future price and wage-setting in our economy. Therefore, at our last meeting in January we judged that it would be necessary to review and possibly reconsider our monetary policy stance at our next monetary policy meeting in early March, when the new staff macroeconomic projections will be made available. Our monetary policy is working, and the ECB is willing to contribute its share to ensuring that recovery remains firmly on track. But there are risks that – if they were to materialise – could undermine its course. The policy challenges we face are fourfold. They relate to the global environment, the situation of the financial system, the economic and fiscal policies of Member States and the political uncertainty surrounding the European project. First, as regards the global environment: growth prospects are slowly improving in advanced economies, but the outlook in emerging markets is more subdued. Overall, growth is low by historical standards. Moreover, emerging markets are facing economic and financial risks: some are suffering from structural impediments and macroeconomic imbalances, while others have to adjust to lower commodity prices. They remain vulnerable to an abrupt shift in risk sentiment that could tighten financing conditions. A key issue is how emerging markets will be impacted by tighter financing conditions and the ensuing capital outflows, and to what extent this will have repercussions for euro area foreign demand. Against this background, ensuring the continued resilience of the euro area economy is paramount. Second, there are policy challenges related to our financial markets. The euro area financial system weathered several episodes of stress in the second half of last year. This is a sign that a lot has already been achieved with the establishment of banking union – which, however, is not complete yet. To make our financial system truly safe and sound, we need to progress in two main domains, which complement each other. On the one hand, we need to finalise and implement the work we started when establishing the Single Supervisory Mechanism and the Single Resolution Mechanism as the initial pillars of banking union. This includes further regulatory work to harmonise our rules for supervisory action and to ensure a consistent application of the Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive’s (BRRD) bail-in provisions. On the other hand, we need a common public backstop for the Single Resolution Fund to strengthen its credibility, and we need to ensure that confidence in the safety of deposits is equally high in all euro area Member States by establishing a European Deposit Insurance Scheme. ‘Risk-reduction’ and ‘risk-sharing’ measures are two sides of the same coin and should be pursued in parallel: they are all essential to protecting the stability of the European banking sector. Third, there are challenges related to the fiscal and economic policies of Member States that require decisive policy action. Fiscal policies should contribute to the economic recovery. At the same time, they should be in full compliance with the requirements of the Stability and Growth Pact. This is important to maintain confidence in the European fiscal framework and in the sustainability of public finances. Moreover, countries would benefit from a more growth-friendly composition of fiscal policies. This involves greater efficiency of public sector services and moving to a more growth-friendly tax system. But the ongoing cyclical recovery in the euro area should also be supported by effective structural policies, particularly actions to improve the business environment, including the provision of an adequate public infrastructure. Such actions are vital to increase productive investment, boost job creation and raise productivity. If reforms are credible, carefully chosen and well designed, their positive effects can be felt quickly, particularly in the context of our supportive monetary policy stance. Fourth and finally, there is still political uncertainty surrounding the European project. This is true in the broader context of our Union. A solution that would anchor the United Kingdom firmly within the EU while allowing the euro area to integrate further would boost confidence. The Economic and Monetary Union architecture also remains an unfinished construction. Citizens and markets are too often unsure about our capacity to act jointly in a spirit of common responsibility. We should prove them wrong. Let me conclude and come back to the subject of our debate: your resolution on our Annual Report for 2014. Let me assure you that we are reading this document closely. It reminds us of our duty as a public institution to conduct our business in a transparent and accountable manner. The publication of the diaries of Members of the Executive Board that starts this month is only one example of this. I am looking forward to the debate and thank you for your attention.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first let me thank the rapporteur, Mr Marias, and his colleagues on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON), for their work on this report. This ex-post assessment of the European Central Bank (ECB) activities by the European Parliament is an important part of democratic accountability and a necessary complement to the ECB’s independence. The Commission shares Parliament’s view that the ECB’s independence, in the conduct of its monetary policy as enshrined in the Treaties, is crucial to safeguard price stability. The monetary policy in the euro area is the exclusive competence of the ECB. With its monetary policy measures over the past years, including interest rate cuts, a series of targeted long-term refinancing operations and an expanded assets purchase programme, the ECB has acted to address the risks of an excessively long period of very low inflation. These measures include bank lending to the euro area non—financial private sector to help reduce financial fragmentation. They should support the economy and bring inflation closer to the ECB’s target of below, but close to, 2% over the medium term. The EU economy is continuing with a moderate recovery, and it is supported by certain tailwinds, such as low oil prices, the aforementioned accommodatory monetary policy and a correspondingly lower euro exchange rate, which is favourable for European exporters. At the same time we are also facing headwinds from geopolitical tensions in our neighbourhood – both our southern and eastern neighbourhoods – and from the slowdown in emerging markets. The global GDP growth forecast has also somewhat deteriorated. It is against this backdrop that we will be updating our economic forecast on Thursday with our winter economic forecast. The Commission fully shares Parliament’s view that Europe cannot only rely on monetary policy and a favourable external environment to lift GDP growth and to raise our economy’s growth potential. Member States’ governments must roll up their sleeves and implement necessary structural reforms. Structural, fiscal and monetary policies each have to play their role for a consistent, growth-friendly approach acting both on the demand and supply sides of our economies. On the fiscal side, adjustments undertaken in recent years have reduced deficits and stabilised debt levels in the euro area. But Member States continue to face different fiscal challenges which call for a differentiated path of fiscal adjustment going forward. The Commission agrees with the European Parliament that fiscal adjustment, using the flexibility that is built into the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, needs to go hand in hand with the implementation of structural reforms: reforms of product, services and labour markets that increase productivity, help regain competitiveness, improve the business environment and reduce inequality. Stimulating investment remains one of the Commission’s policy priorities. The investment plan for Europe will help to reverse recent downward trends in investment by supporting strategic projects and SME financing. European Parliament support for a European Fund for Strategic Investments initiative has been instrumental in laying the ground for decisive and swift Union action to address the main investment needs in Europe. With all the governance bodies in place since early January, EFSI is now up and running. The take-up so far by the market and public authorities leaves us assured that we will meet the EUR 315 billion investment target well within the three—year deadline. The Commission also shares Parliament’s view on the Capital Markets Union. It is our common objective to support diversification of funding sources, promote cross-border investments and improve access to finance SMEs in particular. Implementing the Capital Markets Union action plan is an ambitious objective. The Commission therefore counts on Parliament’s strong support and commitment, in particular – but not only – for the upcoming legislative procedures. At the same time we agree with Parliament that we must remain vigilant with regard to risks in all areas of the financial system arising in the current market situation. Let me conclude by underlining that I see much common ground between your views and the Commission’s. It is reassuring to know that we can count on your support in building the foundations for sustainable growth and job creation in Europe. I thank you for your attention and look forward to a good and fruitful debate today.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – The creation of this parliamentary report has not proved to be easy. The heated discussions already showed that your monetary policy is a hot topic. "Super Mario", "Magic Mario", "Helicopter Mario", you seem to get a new nickname every week.  But I can imagine that you would rather not get that attention, that you prefer a stable European economy, which does not need unconventional measures. That you also prefer an ECB that has the confidence to fulfil its mandate in all independence. That is why our report calls on national ministers not to interfere in this policy by voting. Because trust remains the most important lubricant of the economy and the central bank deserves this trust, together with the governors of the national banks.  Of course, a debate on the policy pursued remains very important. There are clear arguments pro and contra quantitative easing, but the discussion must remain intellectually honest. Shouting that the poor saver, for example, is the victim, while reckless investors and debt collectors celebrate, that's the truth. Of course, no one is just a saver. Many of my peers, for example, are just enjoying very low interest rates today as a mortgage borrower. Employee, employer, pension saver, we all have an interest in the economy picking up faster.  We must remain vigilant about the risks of this policy - I am the first to say it today - but we must not be paralysed by it. For non-intervention, as some here seem to want, there are many serious risks. That is why I support the balanced vision of this parliamentary report.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, first of all, we congratulate the rapporteur of the report, despite all the differences, Mr Marias. Mr Draghi, welcome, your presence in plenary is always welcome, because it strengthens, among other things, democratic legitimacy. Firstly, we recognise the efforts you are making and welcome your policy, especially with the quantitative easing programme, in an extremely difficult environment, for inflation and a return to growth.  Nevertheless, the euro area is still a fragile and heterogeneous field with political and social divergences. That is why we welcome recently the statement by Mr Cœuré, who spoke of the need to address economic divergences in the euro area and spoke of those states that will have a surplus and will have to make more public investment. That is why I would like your statement on this matter.  Secondly, financial fragmentation is a major problem in the euro area. Borrowing costs for small and medium-sized enterprises remain higher than large ones, in particular, in those Member States that are in economic crisis and things are becoming doubly difficult. And here I would like your view on how to provide low-cost loans to the real economy.  Another issue is cooperative credit institutions which play an important role, both because of their particular operating principles and their mission. The supervisory authorities should bear in mind that there are specific principles that should be respected, and we would also like your comment.  Finally, with two short schools: first, non-performing loans. What is your position, should there be an appropriate mechanism, as in Spain and Ireland or something else? And one last word on deposits and protection. What do you intend to do about those Member States that will not follow your instructions and have the 'à la carte' Banking Union?

name: Stanisław Ożóg
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear Rapporteur, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. The report is a balanced assessment of the ECB's activities. For the first time, however, there are criticisms in this report.  Firstly, it is important to emphasise all the medium- and long-term instruments that should affect europe's economic recovery and which would meet the need for a sustainable recovery of the real economy in all – not in part – the 28 countries of the European Union. It should also be stressed that although the ECB is implementing its efforts to maintain favourable financing conditions, private and public investment in the euro area remains well below pre-current crisis levels. So it is desirable to increase access to finance primarily for small and medium-sized enterprises.  When considering the annual report on the ECB, I would also like to draw attention to, in my opinion, a very important point. This is, firstly, respect for the independence of the ECB's decisions, but also an appropriate separation of the ECB's supervisory role and its decision-making functions within monetary policy. The combination of the two functions should not give rise to a conflict of interest for the ECB.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Marias, and my shadow rapporteurs for their pleasant cooperation in this report. In this report, Parliament expresses strong concern about the effects of quantitative easing, with €60 billion of financial growth hormones pumping into the economy every month.  Mr Draghi, you have said it many times and repeated it again today: monetary policy alone is not enough to get the economy going. It also requires economic reforms and sound fiscal policy. You mentioned it in your speech today as a third point. Do you agree with me that things are not heading in the right direction in these areas? In many countries, the labour market is still locked. It seems as if in several places the mental transition from a job for life to a life full of jobs still needs to be made. Adjusting the retirement age is not yet in order and there are mainly large countries that have the highest debts and the largest deficits, combined with the lowest growth and also the lowest inflation. These countries, on the contrary, are trying hardest to get out of the budget agreements. Not a good development! All this, i wonder whether it is wise to continue and develop quantitative easing in these circumstances. This concern is reinforced by the strongly negative side effects of this type of monetary stimulus for the stability of pension funds and financial markets in Europe. If we do not take the extremely low oil prices with us, inflation is not so dramatically low at all. I therefore wonder whether it is necessary to add another scoop of quantitative easing. Once again, in the light of the fact that the much-needed structural reforms and a sound fiscal policy are still lagging behind, do you still think it is justified that you should pull the cart alone with your quantitative easing, which you should then continue to do?

name: Fabio De Masi
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Draghi has calmed financial markets for a while with "whatever it takes." However, the bad loans in the Italian banking system and the attempt to sell off the toxic waste to the taxpayers with a lot of lametta shows that the euro crisis is continuing! For the majority, every day there is a euro crisis in their wallets, and there are reasons for this. Mr Draghi himself named it in Jackson Hole: there is a lack of public investment to support monetary policy. Banks make little credit by cutting wages, pensions, and government spending because of a lack of investment demand – despite zero interest rates. Quantitative easing thus only leads to financial bubbles, rather than money ending up in the real economy. As a result, the ECB regularly misses its inflation target of around 2% per year. The Financial Times is already mocking the fact that German central bankers have an inflation target of 0 to 0.2%. The ECB also has a responsibility to do so. In Ireland, the ECB threatened to turn the euro down unless the ailing Anglo Irish is bailed out by Irish taxpayers. This was corrupt, not monetary policy.  In Greece, the ECB forced further cuts in wages and pensions. A blind man with a crutch sees that structural reforms have only made things worse. Freely after Bill Clinton: It's the austerity, stupid. The investment strike can only be overcome by public investment. The ECB must support this, for example by buying bonds from the European Investment Bank. Otherwise, the euro is in danger of breaking up or it will be voted out.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Mr Draghi, Commissioner. Thank you, today, for your presence. Mr Draghi, this Parliament has welcomed many of the measures it has taken in recent years, such as unconventional monetary policy measures, or its willingness to maintain sovereign bond-buying programmes, which, even momentarily, has put an end to the sovereign financing crisis. However, Mr Draghi, I have to say that these programmes — and in particular the quantitative easing programme — were late in some cases and poorly designed. We know that the volume of quantitative easing is insufficient. So much so that it's hardly having an impact on the price level, as my partner previously pointed out. And we are also concerned, Mr Draghi, that this programme is not a programme focused on being able to reach the real economy directly — something we have asked for on several occasions — and that we are currently more fuelling speculative bubbles and generating processes of inequality than by making a programme that can truly reach the real economy. And we know that monetary policy doesn't have to do everything; that the lack of policies to sustain aggregate demand is, today, a problem. And that's not your responsibility. But it also seems to us that some of these programmes, like TLTRUs, the results of which we have at the moment, also because of the data we have, are very scarce — have not worked as they should. And finally, Mr Draghi, I have to say that, since we are evaluating your work in recent years, we need to talk about Greece. We are very concerned about the lack of a clear legal framework for mechanisms such as the provision of emergency liquidity; we are concerned that you would make decisions in a totally arbitrary way, depending on whether one Government was one colour or another, especially when compared to what happened in Cyprus; We are also concerned, and with this end, the independence of the European Central Bank, having taken decisions by its Governing Council almost in parallel over time with the Eurogroup, seriously jeopardizing the credibility of the institution.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the ECB's work in 2015 follows what is a long-established political plan. To date, 19 eurozone countries, more than 330 million people, have ceded their monetary sovereignty to the ECB. All the peoples of Europe who no longer control their own currency and banking system must realise that they are peoples who have been deprived of fundamental rights in order to determine themselves democratically and who are under dictatorship in Brussels and Frankfurt. Since the entry into operation of the first pillar of the Banking Union at the end of 2014, the ECB has been managing both bankruptcy monetary policies, inflating banks and supervision of banks themselves, in total conflict of interest. The ECB continues to profess political indications that do not fall within its control, austerity and reforms, paving the way for major stakeholders, investment funds, large tax avoiders, those who pull the strings of this political project and who are strategically disjouring public resources at balance prices with privatisations. Strong shocks are expected in 2016, due to the global economic slowdown and the migrant crisis. We cannot think that the only plan on the table is to further transfer sovereignty to new figures who are not democratically elected and far removed from the needs of the people, as enshrined in the report of the five presidents. That would be a further slap in the face for the citizens by the Eurocracy. That is why we must support a new and democratic political plan for Europe as soon as possible, starting from an exit strategy ordered and agreed by the euro. One thing must be clear: the enemies of democracy are not those who raise doubts about the single currency and the ECB, but those who continue to defend it religiously by not admitting its obvious failure.

name: Gerolf Annemans
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – As if seven years of euro crisis were not enough, socialists, Christian Democrats and liberals have hijacked our good colleague Marias' report here in order to give Draghi a nuanced good report so that he can continue as he has always been.  Mr Marias has indeed been set aside in spite of what he himself is saying about it. A cautious - I think far too cautious - paragraph which was critical of the ECB's possible over-mandate when it started buying up sovereign debt. It all had to die. His report has been hijacked and we have now come here in an annual report that reaffirms the euro religion with Mr Draghi's classic dogma: everything is going well, because if I cannot go any further it would be even worse.  According to that dogma, the way has been paved for Mr Draghi to continue with his debt economy, his unemployment economy, his unitary economy and the transfer union that goes around. And all with a money fountain that keeps spraying, even though it causes no growth and does not bring solace. Which is also not possible, because there is no confidence in the fundamental survival of this currency. Mr Draghi seems to be a gold-in-the-old con man who guides us all to the abyss, to a chaotic implosion, when it would be wiser to deconstruct this currency union in an orderly way. Stopping Mr Draghi here today would probably be a much more interesting and sensible measure!

name: Presidente. –
text: I am sorry, Mr Annemans, but it is not permissible to offend, let alone offend our guests.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Mr President, a single sentence in the report reflects the essence of the existence of the European Central Bank, but also the economic policy of Germany and, by extension, of the European Union, paragraph 11: 'welcomes the unequivocal commitment of the European Central Bank to make every effort to protect the euro which it undertook in August 2012'.  Everything about money, not about citizens, not about nations, not even about countries. Greece last year negotiated with the institutions for its survival. The European Central Bank, faithful to the policy of independence, has stopped providing liquidity to my country to impose the vengeful behaviour of Europeans on their evil little so-called 'brother'.  It is clear that the so-called stability of the euro is simply a means of enforcing Germany's financial interests, so part of the problem. In order to become part of the solution, the European Union must change direction. And this can only be done with nationalist governments that energize the citizen, the family and the nation against money.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in my opinion the monetary policy of the ECB has been properly focused on restoring price stability and on contributing to gradual economic recovery in the euro area. Unconventional measures, such as the asset purchase programme and the negative deposit rates, have been generally successful, if somewhat overdue. Had they been introduced earlier – in my opinion at least – the results would have been probably better. But this is not a critique, Mr Draghi, as I am fully aware of the political constraints within which you have to act and the especially strong opposition to those measures from some members of the Governing Council. But let me tell you that the opposition has been vindicated by the facts. These have demonstrated that you were right and your opponents were wrong. Mr President, we are discussing the European Parliament report today, and I think this is a balanced and objective document. It is a much-improved document compared to the first draft that has been discussed at the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON), which in my opinion was one-sided, biased and full of unjustified accusations against the ECB – especially for matters for which the ECB is not responsible. Mr Draghi, I have one question. At one of our earlier meetings during the monetary dialogue meetings at the ECON Committee, you said that you would consider ‘helicopter money’: that is, the direct emission of cash money to market participants. I would like to ask you: what is your current thinking on this, on the legal grounds, and on the consequences – both bad and good – of this measure in the event that we introduce it? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Rosati, you gave a very astonishing speech. You are holding Mr Draghi's hand above his head and you are saying that the ECB has done a good job. I am very surprised by this, because the ECB has not done its job well at all. The ECB should ensure price stability and inflation at around 2% levels. Since 2013, inflation has not been at that level. How can you say that Mr Draghi has done a good job? Incomprehensible!

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – The ECB has done whatever was possible within its competences as described in the Treaty. As I said, perhaps the quantitative easing could have been undertaken a little bit earlier, but I also said that there were political constraints. In the final analysis, Mr Draghi took the decisions that saved the euro area back in 2012 by declaring that he would do whatever it took to save the euro. I think he deserves credit for what he has done.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank all the political groups for their contribution to improving this text, which is now a balanced text, in which a clear positive assessment of the ECB's monetary policy action is expressed and the importance of the unconventional measures taken in recent months is recognised. I also agree with President Draghi's assessment of further developments in the macroeconomic framework. On the one hand, we are seeing the strengthening of the domestic economy, driven mainly by consumption, and, on the other hand, we are seeing a weakening of the world economy, caused both by the slowdown in emerging economies and by increased uncertainty on the financial markets. Our ability to influence the global economy is limited. However, we can influence what is happening in the euro area, first of all by continuing and adapting the monetary policy measures in place. From this point of view, it is very positive that the Governing Council of the ECB has unanimously declared itself ready to reconsider the monetary policy stance if it does not prove sufficient to achieve the objectives announced. Of course, monetary policy alone cannot guarantee the transition from a cyclical to a structural recovery. For this to happen, it is necessary to continue along the path of socially balanced structural reforms aimed at increasing the growth potential of our economy and, at the same time, budgetary policy, at aggregate level, must go hand in hand with monetary policy, and not against it. Countries that have fiscal space must use it, and the fiscal adjustment of those with less space must continue at a sustainable pace, applying all the rules of the Stability Pact, including the flexibility it contains. Finally, work is needed to complete economic and monetary union, giving concrete form to the long-term vision of the five presidents' report: fiscal backstop, starting work, working on the European Commission's legislative proposal on deposit guarantees. It is, of course, permissible for work on risk reduction to continue, but it must take place within a broader international framework and also taking into account the requirements of financial stability.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: Mr Draghi, you are indeed independent, but you must also be accountable for your policies. Economist Geert Noels, for example, asked you seven questions at the end of last year. It was your chief economist, Peter Praet, who was kind enough to answer it. What were his answers? One and a half trillion euros! That's how much money you've made in the meantime. Inflation has not risen accordingly. Economic growth is also disappointing. But, says Mr Praet, we will continue. We just keep printing money without a limit. Mr Draghi, you are blowing bubbles in our economy. Your policy is an attack on our savings and on our pensions. I would like to recommend that you take a closer look and hear what William White is saying, the economist who did announce and saw the financial and economic crisis coming. What's he saying? Monetary policy becomes less effective over time, and these damaging side effects become clearer and clearer. I think it is time for all of us to think carefully about this.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Draghi, Commissioner, in one minute four ideas.  Congratulations as technical banker, Mr Draghi. However, a technical question: have you not been concerned that China's entry into special spinning rights was almost entirely at the cost of the euro?  Second idea. As a political banker, you know that both I and my group will always support the idea that monetary policy does not solve the productivity or competitiveness of the European economy – that is where we will support it – and therefore the structural reforms pending are what you have to demand in depth.  As a third and as a technical-political banker, I thank you for the introduction and the first steps you have taken in terms of European deposit security. But it's a very slow and still very shy process.  Finally, and congratulating you as a European banker, you in 2014 have managed to make great profits for the European Central Bank in 2014, and that is good. Why don't you imagine how these benefits can help finance a greater and better European project?

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr Draghi and Mr Dombrovskis, monetary policy is not enough, there is also a need for a change in economic policy, and that is what Mr Dombrovskis who is here must answer. Because we need to abandon unilateral austerity and turn to growth, stimulate investment and demand, especially in surplus countries.  Mr Dombrovskis, why is the pan-European deposit guarantee, which is the third pillar of the banking integration plan, delayed? How long will Mr Schäuble veto it? Mr Draghi, are you going to go ahead and strengthen the quantitative easing programme or are you going to pick it up because you have internal opposition from ultraconserval circles expressed by Mr Weidmann? And when will my country, Greece, finally be in the quantitative easing programme and when will it stop borrowing at higher interest rates than other countries? There are signs of a stabilisation of the Greek economy, and you must also take initiatives to keep it from being strangled. (Sõnavõtja nõustus vastama nn sinise kaardi korra kohaselt (kodukorra artikli 162 lõige 8) esitatud küsimusele).

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF)
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, why is the Greek Government not asking the Central Bank to issue money to invest in energy savings and new energies in the Greek economy, because in that case we would not create counterfeit money, we would invest in the real economy and we would have a real change in the economy. Why is quantitative easing reduced to banks?

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL)
text: answer a question with a "blue card". – The break-up of the euro area and the return to national currencies is the agenda of Marie Le Pen, not the Tsipras government, Greece's exit from the euro was Mr Schäuble's plan, which was fortunately cancelled in the summer. The Greek economy is stabilising and we estimate that in the coming period, and as early as the second half of 2016, we will move to positive growth rates. What is needed, and that is why we on the Left are fighting, is not the break-up of Europe, but the change of Europe, social Europe.

name: Patrick O’Flynn (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, Mr Draghi says his policy is working, but under-performance in the euro area is only out of the spotlight because of catastrophe in the Schengen area. The truth is that both these pillars of European integration face collapse. The Schengen breakdown currently produces more shocking pictures on the TV news, but the euro malfunction is also having devastating consequences. Youth unemployment rates of 40% or more in the southern periphery and long-term stagnation are destroying human potential. The ECB report speaks of structural reforms and, yes, these are sorely needed to improve southern productivity; but even if successfully implemented, they will only go a small way to correct imbalances created by fundamental differences in economic strength. Each country needs its own currency so that it has levers of control over interest rates and influence on exchange rates too, just as each country needs to control its own borders.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF).
text: Mr President, Mr President of the ECB, ladies and gentlemen, I would like, above all, to denounce the heavy influence of the main political groups on the rapporteur, Mr Marias, who has unfortunately distorted the quality of his report. In this report we are looking at today, one word is never uttered: the word oil. Needless to say, however, the steep drop in oil prices over the past year and a half is at the heart of economic news. The consequences are a destabilization of the oil industry and of the European economic and financial order. The impact of crude oil prices is central to the level of prices and partly explains the high risk of deflation opposed by the European Central Bank. However, the 50% drop in prices in a few weeks is not the effect of supply and demand on the physical oil markets, but the result of speculation in the derivatives markets.  Each barrel of oil traded on physical markets is traded 200 times on the same day in derivatives markets. Under these conditions, it can be predicted that the sharp decline of recent months will soon recur, but in the opposite direction, as soon as speculators bet on the rise. These large-scale movements directly complicate the ECB's monetary policy and the achievement of its target of 2% inflation.  This volatility on systemic banks has unexpected risks to their solvency as well. Framing speculation in commodity derivatives markets was one of the main priorities of the French G20 presidency, which wanted to moralize capitalism, but five years later we are still at a standstill.  I would therefore like to know, Mr Draghi, what the ECB is planning to do against financial speculation on energy prices in order to ensure sustainable price stability in the euro area.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am convinced that without the determined and professional decisions of the European Central Bank the euro area economy would have remained in stagnation for a long time and would have also gone into deflation. What I think we have discussed less, however, is the impact of cheap money policy for a long time on the savings and long-term investment process. We cannot fail to find that pension funds, insurance institutions and especially long-term institutional investors, as well as the savers, have lost. That is why I think it is legitimate that many ask the European Central Bank: how long do you think this monetary policy of cheap money will continue?

name: Elisa Ferreira (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Dombrovskis, Mr Draghi, thank you very much, Mr Mario Draghi, for the answers he sent me to the questions I addressed to you as a signatory to the report of the five Presidents. I am still waiting for the response of the other signatories, from the other presidents. In its reply it confirms interests, the importance that the European Stability Mechanism could directly capitalise on viable banks and, even today, has reinforced its conviction that the common credit line for the Resolution Fund and stabilisation of deposits are key elements of the agenda. Let us hope that the Council and the Commission will also keep their commitments in the same way. But the truth is that today we have a unique banking supervision, since November 2014. We have had a single resolution for a month and all these elements of stabilisation of the banking union are not operational. And while the single European resolution has not yet actually intervened, the experiences of implementing the new European Resolution Directive ABERD have proved highly problematic, especially in the case of the weakest economies. Today, when a private capital is asked to strengthen private capital to banking and, at the same time, for the first time, it is made bail-in, losses are attributed to senior creditors and depositors in other resolution processes, absolutely contradictory tensions are generated in the market. Contrary to what was intended in this transitional period, the relationship between banks and states seems to me more complicated, intense and dangerous than ever before and is only in the hands of the State, and of those fragile states, the containment of brutal systemic risks. This leads me to ask a number of questions, but in particular the following: who is monitoring these impacts? Is the ECB accompanying you on the systemic risk board? Can the Capital Market Union help deal with the problem of non-performing loans of badly overt credit? And who has the global vision - I end up now, Mr President, thank you very much - who has the global view of the banking system of countries? Is competition policy in the hands of the Commission or is the SSM supported and coordinated by the European Central Bank? These are questions that need to be answered because a bad start to the Banking Union can destroy it and that would be fatal for European stability. Thank you so much for your time and tolerance.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Today we are talking about the ECB with the ECB, good morning, Mr Draghi! You have been pursuing a policy of national special interests for years, you are saving states that are insolvent and banks facing collapse – that is fiscal policy, this is not monetary policy! They have no mandate for this. On 25 July 2012, you said that you are doing whatever it takes to keep the euro together. Mr Draghi, that is not your job either! Their task is to keep the value of the euro stable, not the number of members in the eurozone. Now you say you are not giving up, and now you want inflation. Someone will have to pay for your policy, and it will not be the winners of the crisis, not the perpetrators of the crisis. It will be the people who hold life insurance, who are in occupational retirement provision and are savers. So the little people. And you don't notice, that's the perfidious thing! Their policies do not solve the problems and harm the little people, which is unfair and antisocial. Stop saying that this is a service to Europe!

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr Draghi, the recently-published report on the banking inquiry in Ireland points an accusatory finger directly at the ECB and estimates that over EUR 9 billion could have been saved on applying haircuts to the unsecured, unguaranteed bond holders but for the threats and bullying of your predecessor Mr Trichet. That EUR 9 billion is gone, history. But there is an even greater injustice happening to Ireland right now under your watch, Mr Draghi. I am referring to the ongoing destruction of the EUR 31 billion promissory note bonds. Those bonds were created in 2009 and 2010 to bail out the creditors of two insolvent Irish banks, but more significantly to help protect the euro itself. The banks were non-systemic. Those banks were eventually liquidated, but the ECB now insists that the entire 31 billion must be taken out of circulation by our central bank. Already we have borrowed 6 billion, and our central bank is now going to be forced to burn 25 billion more. Please answer this question. I am asking you today directly: will you please work with us to stop this obscenity? Do not let this be your legacy to Ireland or our legacy to our children. Please answer this question. Make it a first for me in this Parliament that any damn question would be answered!

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Vice-President Dombrovskis, I would like to thank Mr Dombrovskis for his Mr President, Mr Draghi, I would like to thank Mr Draghi for A slowdown in global economic growth, stock market turbulence in China and a rapid drop in oil prices are creating great international uncertainty. In the eurozone, too, there is uncertainty not only because of this global volatility, but uncertainty about the impact of the European Central Bank's monetary policy, uncertainty about the impact of the huge bond-buying program under quantitative easing, which has not led to a relevant rise in inflation or to a boost to the economy. Inflation remains low, with 0.4% in January this year close to zero – good for consumers and purchasing power in the short term, but difficult in the long run. Lending to the private sector is also not starting. In December, banks lent just 0.3% more corporate loans and 1.4% more loans to households, which is disappointing! Since March last year, the ECB has been pumping 60 billion euros a month into the economy – by March 2017, by the end of the program, it will be 1.5 trillion. These massive bond purchases will make the national banks, the central banks, the largest creditors of the Member States. The interdependence of monetary and fiscal policies is increasing, and pressure is mounting on the ECB to keep interest rates low and continue to buy government bonds. At the same time, pressure is mounting on Member States to implement structural reforms. Without structural reforms, fiscal consolidation and public investment, however, there will be no growth and employment in Europe! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, assessing the success or failure of the euro is simple enough because there is a control group: we can look independently at how eurozone and non-eurozone economies have developed, and the non-eurozone ones have developed faster than the eurozone ones. So do you agree with me that the euro is a failed political project, not a successful economic one? Do you agree with me that we should respect the democratic sovereign right of any country which does not want to join the eurozone, and actually we should look at countries leaving rather than joining? (Applause)

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I agree in principle that the democratic rights of each Member State, or of every state in general, should be respected, and I also believe in principle that it would have been more sensible not to introduce a European currency, a single European currency, without further unification. Since this cannot and will not exist at the moment, it is probably very doubtful whether this currency will lead to success. Not as it looks at the moment.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to get back to an issue I raised when discussing the previous ECB report, and that is the availability of bank lending to businesses. Unfortunately, the situation is still unsatisfactory, despite the measures that have been taken lately. European businesses are largely dependent on bank lending and alternative financial sources are quite insufficient to meet the necessary demand. I do still welcome the measures taken by the ECB to address this problem. These include negative interest rates and targeted long-term refinancing operations. I am also happy to see from the early evidence in this year’s report that parallel policy initiatives were relatively effective, especially when it comes to reducing financial stability risk and giving banks funding. However, while the targeted long-term refinancing operation helped stem the decrease in bank loans, the programme did not provide a stimulus to generate loan growth as intended. A total of EUR 400 billion has been introduced into the banking system through five refinancing operations, but bank corporate lending has only experienced a very moderate growth. As the ECB Annual Report 2014 points out, credit conditions for firms remain tight, especially in some euro area countries. We can see that ECB monetary policies were transmitted only imperfectly to borrowing costs. Bank lending is still insufficient at times, and therefore I do ask the Commission to take more decisive measures to stimulate bank lending to corporations and, especially, to SMEs.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr President of the European Central Bank, you know that this Parliament has a record of how you intervene, formerly under the troika and now under the Brussels institutions. Several questions remain about the role of the Central Bank in the implementation of the memorandums, particularly in Greece. Clarification is needed in this regard. I ask you to bring it to us. The rapporteur has indicated that, whatever the quality of monetary policy you are pursuing, it cannot do everything and that there is a need for investment stimulus here and there.  You yourself have said that economic conditions are not so serene and that economic and monetary union must be supplemented urgently, not only by one of the pillars of the Banking Union, this project of the Capital Markets Union, but also by the so-called completion of economic and monetary union, including the establishment of budgetary capacity. You are one of the authors of the report of the five presidents in which this issue was raised. Given the economic situation in the euro area, given the difficulties in which a number of our States are struggling, do you not think that the timetable must be accelerated and that the prospect of waiting until 2017 so that, alongside monetary policy, the tools of economic policy can be fully mobilised is too late? The last question, Mr President, which was not mentioned in Mr Marias' annual report and which is sometimes the subject of this annual meeting, is the question of the use of 500 euro notes. However, you know that this is a recurring issue, particularly when you are looking at the financing conditions for terrorism. Can you tell us a little bit more because it seems to us that your institution will also have to contribute to this issue?

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would also like to recall the declarations made by President Mario Dragi in 2012, who said that the ECB would do everything possible to maintain and defend the Euro. Indeed, since then, the ECB has pursued a policy of very low interest rates – most recently even negative ones – and from March 2015, as we have heard, until March 2017, also the purchase of government bonds on the secondary market at EUR 60 billion per month, i.e. at least eur 1.5 trillion.  While this has kept the debt price for the euro area's most indebted countries relatively low, the credit dynamics of companies are still low, but unfortunately the risk of further speculative bubbles is increasing. The level of investment, both private and public, is still lower than before the crisis, and even the launch of the so-called Juncker Plan is not likely to provide a breakthrough in this regard. As a consequence, EU countries using their own national currencies have been experiencing both higher levels of economic growth and lower unemployment rates than most countries using the euro for several years.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Despite a problematic global environment, the forecasts for EU growth are good: 1.7%. Nevertheless, high levels of debt in the Member States and unemployment rates must continue to fall. Better funding for the real economy, such as small and medium-sized enterprises, must contribute to this. However, the potential risks of low interest rate policy, President Draghi, must not be hidden. I am thinking of pensions, I am thinking of insurance. Many of your political interventions may differ; on the other hand, the insults from the far right are totally unacceptable. In a normal economic environment, setting the key interest rate is sufficient. But in the face of the debt crisis, you have taken many unconventional steps to strengthen monetary policy. You can argue about ways, but the goal is absolutely fine. And one more thing: you have been able to allay some of the concerns about the ECB. The scope of tasks has been criticised, and now we are witnessing a clear organisational and spatial separation of the supervisory and monetary policy portfolios. It worked. And since November 2014, the ECB has been monitoring 122 banks in the eurozone. In order to resolve further doubts, we need to create more transparency. Positions that we share with you in the context of the monetary dialogue and with us in the ECON Committee and with which we agree. It is only regrettable that political experts in particular are aware of these matters, while many economic operators do not yet know this, and unfortunately still not a wider public. We must work together on this.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: As far as I am concerned, this is the latest annual report by President Mario Draghi. Mario has to move. He has failed to meet the ECB's target of bringing inflation to 2% levels. Not since 2013. In fact, we have been at an inflation rate of near zero for months. The deflation spectre is knocking on the door and the oil price continues to fall, as well as declining demand and increasing supply. So we're going to be in deflation later.  But what do we see? The ECB continues to buy up debt securities and thus expects to raise inflation. That's not going to work, even if you double your program. Because what's happening? Debt continues to rise, necessary reforms remain. Stop this program! You've lost your credibility. I ask you to draw your conclusions and step up. Mario has to move.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say the following to President Draghi. You have applied the right monetary policy tools towards reaching the ECB’s objective on price stability in extremely challenging economic times over the past years. The euro is a trustworthy currency; the euro area has remained attractive, and new Member States have joined over the course of the past two years. What is needed to consolidate the recovery in the eurozone and the EU are economic reforms at national level. Devaluing our currency cannot remain the only economic policy tool applied to increase demand for our goods on the global markets. The ECB’s policies buy time, but there is no way around reforms. Member States should not lean backwards, even in good economic times. Those countries that are not competitive, do not reform, do not bring their public finances in order and do not stabilise their banking systems will be heading into the next crisis, and the ECB will not be able to help them. Speaking of price stability, so far core inflation is not heading upwards. The impact of the slowdown in China and other emerging markets is not to be underestimated on the European markets, as you also rightly stated. Given the extension of quantitative easing, the ECB has to provide more information about how it will exit the programme again without having major consequences on inflation targets, on price stability and – most notably – on financial markets. Finally, President Draghi, you said that policy-makers now have a bigger challenge to think about than the euro, as the refugee crisis is more urgent. You are right, but I would also like to add that we have to learn to tackle two major challenges at a time. The fact that the refugee crisis is a bigger and more urgent crisis should not, of course, be an excuse for us not to work on further strengthening the euro in the long term.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Mr Draghi, the measures you are taking are important and valuable, and we appreciate all efforts to open sources of funding to European entrepreneurs, innovators and researchers. But, of course, without fiscal policy measures, implementing reforms and raising competitiveness by investing in development, research and innovation, an economic miracle cannot be expected. Economic growth of 1% or 2% means our lag in the long run. That is why we must do everything to open sources of funding to riskier projects with high growth potential. European solidarity and the functioning of the single market with the same business conditions are needed more than ever in the part of achieving the same credit conditions and the availability of sources of financing to entrepreneurs in all Member States. That is why, as careful as we should be, we should be both quick and determined to further establish a Banking Union and a Capital Markets Union, and we need to be innovative in finding new instruments to finance the economy.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – The European Central Bank, of course, plays a very important role in the recovery of the global and European economy. It has mechanisms that promote growth. It is difficult to choose the right combination of instruments, but in the past the ECB has already demonstrated that it can and can do this: to help the economy. Yet these measures have not been effective enough so far. The money didn't get to the economy. It's not what we expected. However, notwithstanding the criticality towards the ECB, we must also recognise that the ECB's actions alone will not be enough to stimulate economic growth. Reforms are needed, as some of my colleagues have already pointed out. And, of course, individual Member States have not been equally successful in implementing these reforms. We have another economic, financial and social crisis ahead of us, and the ECB has a great responsibility to prevent this from happening through its actions, how it will act.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the revival of growth requires decisive political action in three areas: structural reforms, budgetary policies and monetary policy. With these words, President Draghi answered my questions from September 2014, setting out the ECB's monetary policy measures and then adopted in recent years. However, the crisis has painfully highlighted the economic difficulties that European citizens face when structural rigidities are not corrected by the Member States. Consequently, the activity of the ECB, which must be credited with having, with all determination, defended the euro and price stability, is not enough. Strengthening governance and coordinating economic policies is an obligatory step towards correcting macroeconomic imbalances and exploiting the effectiveness and flexibility of the Stability Pact. If, therefore, there is a recovery in the euro economy, the great fragility of its fundamentals leaves ample room for manoeuvre for the political commitment of states and institutions to the implementation of sustainable and socially balanced structural reforms. I support this report and thank President Draghi for his commitment to preserving the credibility of economic and monetary union through the actions implemented.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen! The European Union is facing two huge crises: the euro crisis and the refugee crisis. These two crises are ghostly. While Mrs Merkel is taking in refugees on an unprecedented scale in the refugee crisis in order to hold the Schengen area together, the European Central Bank is printing money to an unprecedented extent to keep the eurozone together. But both buy time at best. It does not address the structural causes of these problems. For the refugee crisis, these structural causes – wars and poverty beyond the borders of the European Union – are unmanageable. But for the eurozone, that is manageable! For the eurozone, what we have in terms of economic problems within Europe and in the eurozone is manageable.  Greece is the sick man, the sick man, who is almost on the Bosphorus. Greece must leave the eurozone so that the eurozone can return to growth and prosperity!

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the European Central Bank is now the largest centre of power in the European Union. In a sinuous manner and on the backs of the population, the ECB has been appropriating functions that clearly go beyond what was enshrined in its statutes. The ECB joins monetary policy with banking supervision, two clearly conflicting functions. The ECB has long been extending its intervention in the areas of economic governance by using blackmail to dictate to national governments what their policies should be. National states are required to have access to finance. On the contrary, the financial sector is watered with billions of euros and I ask: with what counterparts? What guarantees does the ECB have that these millions distributed to banks will actually reach those in need? The legitimate question today is this: given this promiscuity, what is the ecb's current mission? Promote a stable macroeconomic framework or ensure the survival of the financial sector?

name: Peter Eriksson (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to say that I have great respect for Mr Draghi and the ECB's mission to try to get the European economy back on its feet. It is an extraordinarily difficult task, but I also find it interesting to see the issues of inflation and quantitative easing. What can be done in the future?  What are the possibilities, for example, of making the efforts and efforts made by the ECB more effective? Can the efforts, money and funds spent on society and the economy be better targeted in order to achieve greater efficiency and more impact from investment through the funds used by the ECB? These are the kinds of questions I think it would be interesting to get an answer to.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, there are two ways that you can do things in life. One way is the independent, impartial way. It is the evidence-based way, taking decisions on the grounds of what is best for citizens. The other is to pre-decide on your conclusions and then do whatever it takes to defend them. Well in this report we are urged to do everything possible to defend the euro, so I think we know which of those two it is going to be, and the evidence really does not support that. Take one example of so, so many. I could point out that the Commission expects a 1.7% growth rate for the eurozone in 2016, whereas the World Bank predicts that the UK economy will grow by 2.6%. The report even goes so far as to suggest that officials should be chosen on the basis of gender, which seems to me to be simple, patronising tokenism. So what do I do? Do I vote against this report because it stands for everything that is wrong with the EU, or do I abstain because, thankfully, Britain is not in the euro and so it is not for British MEPs to tell other countries what they should and should not do?

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, in 2012, together with François Drouin, the Secretary General of the Élysée Palace, Mr Bassanini, with mr Monti's support, launched a working group with development banks to see quantitative easing focused on the real economy. The idea was to invest, in structurally deficit countries, in projects that are profitable, such as energy savings, new energy or absolutely safe infrastructure projects.  This project did not come about for a variety of reasons. Why don't you relaunch quantitative easing focused on the real economy?

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all thank you for this debate. Parliament has an important role in the debate on European economic policies, and it was positive to see such an engaged and informed debate. The Commission fully supports the active role of the ECON Committee in the dialogue with the ECB, which is an important component of the ECB’s transparency and democratic accountability. The ECB has acted to address the risk of too prolonged a period of very low inflation, and it will continue to play a key role in the overall policy-setting of the euro area. It is now time for public authorities at all levels to take responsibility within their respective mandates. The impact of the crisis has not only been cyclical, it has also had a significant structural component and it has lowered the potential growth of EU economies. Structural, fiscal and monetary policies each have a role to play in tackling this challenge. This year the Commission will give a clear priority to initiatives which, if agreed quickly, can have a direct impact on jobs and growth. We will focus on new boosts for jobs, growth and investment. We will work to make the internal market deeper and fairer and strengthen its industrial base. Finally, we will endeavour to make economic and monetary union deeper and fairer, building on the conclusions of the Five Presidents’ report.

name: Mario Draghi
text: President of the European Central Bank. – Mr President, I am very thankful for this debate and I will try to respond to most remarks, though – I have to apologise in advance – not all of them, owing to time limits. By the way, some of the statements or questions were inherently political, and so the best equipped to answer are the national governments and the national parliaments, and perhaps your own Parliament. Let me just try to focus on the main points. I take from many of the questions that were asked that many of you have doubts about the effects of our monetary policy measures. Let me try to explain why I have said several times that our policy measures are actually working. All the quantitative indicators show improvements in the provision of credit and financing conditions. To give you an idea, bank lending rates in the euro area have fallen by 80 basis points on average since mid-2014. We should also recall that the report you are addressing is 2014, but many things have happened since then. So let me give you an updated picture with respect to the report. The lending rates have fallen by 80 basis points since mid-2014 and by up to 140 points in the countries that were hit hardest by the crisis. Second, these improved conditions have translated into higher credit and investment in the euro area, supporting economic growth and inflation and strengthening the resilience of the euro area in the face of adverse global developments. To give you an account of this, in May 2014, before the announcement of the credit-easing measures, the loans to the non-financial corporations, to firms and companies, contracted at an annual rate of 2.9%, but since July 2015 the contraction stopped and loans have started to grow. Third, actions to ensure price stability bolster confidence in the euro economy as a whole and also support the ongoing recovery. We reckon that, if we had not taken our measures, the euro area would have been in outright deflation last year and prices would have fallen at an even quicker pace this year. To give an example, our staff has calculated that, in the absence of our credit measures and QE, growth would be one percentage point lower in the years 2015-2017. Inflation would have been thoroughly negative in 2015, and certainly much lower than we are projecting now in 2016. When some of you – several of you – asked ‘what about the SMEs: how is all of this impacting the SMEs?’, well here I can repeat what I said in a press conference: that the pass-through of our measures into the real economy has been significant, if not spectacular, and the credit-easing package in June 2014 seems to have particularly benefited the SMEs , because the lending rates for small loans declined more than for large loans. Regarding the recent surveys, there are two types of survey. One is the bank lending survey, where we ask banks what they plan to do and what are the major factors that they consider in deciding whether to give credit or not. The response is that, basically, there is no limiting factor today. Then there is the Commission’s survey – if I can quote it – and that says the last survey on SMEs’ access to finance reported an improvement in the availability of bank loans for SMEs and also in the willingness of banks to lend in the six months from April to September 2015. However, we have to acknowledge that lending rates for very small loans remain higher than for large loans, in particular in the vulnerable euro area countries, and that of course reflects the higher lending risk to SMEs to some extent. But certainly we want to overcome this situation. So there have been improvements. Have the improvements been as much as we would like? Not yet; we have to do more. We have to make sure that the SMEs’ credit conditions improve further. As far as monetary policy stands, I did say in my introductory statement that, in view of the increased downside risks to price stability, we stand ready – and the Governing Council stands ready – in accordance with our mandate to review, and possibly reconsider, our monetary policy stance in early March if warranted by incoming information. Several of the questions and statements dealt with potential risks associated with low interest rates and our unconventional measures. These concerns relate, in particular, to a perception that low interest rates negatively impact on savers and that our policy may threaten financial stability, with respect especially to pension funds, insurance companies and savers in general. I have discussed these concerns on several occasions, but let me, however, stress the following. For savers, it is true that nominal rates on many types of savings in the euro area are currently very low by historical standards. I also explained that the low-interest-rate environment is actually a reflection of the current economic and structural conditions. So when I am asked how long this will last: it will last until the economic environment improves. So the low remuneration of savings is a symptom, rather than a cause, of the sluggish recovery after many years in which the economy has operated below its potential and unutilised resources have accumulated. Imagine that we were to depart from the current accommodative monetary policy stance. What would happen? Well, it is not difficult to imagine. We would further curtail economic dynamism and ultimately contribute to prolonging the period of low interest rates through further recession. But we should also note that deposits are not the only way in which savers invest their savings.
