So, if one takes a comprehensive view of the financial returns of a household, we see that other financial assets provide a buffer to counteract the low returns of bank deposits. Let me quote a recent study by the Bundesbank that showed that the real return on a typical German household portfolio since 2008 has been around 1.5%, which is certainly lower than the pre-crisis average – but it is certainly higher than many periods during the 1990s, for example. So I do not think we can talk about the expropriation of savings, as some have done – not today, but on other occasions. Finally, the possible implications for savers have to be put in a broader context. Savings are made out of incomes that must be earned. By supporting employment and encouraging investment in the context of continued sluggish demand conditions, our accommodative monetary policy therefore supports the capacity to save. Concerns were also expressed on financial stability and how our monetary policy could have an impact on financial stability. Of course, price stability – our objective – is the prerequisite and the basis for financial stability, and we have to stay focused on delivering price stability. At the same time, we are aware that monetary policy measures may have unintended side effects on the financial system, for instance, if low yields invite excessive risk-taking. But to address this we need macro- and micro-prudential measures as tools, not changes in our monetary policy stance. Let me now just briefly mention comments made on the ECB’s involvement in the macro-economic adjustment programmes in general, which was another point that has been raised. When the Troika was set up in early 2010, the European Monetary Union was not equipped to deal with Member States losing market access. In the run-up to the first Greek programme, Member States saw an advisory role of the ECB alongside the Commission and the IMF, and it was considered to be a useful complement to assure a strong programme. In short, the Troika was created to draw on the diverse experience of the institutions. There was not only a good reason to ask the ECB to provide its advice in the context of the programme work, but also a good case for the ECB to accept this request. Successful programmes had to repair the transmission mechanism of monetary policy and to safeguard financial stability. Let me stress that this set-up was codified in the ESM Treaty and by the co-legislators in the Two-Pack, and the Court of Justice confirmed its legality. In line with this, the ECB has since provided its advice in programmes in five Member States. But we should not forget that the final responsibility for decisions on the programme design and financing lies with the Eurogroup and with the Eurogroup ministers in their capacity – and the ESM – and not with the institutions involved in the programme. As I have said on other occasions, the ECB may not be part of the Troika forever, but I believe the right timing for changing the current set-up needs to be carefully considered, and this is not for me to decide upon. A few remarks dealt with our transparency, and I can only say that this past year has been a year full of decisions that were meant to improve our transparency. Certainly what we have done has strengthened our commitment. The publication of the account of our Governing Council meetings, and the calendars of my fellow Executive Board members and myself and the Supervisory Board Chair, were two further major steps towards increased transparency. But our readiness to provide further information on topics of interest also underlines that the ECB is a transparent institution. To give you some examples: since September 2015, national central banks can publicly communicate about the provision of ELA to the banks in their respective countries in cases where they deem such communication necessary. We also provided further information on our plans regarding the collection of granular credit and credit risk data, better known as AnaCredit. So I can assure you that the ECB monitors developments in the area of governance and access to documents with a view to further enhancing its transparency and therefore its accountability. Let me now comment briefly on completing the European Monetary Union. As some of you have acknowledged, the Five Presidents’ Report outlined a clear roadmap for moving ahead with euro area integration, and I certainly welcomed the Commission’s proposals for short-term measures which should now be fully implemented. For the ECB, of course, the completion of the banking union is of the utmost importance. On the one hand, this means that commonly-agreed rules need to be implemented. The most prominent example of where further progress should be made is the transposition of the Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive (BRRD) and the Deposit Guarantee Scheme Directive (DGSD) in all euro area Member States. We are still missing a common backstop for the Single Resolution Fund. We also need progress on the necessary, still-missing third pillar of the banking union, namely the common European Deposit Guarantee Scheme. Why is it important? Because only such a system will ensure that depositors’ confidence is equally strong across countries and across the whole banking union, which is vital for the future of our economic and monetary union. Implementing the short-term proposal of the Five Presidents’ Report is important and may be necessary, but it is not a sufficient condition to completing the union. So I am looking forward to the proposals for developing the long-term issues. Let me also recall, as I have done on other occasions, that for the euro area to prosper, the recovery cannot continue – and here I certainly agree with some of the statements today – to rely on monetary policy only. Our monetary policy provides the room – as I said, it is an essential condition but is not in itself sufficient – for this recovery to become structural from what it is today, namely cyclical. There was one question about high-denomination banknotes. Let me say that the Executive Board of the ECB has been considering this issue for some time now, and technical work is under way to look at high-denomination banknotes. We have not made a decision yet. There are questions on how to best implement a decision and how to communicate this. We want to make changes, but we want to make changes in an orderly fashion. But rest assured that we are determined not to make seigniorage a comfort for criminals.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank colleagues for their participation in the debate. Mr Draghi, I agree that we need to look to the future, but this presupposes that the ECB must see the mistakes it has made in the past. The ECB underestimated the risks of deflation, and it was only in September 2014 that it woke up and resorted to unconventional instruments, planning quantitative easing which it finally began to implement from January 2015. You have also been slow to cut interest rates as the Fed did in good time and you have not answered, Mr Draghi, because unemployment is still soaring. At the same time, you continued to insist on tough fiscal policy and austerity. You did not reply, Mr Draghi, to the measures you must take to stop the conflict of interest within the ECB. Finally, when are you going to leave the Troika, Mr Draghi, as the Court of Justice of the European Union pointed out to you in judgment C-62/2014, and indirectly, just now, you yourself accepted it? Finally, how can we explain, Mr Draghi, that the borrowing Greece is lending eur 17 billion to its lenders through quantitative easing - with the Bank of Greece? Where did Mr Stournaras get 17 billion euros and the Bank of Greece participated in quantitative easing in 2015?  You do not reply, Mr Draghi, to the way in which the Memorandums are implemented. You wash your hands as Pontius Pilate, and you blame the Eurogroup. But you tried and imposed credit suffocation on Greece in 2015 and capital controls were imposed. Your blackmail policy and the support of lenders to bent the "no" vote of the Greek people in the July 2015 referendum is recorded as a black spot for the ECB. As an unacceptable violation of popular sovereignty in Greece, as the catalysis of the European Republic.  Mr Draghi, in order for the eurozone to actually have a solution to the contradictions, the Eurozone must cease to be a Union of Lenders. The issue of public debt must be resolved and this must be done by writing off the shameful debt and reciprocity of the debt. The above points were in the original proposal, but the PRE, S&D and ALDE groups took care to remove criticism of the ECB. As I said, they were 'king's royals', i.e. they were more 'drags' than you, Mr Draghi.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the next part-session. Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulation)

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Union is going through a time of political uncertainty, the result of the rise of populist parties in some Member States, and economic, mainly due to external factors such as the crisis in China. The European Central Bank has at all times shown its commitment to ensuring the stability and integrity of the euro area and I welcome the measures it has taken. Member States should use expansive monetary policy as an opportunity to move forward with the reform process to ensure that our economic recovery is structural and non-cyclical.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Viviane Reding, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, which contains the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations on the Agreement on Trade in Services (ACS) (2015/2233(INI)) (A8-0009/2016).

name: n/a
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the ACS remains unknown to the general public, even though it has been negotiated since 2013 with 23 countries which account for 70% of trade in services.  We will soon be subject to its rules, whether it is when we take our phone, our credit card, the various means of transport abroad, when we surf the social reasons, on the online shopping sites: no sector, from digital to transport through financial services, will escape it. Therefore, we have no right to make mistakes.  That is why, although the Commission is conducting the negotiations on behalf of the Union, Parliament - which controls the Commission - will draw up very clear guidelines. As evidenced by the report on which this House will vote on Wednesday, the stakes are such that MEPs have joined ranks, across political divides, to change the direction of Europe's trade policy, both in form and in substance of the negotiations. On form, first of all, it's a real break. For a long time, the negotiations were conducted in a vacuum. Since the 2014 elections, things have changed, with the main political groups constantly monitoring every round of negotiations, as well as an intense dialogue within Parliament, with the consultation of no less than eight parliamentary committees, and outside the institutions, with civil society, among others.  At our request, the Council's mandate and the European Union's proposals for commitment have already been made public, and I would like to thank the Commissioner for her help in this regard. With this report, we want to go even further in transparency. In substance then, the change is just as radical. As elected officials, it is our responsibility to delineate which ACS we want and which we do not. Our message is clear: we want better international regulation, fair and robust regulation.  Specifically, this report contains blue lines: more reciprocity in access to foreign markets, especially in the telecoms, transport, public procurement sectors, more rights for consumers against abuses such as roaming charges or spam, more benefits for our SMEs, and finally more participants at the negotiating table , where we can imagine having China as well. Our red lines are just as numerous. Our public and audiovisual services must be explicitly excluded, our right to fully regulated, our fundamental rights and the right to data protection safeguarded, the movement of people limited to the temporary movement of qualified personnel under a contract. Finally, offensive and defensive interests are often wrongly opposed. They are inseparable. There can be no agreement without protection or protection without agreement. Concentrating 25% of world exports and a trade surplus of 160 billion, the European Union can and must make a difference by establishing fairer and stronger international rules. Colleagues, you will have the opportunity on Wednesday to send a strong message to the negotiators that these negotiations will take the right direction, in the interests of our businesses, in the interests of European citizens.  To vote against the report is to vote for the status quo, that is, for the lack of reciprocity, for the absence of rules. To vote for the report is to vote for change, that is, for transparency, for the defence of our values, our interests. To vote in support is to bind the Commission by a clear parliamentary mandate. So let's take responsibility.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission would like to thank Parliament for the broad engagement – so many committees engaged in the TiSA negotiations – and, of course the rapporteur, Mrs Reding, for the work she has done on this, as well as the shadow rapporteurs. It is very important for us to make sure that we negotiate this in close cooperation with the European Parliament. As you know, services account for about 70% of our GDP, but they represent only 25% of our external trade. So TiSA is a tool to try to redress that imbalance and open up foreign markets to EU suppliers. This week, as we speak, negotiators from 23 WTO members are meeting in Geneva for the 16th negotiation round of TiSA. We welcome the progress achieved to date, especially in the autumn: a lot of progress has been made, and we hope to continue on this positive track. I had the possibility to meet almost all ministers whose countries are engaged in TiSA in Davos. We took stock of where we are. There was a positive atmosphere, and many countries wanted to bring these negotiations to an end this year. This is an ambitious, realistic tool, but, of course, for us the content is more important than speed. Having a very ambitious work plan ahead of us, we appreciate the support and recommendations that the European Parliament has included in the draft resolution to be voted on Wednesday. We would certainly take your views into account, as much as possible, as the negotiations progress. As you point out in the resolution, TiSA aims to unleash the untapped potential of more integral global services markets. It could give us a unique possibility to address the existing barriers to the international trade in services that are impeding the expansion of services export. We aim to develop strong, transparent and effective rules across the different sectors that are crucial in enabling global services trade in TiSA. This is also an important contribution to the multilateral trade agenda, in particular in a situation where plurilateral deals are meant to play an increasing role in the post-Nairobi context. So we fully agree with you – and this is important for me personally – that there should be as broad a participation as possible in TiSA so that we can work towards future multilateralisation. As you know, today 23 countries participate in the negotiations, and that represents 70% of global services trade. But we should keep the doors open for more applicants, notably towards large, emerging economies such as China. It would bring TiSA towards the critical mass required for the multilateralisation of the deal. With this in mind the EU has been leading the efforts to design the proposal and the architecture of TiSA so it would be fully compatible with the GATS agreement and thus facilitate future multilateralisation. I am pleased to hear that the European Parliament has appreciated the efforts of transparency. Thank you for pushing on this, and we will continuously try to enhance that. You now receive all negotiation documents, as does the Council. The chief negotiator regularly delivers extensive briefings to the INTA monitoring group led by the rapporteur Mrs Reding, and we are in regular dialogue with civil society. In addition we have ensured that all the reports from the negotiating rounds are available on the internet. I would like to reassure you on some of the points that you raised in the resolution and some of the concerns. The draft resolution calls for horizontal carve-outs accepted by all TISA participants on public services and an assurance that TiSA parties subscribe to the ILO Conventions. However, if we want to see TiSA multilateralised in the framework in the future, we need to base it on the scope of the GATS, and GATS does not contain such broad carve-outs or requirements to subscribe to other international conventions or law which developing and emerging countries would want to see if they joined TISA, and they will have difficulties to subscribe to this. But that does, of course, not exclude us in other fora working with countries for them subscribing to the ILO Conventions. Secondly, and this is very important, public services, culture, labour rights – it is my firm intention, and this is for the whole negotiating team, to ensure that we remain able to unilaterally, here in Europe, decide on the level of protection we want to have. In particular, the EU will never compromise on the essential role of the widest discretion of national, local and regional authorities in providing, commissioning and organising public services as guaranteed in the EU Treaty. This is our approach and that will remain. Third, I note that the draft resolution recommends limited trade liberalisation commitment in cross-border trade: the so-called Mode 1. We will pursue a very cautious approach here, for instance, in some sectors such as financial services. However, in other sectors like digital services, which represent growth potential – especially for us, it is an offensive interest – the cross-border nature is so inherent to the technology that it would not be in the EU’s interest to limit our commitments. Fourth, data protection is a fundamental right of the EU. TiSA will not jeopardise it. Finally, let me say that we have come to a compromise on the e-TiSA architecture as a result of very difficult negotiations, and any changes to ratchet and standstill clauses here would bring us back to day one. But be assured that these clauses only apply to a right to discriminate between foreign and domestic companies – what we call national treatment – and not to liberalisation, meaning market access commitment. In addition, we also deploy broad carve-outs for sectors which we consider genuinely sensitive. So I consider this resolution as a strong signal of support by the European Parliament to continue and to conclude TiSA negotiations. You have clearly marked your red lines and your input here, so allow me to thank you for this and also for all the opinions given by the different committees and to pledge my full cooperation with the European Parliament in the future as we push for a conclusion of this agreement.

name: Thomas Händel
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Mr President, I would like to thank the It is good and important for the European Parliament to give its opinion on TiSA, but more than a raised index finger has not come out on essential issues. I would like to point out that, since 2007, we have been ironed out billions in 64 cases through the Globalisation Fund, which in the majority was the negative consequence of so-called liberalisations. It is precisely for this reason that the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs has called for the ratification, implementation and application of eight minimum labour standards of the International Labour Organisation to be firmly anchored and for violations to be made enforceable and sanctionable. The report does not contain this, it contains the now innocuous phrase 'should be respected'. Countries such as the US, Pakistan and Turkey will be very impressed. We should exclude public services of general interest and not include in this report any commitment to liberalisation that is irreversible. Trade in services cannot be fair and social.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: draftser of the Opinion of the Committee on Development. – Mr President. Thank you to everyone who is working to mark some lines of negotiation that make this agreement a little less nefarious. Thanks especially to the members of civil society, because you have been the most shrewd readers of the filtered texts, finding and denouncing the chapters that make the ACS simply inadmissible. It seems that those who support this Agreement have learned the lesson very well with the TTE report in June. They did not want to start from an openly outrageous text, but to coat the harmful core of very nice but mostly superfluous words.  It remains to be seen what each will vote on in the amendments that really matter: those that unambiguously demand the use of positive lists, the firewall for the uncontrolled expansion of financial services, or the blunt rejection of the infamous status quo and ratchet maintenance clauses. I trust that no one will want to postpone the vote on the report on the grounds of the number of amendments. Since citizens are not consulted or informed, however less than letting them come up and the amendments reflecting their will be voted on.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the objective of the TiSa, like that of any trade agreement, must, in our opinion, be to bring benefits to European consumers and workers through the inclusion of ambitious rules that promote long-term growth and that are able to regulate the provision of the various services. In this respect, with regard to financial services too, the European Parliament is calling for the implementation and application of international standards to be promoted, without, however, making new commitments that could jeopardise European Union regulations in the financial sector. The TiSa must also be used as an opportunity for a global system to combat tax fraud, evasion, aggressive tax planning and money laundering in the financial services sector. Last but not least, we call on the Commission to continue along the path of transparency, which is fundamental to bringing European citizens closer to the decisions we take every day. We hope that the committee's vote in favour can also be confirmed by this House.

name: Virginie Rozière
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Mr President, with the agreement on trade and services, a new free trade agreement is coming to the table, a new discussion in the European Parliament, and this discussion again raises the same questions and reveals the same problems that we have encountered with other agreements. First, a question about the objective, because a free trade agreement is not an end in itself. It only makes sense if it is favourable to European businesses and citizens and this requires simple principles: the conditions for fair competition, reciprocal access to markets and, above all, the maintenance of the possibility of legislating in the direction of the general interest. And then we have the same problem on the method, with always this lack of transparency, both for the representatives of the European people that we are and for civil society.  Therefore, we must send a clear message in this report: we want more transparency, we want to prevent tax evasion and social dumping, we want to protect the personal data of European citizens and we want to exclude from this agreement a number of services: public services, of course, but also cultural services. I thank all the colleagues and the rapporteur, who propose to send a number of messages in this regard. I imagine that the rapporteur is acting against the will of a part of her political group and I thank her for this effort.

name: Terry Reintke
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. TiSA is a very far-reaching agreement which will also and above all affect the local and regional level. The Committee on Regional Policy is therefore very clear in its opinion: TiSA must not go against the objectives of European cohesion policy, the EU's main investment instrument. We welcome the fact that the exception to public services, which were mentioned in our opinion, is now firmly anchored in Mrs Reding's report. It is essential to respect the principles of universal accessibility, quality, safety, affordability and equal treatment. TiSA must not restrict the capacity and responsibilities of local authorities in the European Union so that they can achieve the objectives of the common good and fully represent the interests of citizens. It is the task of this Parliament to protect the interests of European citizens and, therefore, to maintain a good supply of public services. That is the point of the opinion of the Regional Committee on the TiSA agreement.

name: Wim van de Camp
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Europe is facing major challenges at the moment. We know the problem of the flow of refugees and the increasing nationalism. However, we in the transport sector see enormous opportunities in the Agreement on Trade in Services, the TiSA Agreement. If you look at what we are doing in the field of rail transport, but certainly maritime transport, Europe has great opportunities in the TiSA agreement, including with its other services.  I would also like to draw attention to the social aspects of workers in the transport sector. They are a little anxious for too much influence from outside Europe. And I call for particular attention to be paid to the position of postal services and public transport. But in general, I wish the Commissioner, but also Mrs Reding, every success in completing the TiSA agreement.

name: David Borrelli
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as draftsman of the opinion adopted unanimously in the ITRE Committee, where we supported both the general structure of the Reding report – transparency, reporting and protection of public services – and the specific needs of telecommunications and energy, I would like to explain why Parliament has intervened. Parliament is moving, by supplementing the Council's mandate, to establish further constraints which this delicate negotiation must respect. These are constraints that concern the substance: respect for our sovereignty, reciprocity, guarantee of real benefit for citizens and businesses, because it is particularly important to preserve our economic and social model, recognising the importance that we attach to our public services in the Union. And these are also constraints on the procedure: access to documents, extensive consultation with all parties and permanent control of Parliament. We must ensure that the negotiations will respect all the precautions rightly demanded by the European citizens we represent. Let it be quite clear, therefore, to the citizens that on Wednesday Parliament will not vote 'yes' to a treaty, but will vote for a more stringent and precise mandate for the negotiators.

name: Daniel Caspary
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Ms Reding is nominated for the MEP Award to the Committee on International Trade this year. I think that if you look at her report today, she definitely deserves this prize. She said a sentence that I found remarkable, and that sentence alone deserves the price! She said: no agreement without protection, but no protection without agreement.  That is what our group in the European Parliament is all about. We want to make agreements. We want to create globalisation, we want to establish binding rules that can be encumbeced and on which our companies, but above all our workers, our consumers, our fellow citizens, can rely. And I believe that the fact that, for the second time today, we in the European Parliament are dealing with TiSA in detail is a good sign. Before the start of the negotiations in 2013, we already had a report from the European Parliament, where we set out our points very clearly, and Viviane Reding and colleagues have taken sufficient time in recent months to go into detail, to work out better what are important to us. I call on the Commission: please, Commissioner, take on board what the European Parliament will decide on Wednesday.  I assume that this will be a very broad majority, and if you then bring this agreement home with these results, then I am pleased that we can really give our citizens something to promote services. It's not about anything. If you go abroad for skiing, you will accept a service. If you wait for an elevator abroad, you provide a service. Those who have their life insurance abroad accept foreign services, so it is time to regulate them internationally.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Caspary, my question goes in the direction that, of course, trade in services, on the one hand, brings higher wages and thus strengthens purchasing power. If you buy cheaply, our businesses will become more competitive. My question is this: is it really important for the employment impact in Europe that we conclude such contracts, and can small and medium-sized enterprises also benefit from this?

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Rübig, I would like to thank mr Rübig for his excellent work and for his excellent work. That is exactly what you are talking about. On the one hand, shopping becomes easier and cheaper. But what is most important is that selling is getting better. And it is precisely in the services sector – which is one of the areas where many countries have positive trade balances – that if we manage to establish binding rules here, which small and medium-sized enterprises in particular can adhere to and which can be addressed, then we are doing exactly what is urgently needed, namely the creation of jobs, which are not the main focus of the large companies. , but above all in small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the other shadows. These TiSA negotiations are controversial. Services are crucial to our economies and their quality has a direct impact on jobs, fairness at work and social cohesion. In this House we have the power to veto any trade deal, and if we use this power wisely in the negotiations we can deliver a more democratic EU trade policy that works for people and not just for profit. To do that, we have to set out clear mandates for the negotiators on what we are willing to accept and what we will not. We found such an agreement in the Committee on International Trade in the middle of January. We got support from six of eight political groups, and I am now calling on colleagues from all sides of this Parliament to confirm this strong mandate in plenary and, in so doing, to make it impossible for the Commission and the Member States to disregard our views and the public’s concerns. This is not a vote on whether we are for or against a TiSA deal; it is about setting out red lines. We should be clear: today’s global rules reflect the analogue era, whilst we are in a digital world, and they need to be updated. We need new safeguards and protections. We want a full, unambiguous exclusion for all public services. We need rules to guarantee public authorities’ right to regulate and, while we are good at exporting services in Europe, which is creating and maintaining millions of jobs in the EU, we should do what we can to create new opportunities for our economy. At the same time, we should ensure service sector workers know that we are on their side and that we will not accept an agreement which intensifies social dumping. We need to re-regulate globalisation, and TiSA could help us achieve that. But the Commission needs to get it right. EU negotiators must change the EU’s priorities in the TiSA negotiations. They need to see that we are serious, and that is why we need strong support for this resolution when it is voted upon in plenary. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: n/a
text: "blue card" question. I know Mrs Kirton-Darling as someone who considers trade union rights very important, but we have also heard Commissioner Malmström say that she does not want to include the ILO rights, the ILO treaties, in the TiSA Treaty. I wonder if it will accept the TiSA Treaty if the ILO, the eight basic conventions, are not included in the TiSA Treaty.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – In these negotiations – in the GATS agreement at international level which we are looking to revise – there is no social chapter and there is no inclusion of the ratification of ILO standards. We have tussled with this inside the Committee on International Trade (INTA), as well you know. We have worked out how to tackle ensuring that those basic fundamental labour rights are reflected, and the report and the compromise that we reached in the INTA Committee actually sets out a clear demand for all TiSA parties to ratify and to apply ILO Conventions, not in the TiSA agreement but in practice – and, in reality, practice is the thing that we need , not words on paper, and I think this report is a strong step forward.

name: Emma McClarkin
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I welcome the Commissioner. It is great that she is here in what is going to be a vital debate that is actually one that is going to affect tens of millions of jobs in the European Union. The Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) has the potential to add GBP 20 billion to the annual GDP of the EU, and with services accounting for 70% of our EU economy. The UK is one of the biggest exporters of services in the world, and so my Member State has a keen interest in the advancement of talks at a plurilateral level. And we have managed to attract very broad support in the committee for this report, which shows that many of my fellow colleagues also understand the significance of this trade agreement. On the one hand, we must ensure that TiSA is an ambitious agreement that tackles the modern-day issues of the 21st century, such as trade in digital services and recognition of and help for the inclusion of small- and medium-sized enterprises in global supply chains. But, on the other hand, we must take on board public concerns about trade deals and their perceived threat, which is why the committee has included the language on the protection of public services such as the NHS and continuing to allow Member State governments to manage the services as they see fit. I am confident that this language is secure and offers the guarantees that people need. To conclude, I believe that this report offers a solid grounding of support from the European Parliament to the Commission for the advancement of the Trade in Services Agreement that I hope will open up market opportunities for European businesses within a rules-based system that we can then take on a multilateral level.

name: El Presidente. –
text: Mrs McClarkin, you have a 'blue card' question from Mr Dartmouth. Don't you accept it?

name: Emma McClarkin (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I have to go.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the European Union is the world leader when it comes to the export of services. We expect the sector to become even more important. Our service providers are competitive, as the EU itself is already very open and foreign companies are treated equally on our market. There is therefore a lot to be gained by seeing more countries reciprocally opening up their markets to EU service providers and having a level playing field across a larger group of countries. In fact, we would ultimately like TiSA to become a multilateral agreement. Similarly, services are being developed in new areas, such as the digital economy, which will require the rules to be updated. Everyone with internet access could in principle offer a service in a third country. The Trade in Services Agreement should contribute to clear rules to ensure that principles such as fair competition, but also fundamental rights, are respected. In today’s report the Parliament calls on the Commission to aim for an ambitious agreement, especially in sectors such as e-commerce, telecommunication, financial services, procurement and transport. I think – and this is important to underline amidst all the concerns that also have to be addressed today – that we have every reason to be self-confident. This Parliament does confirm existing legislation and standards are not lowered and free trade should follow rules. Therefore, public services and audiovisual services are also confirmed to be excluded in our report, and TiSA cannot force national governments to break open monopolies on the provision of, for example, water or electricity. I am happy to see that we have, together with the shadow rapporteurs and all colleagues, worked on an interim report on these very important negotiations, and we hope that you will continue to represent the EU with the ambition and self-confidence that we should have here to make sure that the rules-based system is strengthened and that more countries come on board and that trade-in-services relations become more reciprocal. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I would like to thank Mrs Schaake very much for taking this blue card and for showing a courtesy of which Ms McClarkin is clearly incapable. My question is this: do you think that labour rights should be installed, ipso facto, into all the EU’s trade agreements, or do you think that labour rights are better determined and decided at the national level?

name: Marietje Schaake (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – What we have put in this resolution that deals with the trade-in-services negotiations that are ongoing, is that we would like to see all the other partners to this agreement ultimately respect labour rights as enshrined under the ILO. But I agree with my colleague from the UK, Jude Kirton-Darling, when she says that the practice of respecting standards is more important than seeking to underline demands on paper which may not be realistic. So, indeed, strengthening the rules-based system in trade, including trade in services, is there to raise the bar when it comes to standards, including labour rights.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, on Friday, President Schultz launched an attempt to postpone the vote on TiSA on various technical pretexts, as was the case some time ago with TiSA's twin sister, TTIR. And why does the president want to postpone it? Because he doesn't know if his group will vote in favour of the deal or against it. And why doesn't he know? Because this agreement is not needed by the European Union and not many Members want it. GATS already exists, if changes are needed, let's modernise it!  The only ones promoting such agreements are multinational companies and their political representatives. We know the work: deregulation, deregulation, deregulation. Deregulation of rules and services, weakening of states to regulate cases, restriction of small and medium-sized enterprises, questioning of rules and quality of work.  Even now, we propose that Parliament ask the Commission to withdraw from the negotiations, as Uruguay has done. We are asking for power for governments to change policy and agreements if they want to and citizens vote for it. A clear exclusion of public services from the agreement under discussion. Otherwise, services such as health and education will soon be privatised. Ratification of the International Labour Organisation's employment conventions, environmental protection, data protection and privacy. Stop voting for agreements that undermine Europe's social foundations.

name: Julia Reda
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the signal coming from this report to the EU negotiators is quite clear: the EU negotiators need to go back to the drawing board. The negotiating mandate does not reflect the views of the public and indeed not the views of this Parliament. The public interest has not been sufficiently taken into account. Europeans are opposed to the liberalisation of public services through TiSA. They are opposed to ratchet and standstill clauses and other measures that may limit our democratic rights to regulate in the public interest. Challenging the Commission’s negotiating strategy on TiSA is therefore an important achievement of this report. But for this Parliament to really be taken seriously as a voice of the people in this negotiation, we have to become bolder. We have to clearly reject any agreement that is not firmly based on a positive list approach. We have to be consistent in the criticism formulated in this report and demand the EU negotiating mandate be changed to adopt Parliament’s position. If that does not happen, then the Commission has to be sure that we will be prepared to reject TiSA. There are still no convincing reasons for abandoning the multilateral approach in favour of closed-door negotiations between individual countries. These agreements put developing countries at a disadvantage because they do not have a seat at the negotiating table. Civil society has even less access to the TiSA negotiations than on TTIP, and in their analysis they have had to rely quite heavily on leaks. Leaks of the e-commerce chapter in particular have raised many red flags. We must not let TiSA undermine the fundamental rights to privacy and data protection. We must not let TiSA undermine our ability to ensure fair competition and consumer protection, for example through rigorous net neutrality provisions and the right of users to use any technical equipment they choose to access the internet. These are laws that are still being developed to some extent and where it is important that we do not let ourselves be locked into a trade agreement that will limit our ability to safeguard our digital rights.

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Treaty on Trade in Services, the TiSA, seems to have a dual personality. On the one hand there is the good TiSA, which the Commission presents to us every day, the one that will create jobs, the one that will increase growth, the one in which workers will be safe and protected. On the other hand, however, the stolen texts show us a dark and dangerous TiSA, that of wild liberalisations, the one that will abolish forever the border between state and private, the one that will put an end to public services as we have known them to date: health, water, school, the free Internet. But then I ask myself: what is the TiSA? What is TiSA? We are still a long way from approving it. The negotiations are very secret and there is still no way of knowing which of the two personalities will prevail over the other. But in any case we will be here to watch, because sooner or later, Commissioner, this Treaty will come to this Parliament. Next Wednesday we will be voting on a text which will put our concerns and demands in black and white. This is not the TiSA text, but guidelines for the negotiators, who will have to stick strictly to it, because we, Commissioner, will be waiting for you at the gate.

name: Franz Obermayr
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Indeed, this report contains many promises: better protection of public services of general interest, consumer protection standards and workers' rights. But in the face of TTIP, many citizens no longer believe this. And I would like to bear in mind that this report confirms the Commission's course. After all, the Commission has been promising for years that our European standards will supposedly be protected. I'm just thinking about our privacy - what it looks like. The report also calls for TiSA to be opened up to even more parties, explicitly to China and to the free movement of skilled workers there. When we consider that China had about 6.4 million university leavers in 2013, I wonder whether the Institutions of the Union have also given some thought to this. Ultimately, I have no confidence in this so-called trade liberalisation, especially when I think of the rapporteur having a close relationship with relevant companies, such as Aqua or Bertelsmann. And for these companies, the TiSA agreement will certainly not be a disadvantage.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, the agreement on trade in services, while theoretically aimed at helping the European companies providing these services worldwide, is in fact another blow to the idea of the national state. Public control over financial services is restricted and the state monopoly in these areas is effectively abolished. The State cannot intervene to protect the interests of its citizens and when it participates, participates in a very small percentage and cannot lay down the rules by which the provision of such services is regulated. We therefore have a reduction in state intervention and at the same time the interests of both citizens and small companies are being affected at the expense of large multinationals.  In addition, the State is obliged to keep records of these companies and to bear their costs. Moreover, if some elements proposed by the UNITED States are adopted, then the state will not be able to give pensions to its citizens. This is happening at the moment in my own country of Greece, where an attempt is being made to enforce this practice. Finally, there is the possibility that we may have a leak of personal data to countries which are characterised by their great corruption. So... (The President removes the floor from the speaker.)

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this agreement will break new ground in terms of market access, but it will also enhance international rules in the fields of transport, digital and financial services. It will also cover a large proportion of the world’s trade in services. With this in mind, it is obvious that this is a great opportunity to open up new markets for companies and to consolidate the EU’s position as a world leader in services. Throughout our work, we have supported a comprehensive and balanced negotiation process, and we have called for even more ambitious commitments across parties, sectors and levels of government – in particular in public procurement, telecoms, transport and financial services. However, let us not forget about consumer rights in terms of roaming fees, transport carriers or credit card fees when used abroad. With that in mind, I fully support the exclusion of public and audio-visual services from this agreement. It is also great to see that, in the digital sector, we are pushing for comprehensive prohibition of forced data localisation and for wide-reaching data protection. With all that in mind, I can fully support this report. I would like to congratulate and thank Madam Reding for her great work and success on this balanced report.

name: David Martin (S&D).
text: – Mr President, given that, as others have said, 70% of our workforce is employed in the services sector, TiSA is a major opportunity for Europe. TiSA can level the global playing field by giving EU companies the same level of market access that third countries currently enjoy in our market. TiSA can be good for small and medium-sized enterprises, in particular, those which find non-tariff barriers more difficult to overcome than bigger enterprises do. TiSA – as we have just heard – can be good for consumers if it tackles the problems they often face with service providers based in third countries. TiSA can be good for workers if domestic labour rights are protected and Mode Four is outlawed from undermining their conditions. I have used a conditional ‘can be’ intentionally. Whether TiSA turns out to be positive depends on protecting our public services, on protecting governments’ right to regulate and on ensuring a high quality of level for data protection. TiSA will only command the support of my Group if it represents, at the end of the day, our values and aspirations. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Martin, I respect the position that you have expressed. I would just like to go specifically into ratchet clauses. I know that Part B, subsection 4, of the recommendations to the Commission specifically opposes such clauses. They would be very damaging if they were included in the agreement. Can you confirm whether you would vote against any such agreement if it still contained a ratchet clause by the time TiSA came to a full vote?

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Our position on this issue, and in terms of all trade agreements, is that we do not support ratchet clauses. We support the right of governments to determine domestic policy. If it decides that a public service should be a public service, no matter what has happened before, it should have the right to return a public service to the public.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Services are an important sector in the EU and also in Germany. The share of value added is constantly increasing. The importance of services for international trade is correspondingly high; we have heard that. It is well known that international trade creates the opportunity to raise absolute and comparative cost advantages that benefit consumers and increase international competitiveness. That too has been emphasised here. TiSA fits seamlessly into the WTO's trade order as a building block. I am following this process positively and calling for the most comprehensive free trade agreement possible. This report responds to this demand without jeopardising public services of general interest. That is why I voted in favour of the report and hope that the negotiations will proceed quickly.

name: Helmut Scholz (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur Reding, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work on the work she has done. Your report includes a number of our demands as a result of broad social expression and mobilisation against TiSA. I expressly acknowledge that. However, many important demands from the municipalities, trade unions and consumer protection associations, which we transport with our amendments, have not found a place in your compromises. For example, we are calling for only positive lists to be used. For what is not mentioned is not subject to the market. Why couldn't you simply leave the demands of the specialist committees to stand, instead of merely 'taking them into account' in lower-quality paragraphs, in other words watering them down? In the voting list, you spoke out against almost every single recommendation by the specialist committees, which tried to shape globalisation in the interests of consumers and producers. Where then are the red lines, for example of the EMPL Committee: legally, binding, enforceable? Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her I do not believe that this resolution will change the way the TiSA negotiations are conducted, because the Council's mandate is different. That is why we will not be able to vote in favour.

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Tonight we are debating the resolution on the TiSA agreement. It is one of several agreements in the making right now and it must be seen together with the TTIP agreement with the US and the CETA agreement with Canada. There is a great and mainly well-founded concern about what these agreements can mean for the environment, consumers and procurement, and about our ability to recapture failed public privatisations.  Trade is good, but it is not an end in itself and it is not a superior environment and democracy. That is why we now need to send a clear message to the Commission. The text on the table has several good wordings in protecting the right to regulate the protection of personal data and the protection of the public sector, but it can be better.  I therefore hope that you will support the Greens' amendments, which seek to make the proposal even sharper and even better with proposals for a positive list, and so on. It is about safeguarding the opportunity to be able to make good decisions in the future as well.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question ("blue card") in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. You mentioned the green aspects, as I understand it, a relatively small occurrence. But in the case of a trade agreement, and especially a trade agreement on services, what aspects did you specifically want to see?

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE)
text: answer ("blue card"). "These include procurement rules, but it is also about the possibility of being able to take decisions in the field of climate policy.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I have just received an agency report: the WHO is calling a global health emergency because of the Zika virus. I know that we discussed this earlier. But if it is a global emergency, then I think it makes sense for our agenda to be adapted to it if we want to be a global player.

name: El Presidente. –
text: Mr Gericke, you may not have been at the beginning of the session, but this matter has already been addressed and a determination has therefore been made. Continue.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which We have witnessed this afternoon, as the chairman of the Group of the European People's Party ( christian democrats) and European Democrats, Mr Weber, made clear in the debate on the Rules of Procedure that he wanted to push through the TiSA agreement this week. He described amendments from concerned groups as a delaying tactic. We should not agree in this House to free trade in public services, certainly not under such a presign. Public services must provide basic social services that are affordable, available to all citizens and not for profit. Private health care will never have an interest in healthy citizens. Should the waste be left behind in the future and electricity should be switched off, because the unemployed can no longer pay the profit-oriented prices? Public services are necessary when market rules no longer meet the requirements. What is more, public infrastructure and services of general interest do not, in principle, belong in private hands. The temptation to put one's own corporate profit above the common good is simply too great. I reject this agreement with the same deep conviction with which I reject this Europe of banks and speculators.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the report we are discussing today aims to make an assessment of the first two and a half years of negotiation of the Agreement on Trade in Services, but to make clear recommendations to the Commission. We must give the Commission the necessary leeway to continue the negotiations, without giving up the improvement of European Union rules. We support maintaining the right to regulate the parties and transparency in the negotiations.  This Agreement is of vital importance to the European Union. We are the largest exporter of services with 25% of world exports – in 2013 we obtained a trade surplus of 170 billion euros in this sector. In addition, exports of services to the European Union have doubled in the last ten years.  It is important to us that the Agreement is as multilateral as possible and that it has the ability to regulate and manage public services of general interest, the ability to regulate for the consumer and the guarantee that social and consumer protection standards will not be lowered.  And congratulations to Mrs. Reding for the magnificent work she has done.

name: Bernd Lange (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. If we want to put this text in a concise formula, we have to say: 'yes' to high-quality services, 'no' to the sale of public services, 'yes' to fair market access conditions and strong workers' rights and 'no' to social dumping. This succinct formula is just right to deal with a trade agreement on services. As far as workers' rights are concerned, we must create a fair basis so that there can be no dumping by sending workers. I also think it is good that the report points out that certain directives in the European Union must also be amended to ensure the principle of 'equal work, equal pay, equal rights for men and women'. In this respect, I welcome this approach. I also hope, Commissioner, that cooperation does not just mean that we work together, but that this is also a clear 'yes' to the text and a clear 'no' to lazy compromises.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: – These days, the European Parliament is making full use of its role in co-creating the European Union's trade policy. We endorse the negotiating recommendations for the Trade in Services Agreement, the so-called TiSA. I would like us, as representatives of the citizens, to be involved in not taking unnecessary, false myths around the negotiations, but from negotiating constructively an agreement that has the possibility of bringing about improved services for the more than two dozen participating countries. TiSA is a chance for our consumers to access cheaper services abroad and provide them with more options when travelling or shopping online. TiSA is a chance for our entrepreneurs to create jobs and make it easier for them to penetrate markets in third countries. The services offered today by the citizens of the European Union are of good quality. Our task is to help to get them to third countries and to modernise international trade rules to match the modern world and to exploit the potential offered today, for example, by the digital sector and financial or professional services.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL).
text: – TiSA, the Trade and Services Agreement, is the ugly brother of TTIP and CETA. And those conventions didn't get a beauty award either. TiSA is yet another example of how the European Union is on the leash of multinationals. This time they are the really good friends of services.  There is nothing against boosting the economy, but it is at the expense of labour rights, democratic control and the economy of other countries. That's what TiSA is going to do. TiSA forces countries to open their markets, it puts public services at risk and it makes it impossible to retreat on progressive insight. I would like to urge Members to vote in favour of Amendment 20, so that we call on the Commission to withdraw from the negotiations. If you really want to protect public services, TiSA is the wrong way.  I would also like to call for the abolition of the so-called ratchet clause, Amendment 29, and for the protection of small and medium-sized enterprises, Amendment 49. And I would ask you to also present the agreement to the national parliaments, as described in Amendment 53. And especially for Mrs Kirton-Darling: Amendment 36 for the basic treaties of the ILO as a binding condition.

name: José Bové (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, they have been trying to impose the general agreement on trade in services for 30 years now.  In 2013, the previous report did say it was a failure. In the WTO, we do not know how to do it, because it goes against the interests of the people. Today, we are once again trying, with a very small private club of 23 out of 190 countries, to impose a general agreement on trade in services. No one in the world wants it! When you want to open negotiations, well, for example, the United States says to China, "We don't want China to be part of the negotiations." And now Uruguay has just come out. But why? Perhaps simply because it is something that goes against the public interest: it is what people have been saying for 30 years. When they protested against the general agreement on trade in services, that was what they were saying. But the agreement that we are trying to impose in countries is even worse than the general agreement on trade in services. This is called, in WTO jargon, "an agreement." This means that once again we will open up all the services. For it is wrong to say that public services will be protected, because within these services there are already systems that allow them to be opened up to foreign actors.  So today very clearly... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – First of all, of course, I would like to thank the rapporteur, my colleague Viviane Reding, for these recommendations. I myself represented the position of the Political Group of the European People's Party in the econ committee, and I know very well that there is a great deal of work and coordination behind this report. I am therefore very sorry that some want to stop the adoption of an agreement that could make it easier for the Member States of the European Union to exchange services and more jobs. It often turns out that opposition stems from fear or ignorance, so it is very important that we be as transparent as possible and that people have as much information as possible. Sometimes, however, this opposition simply stems from a desire to maintain monopolies. Competition is not always desirable, of course, but if it is not, it is us, the consumers, who suffer the greatest damage. I want, of course, a successful job, but above all I would like these negotiations to be as transparent as possible in advance.

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Today's trade in services means ever longer value chains, increased digitisation, unclear dividing lines between what are goods and what are services, and this requires new clear rules. Tisa must, however, under no circumstances lead to social dumping, to unfair competition, to poor working conditions and to the exploitation of people and the environment.  I therefore welcome the fact that, in this report, Parliament so clearly demands respect for the core ilo conventions, and calls on all parties to ratify the ilo's basic standards. I see this as absolutely crucial, together with increased transparency, strengthened protection of public services and the guarantee of the right of states to regulate the public interest – that is, crucial to whether there is to be sufficient broad support in this Parliament for the TISA agreement. All this must be done otherwise it will not be feasible.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I am surprised by your speech. You say: this resolution confirms my mandate to continue to negotiate in the way I negotiate today. Listening to all my colleagues, at least a large majority, but above all to listen to the rapporteur, Mrs Reding, we hear that the resolution clearly asks the Commission to change its course and, above all, to respect a number of blue lines and red lines. Do we have to remember those red lines? Explicit exclusion of public services, no liberalization by default and without return, protection of workers, no social dumping, data protection as a fundamental right. All of this is included in the resolution and is therefore not included in your negotiations at this time. Therefore, to continue your negotiations in the direction that you are conducting them today is to take the risk of having a coherent majority in this Parliament that will say no to the trade in services agreement. I ask all parliamentarians who will vote for this resolution to be consistent, that if you do not respect it, they will have to commit to voting against this agreement.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D).
text: – Mr President. Welcome, Commissioner. We believe it is essential to update the global rules of trade. We cannot be regulating the most important part of international trade with rules from before the internet age. Updating and curbing social dumping, ensuring data privacy, regulating online commerce, roaming and, of course, reciprocating them is critical. Because trade must be an instrument at the service of consumers and, of course, also of our companies. I support this resolution because I think it makes clear what the European Parliament's demands are on the Commission for the negotiations to go the way we believe they need to follow. It is essential to say loud and clear that we demand the total exclusion of all public services, respect for the social and labour rights of workers, the protection of data, the regulation of financial and banking services and, of course, also the right to cultural diversity. I believe that the Commission — and you, as Commissioner here in this Parliament , must take into account the opinion set out in this resolution. Because the Commission has the power to negotiate, but in the end the competence to approve or reject an agreement is had by Parliament, and we want a good agreement, because we need a good negotiation of the ACS, progressive and respectful of individuals and small businesses.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D).
text: Mr President, Rapporteur Reding said earlier that the question we were asked was: "What ACS do we want?" I'll issue a little nuance. I think the real question is also: "Do we want ACS?"  We are a number of parliamentarians, but also citizens, of course, who doubt the merits of such a negotiation. What for? Because we are educated by experience and we have seen the calamitous record of past liberalisations, even though Europe, more than ever, needs rules and protection.  The questions that are asked in this resolution and that we are a number to ask is whether the ACS will be a disguised TTIP or a Bolkestein directive at the global level. Will the ACS involve even more deregulation and even more financial deregulation? If the Commission answers yes to these questions, we will obviously be against the ACS. From that point of view, Ms. Arena is right. Our resolution should not be a support for the Commission, but rather an invitation, a very strong encouragement to do otherwise and to always be concerned with the protection of employees and consumers in the European Union.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – The world is changing rapidly. Various services in the fields of telecommunications, transport and other services represent a very large proportion of today's economy. The world is digitized. The share of digital services is increasing, so it is essential that the European Parliament give the European Commission a very clear starting point, which is being negotiated around the TiSA agreement on behalf of The Europeans. Mrs Reding's report is very balanced, and I therefore support it. The report gives an opportunity for both the European economy, both large and small enterprises, and it is very attentive to workers' rights to ensure that social dumping does not occur. The agreement must also guarantee greater rights for consumers of services, as we are increasingly becoming users of services on a global scale. The protection of personal data is also one of the areas that is processed and it is absolutely important that it is well addressed. However, we must also pay attention to public services, which must remain in the public interest. I support the european Parliament being confident and that it is clear to the European Commission.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, the Trade and Services Agreement negotiated by 23 partners, namely 50 countries, today represents the most sensitive financial and comprehensive trade agreement for the Union. Service activities employ 68% of the workforce, and in 2013 alone the trade in services generated profits of €173 billion.  The market for services has changed significantly with the development of the internet. While European service providers are competitive on the global market with the knowledge and quality they provide, they are prevented from accessing many markets due to legal barriers. At the same time, access to the European market is more liberal. SMEs are particularly left behind by this disproportion. But reciprocity must not be our only goal. We should vigorously defend standards of worker protection, data and consumer rights. This is an opportunity to regulate globalization. The provisions of the Agreement should be made available to the public. I am pleased that the report calls for the exclusion of all public services from the Agreement, such as health and education, and that it leaves sufficient room for local self-government to regulate services and introduce safeguards if necessary.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, I welcome the call for strengthening the Role of the European Parliament in the procedures for negotiating and concluding international agreements, as the practice of negotiating so far is completely unacceptable. Even good agreements thus encounter resistance in public, as citizens get the impression that something is hiding from them. If they and their well-being come first, and they should be, transparency must be high on our list of priorities. The greater possibility of democratic control, tentatively speaking, complicates the negotiations, but it is absolutely worth it. On the other hand, some ideological themes, such as the struggle for gender equality, should not burden such agreements. We need to keep the focus, so focus on opening up foreign markets to European companies. We will not achieve this goal by moralising and sharing lessons to the rest of the world, but by creating a legal-policy framework that will make it easier for our entrepreneurs to access closed markets until yesterday.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I support the negotiations carried out by the Commission on behalf of the European Union, but I would like to highlight the fact that this valuable and significant instrument that we can adopt here in Parliament will hardly receive support if the public is not fully aware, in all details, of what is being negotiated and that the whole process becomes far more public than it is.  Because it is extremely important that citizens also support what we will accept here. I want to emphasize the problem of roaming, the problem of e-commerce, I want to emphasize the need to protect workers, and I especially want to emphasize the right of local and regional self-government to traditional services and all those specificities that subsidiarity carries.  It was especially important that public services, health and education were not involved in this process, because I think then they would definitely lose the support of the public. It's hard anyway, but I believe it'll be easier if we involve the public.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the ACS, together with TTE and CETA form a triad of treaties. Free trade agreements, they call them. Freedom for multinationals to impose their rules; so that they are above parliaments and courts. Freedom to privatize our public services and slavery for workers. The ACS will allow large corporations to choose the labour rights of their workers and allow them to move them freely. ACS will bring extreme precariousness levels. From the European left we are going to vote 'no'. Not the privatization of public services. Not to precariousness. Not the dictatorship of multinationals. Ladies and gentlemen, members of the People's Party and the Socialist Party, what are you going to vote for? Because voting in favour of the report is to vote 'yes' to continue negotiating, on our behalf, which services they privatize and what rights they rob us of. It is to vote 'yes' to have democracy in the hands of multinationals.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I believe, as my colleague Bové has said before, that we know what these kinds of treaties are: to put behind us what we do not achieve within the framework of the WTO. And, on top of that, reinforced. When we know that the GATS is blocked because there is great opposition to such treaties because we do not want it to be traded with public services. And we are very afraid and do not believe the reservations they explain to us from the European Commission.  We know it's going to affect public services. We're very concerned about government procurement. What about the remunicipation processes that are taking place through the European Union as a whole? How will they be affected by this Treaty? They'll be affected, and we know it. We are concerned about the labour rights of 70% of our workforce working in the services sector that may be affected.  I therefore believe, Ladies and gentlemen, that we must send a very clear message this week, and we must be able to do so. And if not, we are not going to vote in favour of this resolution because we do not want it to be negotiated with the public services. We are not going to accept that positive lists are not introduced in these types of negotiations and, finally, we do not agree with the negotiating mandate of the Commission.  We do not accept, Commissioner Malmstrom, that you come here to say that Parliament gives the go-ahead to the way you are negotiating. If so, we will not be in this Resolution.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, in my constituency, trade and services is incredibly important to business. The UK is the largest exporter of services to the world, even bigger than the USA. That is not just a fact, that is a government statistic – for those who appreciate the irony of that. So I want to make sure that British interests and North-East interests are protected. Why? Because that sector employs over 45 000 people in my constituency and over 12 000 in Newcastle alone. But, as ever, this report has its wrinkles. It is advisory only. If we adopt it in full it will not remove a single stroke of the pen from TiSA itself. It also recognises that TiSA will involve movement of natural persons between countries that are parties to the agreement. Does that mean even more massive migration to the UK, and if so, how much? It correctly identifies the threat of a ratchet clause which would put the rights of investors over a democratically-elected government. Long story short: we need to protect the UK’s status as a world leader and I am growing increasingly concerned that TiSA will not do that.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, all trade, all trade is based on regulation, otherwise it is the law of the jungle. Here, the importance of public services is emphasized, and the importance of data, protection and reciprocity are emphasized. Nevertheless, the fundamental problem is the way in which these negotiations are organized, in secret, with a mandate that is not clear, that should be imperative, and especially with this base which had been that of the International Trade Organization after the war, because it had used its experience to rethink trade, the basis that should be the United Nations. Today, it is in secret, in secret, outside the peoples, with a Parliament that gives some advice that we do not listen to, that the future of peoples is settled. This is not how we will be able to restore democracy and the trust of the people.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this possibility to discuss this very important agreement that we are negotiating. TiSA is an opportunity to create a global playing field for trade in services. That has great potential for the economy globally but especially for Europe, because the European Union is quite open to other investment – but we need as well to ensure that our companies can also invest abroad. The GATS Agreement really needs to be updated in order to take into account the new global realities and create, as some of you said, the legal certainty that is so important to get this right. Because I absolutely agree, free trade is not something good per se; free trade is a means to create jobs, goods and investment. But of course it needs to be surrounded by certain regulations and certain rules. The aim is to make this a multilateral agreement. I fully share your concerns on this, and that is why the EU has been so eager to try to make the architecture as open and as inclusive as possible, so that gradually more countries will join, so that we can bring it under the premises of the WTO. It is a fact that the GATS Agreement does not contain obligations to sign up to the ILO, but that does not mean that we are not pushing for this. The European Union is always pushing for countries, in all kind of relations – including trade, of course – to sign up to the key WTO conventions, and we are continuing to do this as well. Public services – audio-visual services – are always excluded in our agreements. That is very clear in the mandate we have from the Member States. It is very clear from what you have said today, but also earlier on this. Public services such as education, health, water supplies and audio-visual services are excluded. They do not need to be privatised, and if they are privatised there is nothing in this agreement, nor in TTIP or in any other agreement, that will prevent the local, regional or national level if there is a political decision to bring it back to the public sector if that is the political decision. Also the right to regulate in a non-discriminatory way is not affected. Authorities on all levels can legislate on, for instance, environmental and health standards as they wish, and this will not change. On transparency, as you have seen, we have really tried to make the EU contribution to this as transparent as possible.
