Most of the EU proposals, and a summary after each negotiation round, are on line. You as MEPs have access to all documents. But this is a negotiation that we lead together with 22 other countries, and there is no way we can legally publish the proposals of Peru, Australia, New Zealand, Turkey, Pakistan, etc. That has to be their decision. I deplore the fact that they have not chosen to be as transparent as we have, but we cannot publish this, and that is why sometimes proposals, even draft proposals from a given country, appear on the internet, leaked. That does not mean that they are actually part of the negotiation; it is a proposal or a draft for one country. Many of these – you referred to some of them – have been immediately rejected by us and others as well. But we will continue to try to see if we can make this even more transparent and to make sure you are as included and as engaged as possible. In the end you will, of course, like the Member States, have your say on this. We are negotiating TiSA based on the mandate given to us by 28 countries, and you also had your say on this when it started. I am very mindful of the concerns that you have expressed here – we are taking them on board and we will continue to do so – and of the concerns that that many people have outside this whole House. But I am also very mindful that we still have huge unemployment in this European Union, that millions of people are still without jobs, and TiSA and other trade agreements are a way to create jobs and investment and growth in Europe, which desperately needs it. So we need to find a balance there. I think that with your input in the resolution, the debate we will have and the continued negotiations – as I said, there is a round as we talk this week, and we will debrief you from that immediately when it is over – jointly we can make this agreement that finds the right balance that so many of you are asking for , and I will be happy to continue to engage with you. Thank you Ms Reding for the fantastic work you have done to get such a broad majority, also all the other committees for your involvement in this, and the shadow rapporteurs.

name: Viviane Reding
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, as most statements have shown, Parliament is forming a common front to demand full transparency, fairer trade rules, more reciprocal market openings, the right to regulate and safeguard and more rights for more consumers. The main political groups are taking matters into their own hands in this direction. Globalization and the digitization of our economies are facts. The question is: "Do we want Europe to be a tax-free continent and the rest of the world a lawless playground?" Parliament's response must be very clear: "No, we want to play the rules of the game today so that we do not have to go through them tomorrow. We want an agreement that protects our businesses and our citizens, and yes, we want a change in policy." Since the 2014 European elections, a new wind has been blowing on the European Union's trade policy and, with this report, Parliament is preparing to raise the big sail. If our recommendations are followed, they will be a source of growth for Europe, gains in competitiveness for our businesses, a safety net for our citizens. I therefore call on politicians and groups to maintain the strong support they have shown in parliamentary proceedings. Only a large majority in plenary will lead to consideration of the demands of the European Parliament.  As the chairman of the Committee on International Trade said, in German...  Ein klares Ja zum Text, ein klares Nein zu faulen Kompromissen.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mrs Reding. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 3 February. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing – Recommendations for an agreement on trade in services should cover an important segment in which several tens of millions of people are currently employed in Europe. The further expansion of this sector is also linked to the repeatedly stressed need to support the digital economy. We hear very often about the importance of technological and market innovation for sustainable economic growth. Europe maintains its position as a leader in this area. Under no circumstances may this status be jeopardising her position. The possible conclusion of a new trade agreement should therefore be conditional on the clear consolidation of the European Union's position as the most important global exporter of services. In addition to the European Union, more than 20 countries are involved in the TiSA negotiations. Their markets mean more than 2/3 of the current global trade in services. At the same time, the European Union already has mutual ties in this area with several of them. The agreement must thus contain concrete potential for further progress. Otherwise, it has no meaning for us. It must bring more employment, more rights and lower prices for European consumers. At the same time, it is essential to define clear boundaries in which it can no longer intervene under any circumstances. This applies in particular to public services, cultural services, the right to data protection or fair working conditions.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. – TiSA must be transparent. That is the starting point. I am seriously concerned that the negotiations have been conducted so far without the required level of transparency while it appears that all negotiation documents will be officially published only five years after negotiations have been concluded.  Overall, transparency cannot consist of the mere provision of information. We need to call on the Commission to involve Parliament in real consultation and at all stages of the negotiations. Secondly, public services must not be put under pressure for further privatisation or deregulation and thus should not be part of TiSA.  In any event TiSA must not result in an opening of service sectors to foreign suppliers at the cost of high European labour, environmental and consumer standards. Wages and conditions for any posted workers must at least comply with those applying to nationals at the same workplace. They must not be treated differently under the guise of being described as ‘service providers’.  Finally, there must be no further deregulation of the financial markets through TiSA. Reforms of financial markets whose necessity became apparent in the aftermath of the international financial crisis must not be treated as trade barriers.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Our group's position is clear: a service regulated according to national principles, on the basis of conquered labour and social rights, is not an obstacle to 'free trade', but a fundamental element of democratisation of the economy. On the basis of the denial of this premiss, the Commission insists on liberalizing the overall provision of services through the ACS with effects similar to those brought by the single market: macroeconomic instability, explosion of social dumping and submission of the State to the private business model. It is regrettable that Parliament is presenting a Resolution whose red lines do not even contain ratification of ILO minimums or clear criteria on the very notion of 'public service' which will give content to its request for exclusion — all the more so when general liberalization clauses are accepted, including in areas as sensitive as finance or the digital market. Therefore, once again, our group's position will be radically opposed.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. – It is no coincidence that the EU's largest up-and-coming partners, namely the BRICS, categorically refuse to participate in any international agreement on trade in services. An agreement which only aims to maintain in every way the hegemonic position held by the major European service companies in the international division of labour.  The lifting of tariff and non-tariff duties primarily serves the interests of multinationals, whereas on the contrary it affects those of small and medium-sized enterprises as well as public enterprises, especially smaller states. EU citizens have expressed their vertical opposition to the international TiSA and TTIP agreements and are demanding that Member States' public and small businesses be defended in order not to become ballasts of international competition.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I would like to welcome the compromise reached by the rapporteur, Mrs Viviane Reding, in particular the refusal of 'status quo' and 'ratcheting effect' clauses and even the safeguards proposed for data protection by foreign companies. However, in the vote, I will abstain. Some "red lines" are indeed lacking. Public services and services to the public of general interest are excluded from the scope of negotiations, but there remains a vagueness as to their definition at European level, undermining the restriction. Let us be careful about these types of negotiations and their impact.  To date, there is no guarantee that TISA will impose compliance with the collective agreements of the International Labour Organization (ILO). Moreover, I am against the principle of "negative list" induced by TISA: only the sectors explicitly mentioned in the agreements will not be liberalisable. Parliament has given its "green light"; I saw an "orange fire" in it. I will remain vigilant that the essential safeguards that condition the agreement are respected.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: Writing. The Commission must take Parliament's position into account in its negotiations. In the end, I will only agree to TiSA if the agreement does not allow national standards to be lowered. National rules on workers' and social rights and collective agreements must not be circumvented under any circumstances. Nor must the agreement prevent Member States from setting stricter rules on social and environmental issues. And most importantly, public services of general public interest must be excluded. These include: education, health, water supply and waste management. I will only agree to an agreement if these conditions are met.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Services play an increasingly important role in the global economy. Today, the UNION is the world's largest exporter of services, so that millions of Europeans find employment in this sector. TiSA expects EU companies to export services more easily, which in turn will translate into growth and more employment. On the other hand, enabling non-EU companies to provide services in Europe will increase consumer choice and lower prices.  Parliament's adoption of the TiSA report is groundbreaking. Indeed, almost all political groups supported the recommendations. This shows that there is consensus in Parliament on the benefits that this agreement can bring to businesses and consumers. It is also a clear signal to the Commission of what may and should not be included in the final text. I am pleased that Parliament's recommendations include recommendations on reciprocity as regards access to markets, the protection of Europe's sensitive sectors, ensuring the protection of data flow, as well as guidelines on facilitation for SMEs. It is important that TiSA benefits all the parties negotiating it, but at the same time does not pose a threat to European values and sensitive sectors. However, in the work on this agreement, I emphasised my separate position on the demands for a full exclusion of public services from TiSA, because I do not see sufficient reasons for this.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on EU-China trade relations and market economy status by Bernd Lange on behalf of the Committee on International Trade (O—000005/2016 - B8-0102/2016) (2016/2514(RSP)).

name: Bernd Lange
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which There is no doubt that China is an important trading partner, and this trade is responsible for many of the European Union's jobs. That is why the issue we are discussing now is a very sensitive one.  As you know, China had joined the WTO in 2001 – and this was a step forward – with an accession protocol. And China has largely complied with WTO rules. In this Protocol of Accession there was Article 15, which provided for a 15-year transitional period with regard to the use of pricing in anti-dumping and anti-subsidisation cases. This transitional period will expire on 11 December this year. In this respect, we must now, in fact, give us quick thought. There is no question that our anti-dumping and anti-subsidisation procedures are usually linked to China. About 80% of all procedures have to do with China, because pricing is distorted internally and we use pricing from third countries in our anti-dumping and anti-subsidisation procedures. In this respect, we must now think very carefully about what it means when the transitional period expires on 11 December and that China – as it is called in technical Chinese – should be granted market economy status. On the other hand, we cannot, of course, hand over our levers for sensible protective instruments. I am a little concerned about whether everything will still work out in time, because a legislative proposal obviously takes quite a while and the Council and Parliament, as legislators, have to agree on this. In this respect, I wonder where these fifteen years have actually remained. You could have gone to work a little earlier. There are three options: let it run, i.e. give China market economy status almost automatically, thereby giving up the anti-dumping and anti-subsidisation possibilities. Australia has done that, with a clear negative effect. You can look at that, they have hardly any opportunities to defend themselves – so I think that's out of the way. The second option of saying a clear 'no' would automatically lead to a complaint to the WTO. Perhaps there is a third option, because if you look closely at the protocol, there is also scope for alternative methods: with regard to the question of the pricing of third countries, which is being used, but also with regard to the obligation to provide proof. I believe that this should also be analysed very carefully as to whether we are making progress here, so that we also have a sensible trade protection mechanism procedure after 11 December. And that also means, of course, holding talks with the Chinese partner in order to find a sensible solution here. Talks must be held anyway, because it is unacceptable that overproduction should be created through state subsidies, which are then sold on the European market, as is currently the case in the steel sector. Talks need to be held here, that cannot be the case. On 18 February, there will also be a large demonstration of the steel sector in Brussels. We are at our core: anti-dumping and anti-subsidy have something to do with jobs, and we need a clear impact analysis of the effects of these three options and how to ensure that jobs are not at risk and that industrial development in Europe – we want to ensure 20% of gross domestic product – is strengthened, not weakened.  I cannot quite understand the Council – which is not really there today – because, on the one hand, it has been failing to reform trade defence instruments since April 2014 and, on the other hand, it is shedding crocodile tears on the question of whether or not to give China market economy status. So, we need to set clear lines, and that is why we are asking you, Commissioner: what do you want to put on the table, when do you want to put something on the table, and what will the content be?

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Lange for giving me the possibility to discuss this issue in depth with the honourable Members. I am happy to update Parliament on where we are on this file. Let me start by stressing that the question is not whether China is a market economy or not. It is not – at least not in the way we understand the term. The question is whether the EU should change the method it must follow to calculate dumping in EU anti-dumping investigations. The debate is, as Chairman Lange said, about the expiry of the 15—year transitional period following China’s accession to the WTO and about the application of certain anti-dumping methodologies and the implications for our jobs and our industry. Anti—dumping actually only affects 1.38% of all our imports from China, but it can provide essential relief to individual companies or sectors suffering from unfair trading practices, dumping or subsidies. We are, in fact, analysing the three options that that Mr Lange referred to. First, not to change EU legislation. China obviously expects the EU to apply the WTO protocol and change its methodology, as of 11 December this year. Not doing so might have an impact on our trade and investment relations, in addition to potential legal challenges. This situation could have a cost for EU business, including in employment terms. These effects are, of course, very difficult, if not impossible, to estimate in advance. We can only speculate. There is a risk that this option would put the EU in breach of WTO obligations, with possible economic effects. There are, indeed, different interpretations of Section 15 of China’s accession protocol, but there are solid interpretations saying that at least some of the provisions will expire. The second alternative would be to remove China from the list of non—market-economy countries in our legislation without further conditions. This would be economically damaging to many EU industries and politically unrealistic. A preliminary estimation of the effects of this option has been circulated to you in an information note. Third, to remove China from the list of market economy countries while, at the same time, introducing mitigating measures by strengthening the EU Trade Defence Instrument to reflect the full extent of the numerous distortions that still exist in the Chinese economy, thereby maintaining an effective anti-dumping instrument. We are of course aware that all these options have economic and social impacts and need to be properly assessed. No matter what path we choose, the Commission remains committed to maintaining a strong anti-dumping instrument to protect our industry from unfair trade while respecting international obligations. The legal advice we have received indicates that the current method of dumping calculations need to be changed on the date of expiry of the transitional period. Even under an alternative interpretation, there is a broad understanding that this so—called analogue country approach, as provided for in our current legislation, cannot be used as such anymore. So these are the basic options. They are all very technically complex and have effects. We are indeed carrying out a deep impact assessment. The paper you received is just a preliminary first assessment. The commitment is, of course, to keep you fully informed. We submitted this paper to you with preliminary findings, and this is part of the transparency we need to have with you. Another issue is cooperation with other stakeholders. The Commission is in regular contact with our main stakeholders, particularly EU industry, and they have all shared opinions with the Commission. Regarding the preliminary findings on the impact on EU industry and employment, we have based the study on robust methodology and existing data from the ongoing 52 cases that we have with China for the moment. This study estimates the following potential negative employment effects of changing from the current non-market economy methodology to the normal anti-dumping. They are estimates, and with each scenario it follows that we have made no mitigating measures. So this is the worst-case scenario. In the sectors covered by anti-dumping measures now, we estimate that between 34 000 and 77 000 jobs could be lost. In the longer run, if we look at other sectors that could also be affected, the study points at between 73 000 and 188 000 jobs. If you take into account the possible effects on downstream and upstream industries, we are talking about between 63 000 and 210 000 jobs. This is a lot, and it is important, but it is much lower than suggested by some other studies by, for instance, the Washington-based Economic Policy Institute. And, again, these estimations are made without any mitigating factors, so you should bear that in mind. We need to take these risks seriously into account, and this reminds us of the importance of the issue. Regarding one of the other questions on coordination with other countries, we are indeed in contact with other partners on this. Yet we must bear in mind that all WTO members have to abide by their legal commitments and consider appropriate actions. Some of our main trading partners do not have to amend their laws. We have to amend our laws, and that takes some time. Some countries can make a decision in five minutes, so that makes us a little different from other partners such as the USA, for instance. So we are in a unique situation in that we are the only country that explicitly lists China as a non-market economy for anti-dumping. So should we choose to change our anti-dumping methodology – and we are not there yet, we are assessing all the alternatives, as I said – this would then require a change of legislation. In that legislation, you would of course be full co—legislators. It would be a proposal from the Commission to the Council and to Parliament, so you would have a full say in that process. But we are not there yet, and this is a way to update you on where we are. I am happy to continue this debate to see if there are any remaining questions. Thank you again for putting this on the agenda.

name: Iuliu Winkler
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, considering the matter of the commercial relationship between the EU and China, we should not stop at stating that China has not met the five EU criteria for a market economy. There are at least three important aspects to consider: the legal aspect and the much-debated automaticity. Since there is a need to amend the EU legislation, granting the MES to China is not automatic. There are economic consequences, since there are hundreds of thousands of European jobs exposed. We expect the Commission to conduct and present a deep and comprehensive impact assessment. The geopolitical context, in both ways, and the EU—China strategic partnership are in need of more cooperation and less antagonism. In conclusion, a legally-sound WTO-compatible solution has to be proposed by the Commission. We see a clear need to keep functioning EU trade defence systems in place. The solution delivered by the Commission has to allow anti-dumping cases against China in the future as well. The entire evaluation and decision-making process should be transparent and should involve the European business community. We need a level playing field in trade between EU and China so that market forces define the competition and not intervention by the state.

name: David Martin
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, we have known for 15 years that a decision on market economy status for China had to be made this year, yet the Commission appears to have made no decision and to have no clear strategy. Now that we have woken the Commission from its stupor, I hope that today will mark the start of a serious discussion with Parliament, with the Member States and with European industry and trade unions – as well as with the Chinese Government – on where we go from here. We want good relations with China, and we understand that China feels that in December, market economic status should automatically be granted to it. But China should also understand that in 2001 we had a real expectation that by 2016 China itself would be a market economy. It is clear that it is not, and the Commissioner herself has made it clear that China is not a market economy. Therefore, there can be no automatic granting of market economic status to China. We cannot allow China to solve its overcapacity by dumping on the European market. Steel might be capturing the headlines at the moment, but, as the Commission again points out, we have 52 ongoing investigations on dumping, so the impact is much wider than just the steel industry. It is not – and we need to keep saying this as the European Union – protectionist to defend yourself against unfair competition. The EU desperately needs a modern, effective regime of trade defence instruments. The existence of such a scheme is a sine qua non for my group supporting market economic status for China.

name: Emma McClarkin
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President,  market economy status for China is probably one of the toughest issues that the European Union will deal with this year, and there are a number of aspects that we must bear in mind during this debate. Firstly, following the opinion of Parliament’s Legal Service, the Commission has to be conscious of its commitments under WTO law on changing its anti-dumping regulations to take account of the expiry of Article 15a under China’s accession protocol. On the other hand, I am more than aware of the importance of this issue, given that my own Member State’s steel industry is currently on its knees and may never recover. This is largely due to Chinese steel being sold on the world market. It is therefore vital, whatever action is taken about the protocol, that EU anti-dumping law retains the ability to take swift and effective action to tackle anti-competitive market practices. Therefore I call on the Commission to include, as part of its strategy over the coming months, a detailed impact assessment on the changing of the methodology for anti-dumping duties, but also to look at the full remit of the trade defence instruments we have at our disposal.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, dumping products on the EU market under the market price is not allowed and should be met with appropriate measures. The question is how the EU can best address the inevitable expiry of the protocol on China’s accession to the WTO that was signed 15 years ago. The question before us is not whether we believe China has a market economy where prices are set by supply and demand: it does not. The question before us is how we should address illegal trade practices by a country that is also an important trading partner. My group believes we must address this complex and technical matter with a cool head. Some people have already taken very emotional positions; others wish to use this moment to enforce their wish-list of protectionist measures. But they seem to forget that there are both importers and exporters in Europe, and that the economic angle is not the only one to consider. I believe we need a thorough impact assessment and a legal analysis, and that we must strengthen the rules-based system of trade. Particularly in relation to China, it is key that we too, on the EU side, practise what we preach and that our solutions should be WTO- proof. It does mean that we need effective trade defence instruments to address subsidies, dumping and other illegal practices by China or any other country for that matter. I believe that we must address this issue proactively, and I do not believe in the proposals by those who think we should best leave it up to WTO arbitration to decide.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Our discussion should not be bogged down in the question of whether China is a purely market economy. Globalisation requires political regulation of market forces. It is important for us that the annual increase in the minimum wage of 12% should be decided politically in China, to the displeasure of European financial investors. It is already higher in China than in Bulgaria, Romania, the Czech Republic and Lithuania. This reduces wage pressure and strengthens purchasing power for imports from Europe. What is at stake is how we can respond to dumping. We want to preserve jobs in Europe, but also in China. For this we do not need a dispute over calculation formulas, but a political agreement with China. That is why we put our question to you, Commissioner. I would also like to make a concrete proposal to you: let us take an active approach to WTO borders ourselves and propose a bilateral anti-dumping agreement to China. We can agree on rules on pricing, but also rules to prevent social and environmental dumping.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. China is not a market economy, but – says the Chinese Government – you must recognise us as a market economy, because firstly, the economic reality is legally irrelevant, and secondly, you promised it. Well, we promised it. But, one might ask, has China actually kept to what it promised 15 years ago? I do not want to go to the reckoning now. I am prepared to recognise a non-market economy as a market economy, as long as this does not result in serious damage to our market economy being caused by the dumping of the non-market economy. Is such damage imminent? It is indeed threatening! One institute, as has already been mentioned, has seen up to 3.5 million jobs at risk. It is more likely to be only 200 000, the Commission now says. I think that too should be far too much for us. We do not know for sure, which is why it is important to have a full impact assessment as a first step. However, I would like to warn against one thing: Commissioner, you have once again ridden over the 1.38% of EU-China trade, which is currently dumping-relevant. If we take note of the fact that overcapacity in China is growing significantly and is pushing into the export market, then we cannot be satisfied with this figure, but must take precautions. We in the European Parliament do not want to be blue-eyed at the expense of European jobs. This Parliament should not unconditionally comply with Chinese demands; rather, we should make an offer. Market economy status can exist if, at the same time, effective defence instruments against dumping are at hand. That is how it can go, otherwise there is no yes here in this House.

name: David Borrelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 11 December this year, the European Union will have to express a clear, reasoned and sustainable position on granting China market economy status.  Apart from legal issues and even more important employment consequences, what is now at risk is precisely the possibility of such a position on the part of the European Union. I and other Members are taking action to make the way in which this challenge is tackled more transparent and effective, but we need more, we need to demand more for the good of our businesses. We cannot trust a document which differs so clearly from the estimates made by companies themselves of jobs at risk. We need a firm initiative towards the Commission so that Europe does not reach the decisive moment without the support of adequate reflection.  Ladies and gentlemen, we must ensure that the Commission negotiates seriously and asserts all the economic and political weight of Europe in order to send a clear message to China. The threat of appeals in the WTO should not frighten us. A confrontation with Europe is not even good for the Chinese.

name: Barbara Kappel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. Highly subsidised Cheap Chinese steel, which floods the European market directly or through imports from third countries, is partly responsible for the current steel crisis in Europe, which is leading to production relocations and, ultimately, the loss of thousands of jobs. Since 2014, the Commission has opened 16 anti-dumping and anti-subsidy proceedings, six of which concern the Chinese steel industry. In August last year, imports of cold-rolled flat steel products from China and Taiwan were subject to punitive tariffs of up to 25%, and of all the anti-dumping proceedings initiated in recent years, 44%, or almost half, concern China. Despite this background, China is now demanding automatic WTO status by 11 December this year. This automatic award would mean that it would be much more difficult for European companies to insist on a level playing field. The economic consequences would be massive, not only for the key industries in Europe, which are already struggling with high labour costs and energy costs. 3.5 million jobs, or two percent of gross domestic product, are available, as has already been mentioned today. That is why we need a comprehensive impact assessment and concerted action by all economies. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – I would like to reflect on what will happen if China calls for us to be recognised as a non-market economy. Because if we impose artificial prices on energy ourselves, then all energy prices are artificial, so all prices are practically artificial and we are not a market economy. Here in this House, I hear that the Nord Stream pipeline should not be allowed to be created. Very well, it is only her political decision, so it is not the market that decides, and politics is to decide. I would like to ask here those hypocrites of socialists who care not about the welfare of poor people who want to buy cheap goods, but to take care of the great capitalists, to take care of their profits. You Socialists! I ask you the question: what will happen if China says that this year for Christmas every child offers a gift worth one hundred euros for free. Will you allow this, or will you defend European children against cheap goods from China?

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the One thing is important for our group: we want our workers and our industries to be protected from dumped Chinese products after December of this year. We are open to a solution. We call on the Commission to present us with an in-depth assessment of what we can expect for all the possible options that the Commissioner has mentioned today. Because we want to have an effective instrument in the end. We have a social market economy, we have a set of rules, and all the problems that we have – wto accession protocol or not – we have precisely because China is still largely not a market economy because it is inefficient. On the one hand, we can be almost grateful, because otherwise they would already cause us greater difficulties in many other sectors of the economy today. But this inefficiency – as many previous speakers have said – means that some European industries are constantly getting under the wheels. We must be able to defend ourselves against this. Secondly, I would like us to remember what was already being discussed here in Parliament in 2000, when China was on the verge of joining the WTO. At that time there was also a question from the ITRE Committee for an oral answer to the Commission, and at that time our colleague Mann said that we should insist very much that the rules of the WTO are actually respected. I call on our friends in China to implement this part of the accession commitments!

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to stress my and my group's satisfaction with this debate, given that we have been trying to have this debate for several months. Our view is clear: there are no conditions for automatic unilateral granting of market economy status. The pressures of the past few months, both ourselves and those involved, have led the College of Commissioners to postpone the decision until the second half of 2016, which is good news if the next few weeks are used to carry out the impact assessment in full compliance with the guidelines indicated by the Commission and to find alternative solutions, not just to minimise the data we have today. However, we are perplexed that such a crucial decision has been reduced in recent months, when there has been 15 years to build a more effective strategy. To date, we remain convinced that the granting of market economy status is very dangerous in the absence of a way of calculating normal production value in order to counter the market consequences that would begin with the collapse of the current anti-dumping defence system and if the decision were taken unilaterally. We are not asking the Commission for ideological closure, but for trade and competition to be based on fairness.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I represent the West Midlands, which is the only UK region with a trade surplus with China, worth GBP 3 billion last year. Free trade is vital for us and is vital for Europe as a whole. Now, do trade subsidies exist in China? Yes. Does the Government play too big a role in the economy? Yes. But how do we change this? By tying China into the global trading system and by treating them like everyone else. If we go all protectionist and reject this status, they will not reform and they will retaliate. This will hurt our export industries and cost us jobs. China opted to join the WTO; they opted to play by our rules. This was a huge success for the West, and we need to build on it, but we also need to meet our own obligations. Market economy status does not stop us imposing anti-dumping measures; we just have to use the WTO parameters. We should approve it, and then we should move forward with the investment agreement. After that, in the long run, we should look at a Free Trade Agreement with China. This is how we deal with China: bind her into the global trading system. But in order to do that, we also need to trust in free trade and in the WTO ourselves.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE).
text: Mr President, this is not only a sensitive issue, it is a very important issue for our economy, for our industry, for our research, for our patents. This decision, it will not have to be taken in camera, it will take debates, public, open, because the stakes are considerable. There can be no automaticity. The question, then, is whether China meets the criteria for a market economy. Obviously, that is not the case. We all know that here. Until China conducts the necessary reforms, until the competition is definitively fair, as long as we are not at an equal level, it will be illegitimate for me to grant it that status.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, China aspires to market economy status, but it is worth pointing out that it is already the largest exporter of goods to the EU – and by the way, Ms McClarkin, you would learn something if you waited around. China’s exports of goods to the EU are substantially more than what the UK does every year, and that is without being a Member State. China has been dumping steel on the UK market. In consequence, thousands of steel jobs have vanished in some of the UK’s most economically—challenged areas. The entire industry is at risk. If only the UK itself had the ability to impose anti-dumping tariffs on China – but it does not as we have given that power away – then things would be different. They would even be different in the West Midlands. According to the European Policy Institute, market economy status for China would put 3.5 million jobs at risk. It is clear that China cannot, and must not, be treated as a market economy. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Lord Dartmouth, do you really believe – having heard the contributions of our Conservative members tonight, and the Prime Minister’s greeting of the Premier of China – that if Britain was not in the European Union, we would be imposing anti-dumping duties on China at the present time?

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – If Mr Martin, for whom I have the highest possible regard, is trying to say – or indeed is saying – that the Prime Minister is entirely pusillanimous, entirely feeble, does not stand up for British interests with the EU and would not stand up for British interests with China, then I have to say I entirely agree with him.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, do you know the Havana charter? I don't know. Neverthrd to say that this charter was signed in 1948, after the war, at the initiative of the United Nations, to think about trade for peace and to establish rules of trade for peace and the pursuit of that peace.  The principles are quite clear: the balance of payments balance (the surpluses of some make the deficits of others; one cannot lock someone in his deficit), fair labour standards, the authorisation of state aid - when it is sovereignty and independence - the authorization, therefore, also, subsidies in certain circumstances and the prohibition of dumping.  It is very clear that today China is not a market economy. It protects itself, it pursues a proactive policy for its own development and may not necessarily be concerned with the interests of others. We must build fair trade with it, and fair trade must return to the fundamentals of the Havana Charter. China is the European Union's largest imbalance in the balance of goods. We must find the foundations for a new sustainable trade balance with China and this must be done within the framework of the United Nations and not the WTO.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems to me that we all agree that China, despite having made good progress in implementing its WTO commitments, is still deficient and that there are major outstanding problems, such as the lack of transparency, the existence of measures that discriminate against foreign companies, the government's strong intervention in the economy, the protection and inadequate application of intellectual property rights. , and so on. We ask ourselves a crucial question: can we now grant China market economy status, fifteen years after the date of wto membership? What would happen? China, at the moment, if it had this kind of recognition, would be in a position to cause a very high percentage of job losses. Our industrial system would have a total guarantee protection reduction of 30% or 50%, which would be devastating in any case.  We therefore want and demand that there should be precise guarantees, in a deepening of openness and confrontation with China, which is certainly a major trading partner. But surely the European Commission's priority and strategy is to safeguard jobs and indeed, through trade agreements, to achieve the objective of increasingly supporting more and more jobs. Then we cannot afford automatisms, we cannot afford partial checks on the impact that this type of recognition would have. Today we have to face the harsh reality, looking at what could happen. Of course, a legal regulatory assessment must be carried out, but at the moment we are asking for a responsible position...  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the subject we are debating today is a very sensitive one. It is important to understand the heart of the problem and the consequences of either one or another position. Full cooperation between the Commission and Parliament is essential and imperative. EU-China relations, politically and economically, are extremely important for both sides, but of course so too is the competitiveness of the European economy and industries. I mentioned the cooperation between the Commission and Parliament because it is only the Commission, with their expertise and the results of the impact assessment, which can put Parliament in the best position to judge the most suitable approach in this situation. We certainly need to avoid an economic and commercial confrontation or war with China. But at the same time, it is absolutely necessary that all measures are reflected upon and put into practice to avoid any dramatic consequences on EU industries and jobs. This means new trade defence instruments.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: – Granting market economy status to China has, as has already been said, major consequences. After all, there are countless jobs at stake. There should be no automatic award and the Commission would do well to study the approach of the United States, Canada and Australia in this regard and to use elements of it for its own approach. The gradual granting of market economy status to certain sectors of industry that meet the conditions could be an option.  In addition, China could make concessions in a package deal. I am thinking of setting self-restrictions for exports and a better playing field for European companies in exchange for market economy status. The EU must also abide by China's WTO accession commitment. Commissioner, do not disappoint our companies and employees! I wish you every success on this complex issue.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, as you know, the question of the possible granting of market economy status to China is being addressed in all cases in many Member States, including the Czech Republic. As you yourself have said, this is not just a legal issue, it is an issue that will have economic consequences, and I am therefore glad that you are paying due attention to this. The information on some of the impacts that you have published in the last week, which you will be presenting to trade ministers, is an important input into this debate. But I'm sure you know that other associations are working with different numbers, so I think it would be a good idea to shed more light on this debate and present perhaps a deeper impact study. In general, in this respect, I see it as absolutely crucial to develop and present a plan for what the European Union can do if China eventually receives market economy status, and what effective instruments we could use to protect problematic sectors that face unfair competition.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, China should not be awarded market economy status at this time. In China, resources are not allocated by the market; prices are not freely determined by the market; major industry sectors are subject to centrally-imposed five-year plans. Market economy status would make it more difficult to act against the steel dumping which has done so much damage in Britain and across Europe. But I see parallels here with the EU’s intrusive and distorting energy policy. Here in the EU, resources are not allocated by the market. Prices are distorted by subsidies and by the EU’s emissions trading scheme. The whole industry is dominated by central planning from Brussels. So perhaps we should not be debating China. Perhaps we should be debating whether the EU itself deserves market economy status.

name: Franck Proust (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, our problem is our anti-dumping calculation methods and not the status of a market economy. Does it really have to be that such an important subject depends on the interpretation of a sentence in an appendix to a protocol of another institution. Is that serious? No! Politics must arbitrate this legal uncertainty. China is a partner, and moreover a friend: you have to be able to tell him everything. However, when it is told that it does not meet our five criteria for granting market economy status, it does not recognize it. When we defend herself against the dumping that she practices en masse, she responds with investigations. When we tell him that we do not have the same interpretation of section 15, we should expect a trade war. Unfortunately, we have experienced the precedent of photovoltaic panels. By banning the importation of French wines and no longer granting any import licenses for German vehicles, China has divided the world's largest trading power. Solidarity is and must remain our strength. Let us already prepare a solidarity pact to avoid division; secondly, a solidarity fund for our companies that would be victims of retaliatory measures and, finally, a dialogue of solidarity with the United States and Japan to establish a true common method. Any simplistic reasoning should be banned. The question is not whether to say no, but how to say no without hindering our investments. Except I'd rather not have to talk about such an important business strategy in front of our Chinese friends watching.  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Jo Leinen (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner Malmström, I would like to thank commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Between doing nothing and automating, there must be a third way of organising fair trade relations between the EU and China. I ask you: what is the third way? The European economy is asking the same question because some sectors – I can also mention steel – are in great distress from unfair trade practices. Their figure of 1.38% of imports that are dumping sounds somewhat harmless. Given china's overcapacity, this can become much more very quickly. We therefore need an instrument to defend ourselves against unfair trade. You say that the calculation method needs to be changed. Yes, prices in China probably cannot be because prices are quite non-transparent. They must therefore provide us with an instrument that is equivalent to what we have today and which can work on the basis of WTO rules. I believe that citizens want the EU to protect them and for the EU to benefit them.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the multitude of trade defence actions across the world demonstrates that today’s China is not a fully-fledged member of the market economy global community. Therefore China should not be treated like one until it completes the necessary reforms in line with the five criteria set by the EU. It is essential to maintain an effective anti-dumping tool to be able to react to the known challenges like those faced currently by steel and other industries. Thanks to gigantic state support, Chinese companies can choose to dominate also in many other areas, and the EU must be able to react adequately and effectively. Granting market economy status to China would drastically reduce our ability to address these trade distortions. It could have a devastating effect on the European economy and consequently it would be impossible to support during the vote on the legislative proposal from the Commission. I therefore believe that the Commission should commission a formal impact assessment but also coordinate with all our strategic partners and stakeholders to explore ways to solve this issue that would ensure a fair and level playing field for European industries and sectors. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. "If I bought a Chinese car for twenty thousand, instead of a European car for forty thousand, I am left with twenty thousand, which I will spend on the highest European goods, right? And although the steel industry will lose, other industries will gain. Please note that if we sell something to China, that is, we buy something from China, then the Chinese get euros. What will they do with these euros? They have to buy something from us, that is, we sell something to China, and the Chinese sell to us. The cheaper we buy from them, the better, not worse.

name: President. –
text: Mr Korwin-Mikke, you had already spoken in the debate. I gave you the floor for a blue card anyway and you did not ask a question, you made a second speech. I do not accept that, but Mr Wałęsa will have the opportunity to react to whatever you said.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, that is exactly what I was about to say: it was not a question to me personally. We all know that my colleague here is a great supporter of actually destroying the European Union. He does not join in any constructive dialogue and I hardly see a reason to answer him.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Mr President, as my colleagues have said, we are against automaticity in granting market economy status to China, simply because China is not a market economy. I think it has to be said, although some say that the issue is not there. No, China is not a market economy. Second, we want effective anti-dumping tools in the face of unfair competition. What we also want to highlight is that the solution that needs to be provided should not be a sectoral solution. Of course, there is a lot of talk about the steel industry, but it is not the only sector that is affected today by China's aggressive approach. Nor do we want an approach that is linked to the specific or specific interests of certain Member States. We want powerful tools, not protectionism, as some have said, but simply to protect against the aggressive unfair practices that are now those of China.

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE).
text: I would like to thank the Commissioner first of all for the very careful procedure and the information we have received this evening. As a member of the delegation for relations with China, as a member of the Committee on International Trade, but also as a Dutchman, I attach great importance to this dossier. I believe that we all agree that it would be wise for the development of the world economy to develop into a real market economy. We have the WTO agreements and we have the 5 additional criteria of the EU. But if China does not cooperate, then we cannot demand that our constituents and our people accept both the dumping of solar panels and the dumping of steel at this time. I wish the Commissioner every success with the careful evaluations and I hope that it will be all right. But I have my doubts.

name: Joachim Schuster (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Free trade is only beneficial for the participating states if a level playing field is guaranteed. And that is precisely what China is not guaranteeing at the moment. We see this, for example, in the dumping practice of steel imports. Many business locations in Europe, and thus many thousands of jobs, are at risk here, and massive industrial policy upheavals are looming. If China is granted market economy status, the EU will find it much more difficult to combat such a practice. It is obvious that China is not a market economy, and there is little evidence that China is willing to substantially change the practice of government support and governance of its economy, but it all suggests that this will continue in the future. It is not a question of protectionism, yes or no, it is a question of fair trading conditions. China is called upon to do this, but it is also up to the EU to set out how it intends to respond to dumping. Commissioner, I am a little disappointed that you have said virtually nothing concrete about what the Commission really intends to do today.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to start by saying that I have never seen such an endorsement by the left, the Greens and the Social Democrats around the market economy as ideals, but when the overarching aim is to protect high tariffs, all arguments are clearly permissible. But now this is not about whether China is a market economy. It is about something far greater; it is a question of whether we should respect China's accession treaty to the WTO – whether the world's largest economy should respect or abandon rules-driven world trade and whether we are to risk a trade conflict between the world's largest and the world's third largest economy, and what that would mean for job losses.  But the most remarkable thing here is that the Commission did not touch on this issue at all in its review of the EU anti-dumping framework, for which I am responsible.  And when we first react at the first of five to twelve, we must hurry to present a proposal that respects the WTO acquis, which does not create a trade conflict with China and which is politically feasible. I can only say, good luck!

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D).
text: Mr President, as our colleague David Martin said, there is still a serious problem of anticipation. We have known for 15 years that the problem is going to arise, and now we are thinking about solutions urgently and having to deal with the most pressing. In itself, that is already a problem. Second thing, everyone pretty much agrees on that, China is not a market economy. Besides, the Chinese, when we talk with them, do not even pretend to believe it ... The real question at the heart of this debate is to us: what do we want for Europe? What Europe do we want to defend? Do we want a europe of strategy, a Europe that protects itself, an imaginative Europe, or do we want to be naïve? I have heard some colleagues say, ''But it is good to give them status, the Chinese will encourage them to reform.'' That is not our opinion, we do not think that. We believe that Europe is not meant to be the idiot of the global village. To do this, it must be able to defend itself, be able to modernize its trade defence instruments, and be able to carry out an impact assessment. In the meantime, which is certain, and I believe, Commissioner, that you have understood the message, for us there is no question of giving China market economy status today.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we have known that this decision on market economy status was coming for 15 years, since China joined the WTO, but our national governments have wilfully ignored the implications for our trade defence instruments. Now I have heard no one here suggesting that China is a market economy. So what is this really about? Well, my constituents across Teesside – steel workers who have lost their jobs in recent months – know only too keenly the damage that dumping is doing. Our trade defence instruments are insufficient to deal with Chinese overcapacity, never mind the slowdown which is coming. We have been waiting for years for national governments to agree the modernisation necessary for these vital tools. Britain is leading a blocking minority in the Council, and as UK ministers cry their crocodile tears for our steel industry at home, abroad they give valuable contracts to Chinese investors and block the tools needed to allow a fair global market. Strengthening our trade defence instruments must be the priority now. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – As a fellow Member for North-East England, would you join me in praising the fact that, in the North-East, a higher percentage of our exporters export to China than in any other region in the country? However – although you do not necessarily accept my view that the EU is part of the problem, not the solution – would you also share my concern that, across the rest of the UK, metalliferous ores and scrap metal are in the top five British exports to China, especially given the recent decimation of the North-East’s steel industry?

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I think that the EU is part of the solution in respect to the situation in the steel industry. The proposals around the circular economy package, looking at recycling targets for metals, are actually part of the potential revival for regions like Teesside and other steel and metal regions. So, on the contrary, I think that there is a lot that the EU can do, but ultimately we need fair trade, and that means proper trade defence.

name: Karoline Graswander-Hainz (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. Basically, I think we are all convinced that it is too early for China to be given market economy status. It has so far met only one criterion for market economy status out of five criteria. Worrying is the direct impact on European industry in the sectors currently protected by anti-dumping measures. A thorough investigation and impact assessment is needed to determine the impact of the economic impact. Jobs are particularly at risk in the steel industry, paper production, ceramics, glass and aluminium production. There must be no flooding of cheap products. We want fair competition with fair rules between European and Chinese companies. If China were to be given market economy status, we need modern trade defence instruments over subsidised Chinese goods. Here the Council is called upon to put an end to its blockade.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we are facing an unquestionable reality. We know that in December 2016 China will not be a market economy and, frankly, I don't think it will stop subsidizing its production or prices, or dumping, nor do I think the state will stop intervening in the economy.  It is true that we are facing a major political decision. We are all under pressure from the representatives of the Chinese institutions, but the pressure is not right. And the truth is that trade policy cannot become an enemy of our industry.  There are innovative sectors that are seriously threatened because China does not comply with the rules, because it practices dumping. We are seriously threatening many millions of families and jobs – taking into account not only the direct ones, but also the indirect ones. There are innovative sectors such as steel, such as ceramics, which employ more than 17,000 people in my region, who are seriously threatened.  That is why two things are essential: the impact study we have all asked for and, please, a coordinated policy with our partners so that the European Union does not unilaterally take a decision.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I think the Commissioner could have heard here in this debate that she has great support for the European Commission to use the following seasons to prepare measures to protect the European market from China's dumping. What surprises me very much is the situation that has been stated here. The Commissioner has made it clear that there is no market economy in China, and yet, as it appears here, china cannot be prevented from being recognised within a year as having a market economy, and only because a 15-year period has passed. So I ask what this 15-year period was set for when it did not actually have to be used for anything. Commissioner, I think it is necessary to protect the European market, I think we all see the danger of social impacts, but I think that other legal instruments must also be used to prevent this absurd situation from taking place, you have our full support.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President. Commissioner, China is not today a market economy according to European criteria. And its labour, energy and financial circumstances, the public support enjoyed by some sectors or their social and environmental production conditions are not compatible with those required by the Union to its entrepreneurs. These differences lead to dumping which, for example, today and now threatens, in the Basque Country and other European regions, our steelmaking. Its workers and the more efficient and sustainable auxiliary industry are threatened with their future. Our institutions are mobilized and hope that Europe will not dispense with the tools it has to protect our industry. By denying this declaration, we force China to deepen the reforms it needs and defend a people-centered economic and social model, which is a global reference in terms of wealth redistribution, social cohesion and sustainability. Strenuous days and misery wages are as toxic as the smoke it denounces every day that some ways of producing and competing are not sustainable. That is why, Commissioner, we are waiting for an urgent response.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this debate is the first real opportunity for the European Parliament to formally discuss the ESAs with the European Commission. I believe that the Commission must carry out an in-depth impact assessment as soon as possible, which will highlight the possible sectoral and geographical scenarios for the European economy as a result of the possible neutralisation of anti-dumping instruments. It would be appropriate for the Commission to commit itself to a public consultation, as is the case with all relevant legislative initiatives, in order to enable all stakeholders concerned to make their contribution. In view of tomorrow's meeting of the Council of Trade Ministers on the ESA, the Commission has sent member states an information note quantifying 210 000 jobs at risk if the ESME is allocated to China. I would be curious to know the parameters behind this estimate. I believe that the recognition of the ESF to China must absolutely remain subject to verification and proof that the technical requirements laid down by the European Union are met and, in any case, that a Plan B should be envisaged which includes equivalent trade defence measures to defend the European system.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). –
text: Mr President, the debate on the status of the Chinese economy is directly linked to whether anti-dumping duties can continue to be imposed on Chinese products to protect the European steel industry and other industries. However, before discussing whether or not the market economy exists in China, the gradual "Chineseisation" of the European economy should be discussed, since for some time now, European companies have been trying to emulate their Chinese counterparts in management and labour rights issues.  Proof of the substantial convergence of interests is the completion of the privatisation of the Piraeus Port Agency promoted by the sale of the last pier, which remained under public control, without protest on the part of the Troika and lenders. This alleged investment by the Chinese offers 368 million euros to the Greek State, when last year the purchase of a corresponding Turkish terminal of the same capacity by the same Chinese company cost 800 million euros.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, as has been shown many times in this debate, China is not a market economy and we are debating whether we can declare it or accept it as a market economy. I do not think so, because we should first support China in its democratisation, human rights and general values and standards. You can also add to them the environmental issues that have come up here, workers' rights and so on. Of course, the dumping that is particularly practised in the steel industry is also a big problem. However, I believe that the starting point is that China must come to the table of the common market economy through common values, which means that everything is not just free, but where there are common ethical trade guidelines and rules, fair trade rules. I therefore hope that China can be helped to develop in such a way that one day in the future it will be able to obtain market economy status, but unfortunately not yet.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, two weeks ago it was announced that over 1 000 jobs at Tata Steel could be lost, the majority of them in Port Talbot and Trostre in my constituency in Wales. Losing these jobs would be a massive blow to the local and the national economy. My party has been putting forward constructive and positive proposals to save the steel industry in Wales, but there has to be a long-term future. That means a speedy and thorough investigation of Chinese dumping and urgent action on tariffs on Chinese steel. Thousands of tons of steel are imported into the EU every week, undercutting Welsh produce and threatening thousands of jobs. I know that other countries suffer in the same way. Market economy status would make it nigh on impossible to impose tariffs on Chinese steel, despite our problems. That is why I am strongly opposed to it.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in the past we have asked the Commission for a technical study on the impact of the recognition of market economy status on China, but I did not expect such a politicised result as the one you presented to us. Your study mentions a maximum of 230 000 jobs lost, as against the 3 million announced by independent studies. Why this big difference? Because you used partial data to distort the statistics. Let me give you an example: you say that we must be concerned because only 1.38% of Chinese exports to Europe are subject to anti-dumping measures. But this is not true because before they were many more and they decreased precisely thanks to the anti-dumping duty. Therefore, when the duty can no longer be applied, imports will increase again. So why do we not calculate exports before anti-dumping measures? Furthermore, in the options you have presented you have not considered that it is also possible not to grant the ES MES, but to allow certain aspects of the anti-dumping duty calculation methodology to change. In short, Commissioner, as is often the case, it seems to me that this study already makes clear the Commission's intentions and are certainly not good for the workers.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish to thank Parliament for this debate. We have listened very carefully and heard your messages on this. The Commission is, of course, very aware of the complexity of all the aspects of this file and the importance that it has for some sectors and jobs. Let us not forget that the root causes for us discussing this issue today are the existing distortions in the Chinese economy. The current worsening economic situation in China and the increasing over—capacities makes any decision on this even more difficult. We are, together with colleagues in the Commission, reaching out to China to have a dialogue on this. It is imperative that China engage in this. It cannot pump out cheap steel as it is doing today on the market, and that is regardless of whatever we decide on the market economy status. We welcome this debate and we will continue to look into all the aspects of it: legal, economic and social. We are preparing an impact assessment that will cover different sections and that goes beyond the preliminary one that Members have been discussing. The one that some of you have been referring to that talks about millions and millions of jobs is simply scientifically not sustainable because it starts from the assumption that all our trade with China would be under anti-dumping and hence affected, whereas, as I said, it is only 1.38% of our trade with China that is subject to anti-dumping duties. We are looking at whether it is possible to strike the right balance between the objective of providing protection to our industry against unfair practices by China through a strengthened trade defence instrument, safeguarding the maximum of jobs in Europe while respecting legal international obligations and ensuring free trade and investment, which is so much in our common interests. This debate will continue. Rest assured that we will keep Parliament informed of all the steps in these discussions.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I firmly believe that at this time China should not be granted market economy status with regard to the anti-dumping measures. While the Chinese Government has been loosening its control on the government, which I commend, China has not met the criteria set out for market economy status. As long as it does not do so, we should not create the fiction that it does. Moreover, granting the status could result in the loss of more than 200 000 jobs, which will affect the steel industry in particular. However, a plan must be drawn up in the near future, since the expiration of the current measures is approaching. In the meantime, China must carry on with reforms, with possible help of the EU.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. In view of the imminent expiry of the transitional period provided for in China's Protocol on Access to the WTO, I welcome the fact that the Commission is finally beginning to listen to the European Parliament's demands on the issue of granting Market Economy status to China. This result, I would like to stress, is also the result of repeated pressure from the Group of The Party of European Socialists and Democrats, which has always highlighted the sensitivity of a subject with such crucial implications for the European economy. Looking at the current situation, we all agree that China cannot yet be regarded as a full market economy and the next deadline laid down in the Protocol cannot lead us to take hasty decisions that could cause incalculable damage to our industries and to employment. That is why we have asked the Commission to undertake to carry out a comprehensive and realistic impact assessment of the repercussions that the possible granting of the ESA would have in Europe. We also support the need for the EU to coordinate with its international partners before taking any final decision, as well as to maintain, in the face of all forms of unfair competition, instruments to protect its industry.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. China's Protocol of Accession to the WTO, signed in 2001, does not recognize China as a market economy, allowing the EU and other trading partners to apply anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures to alleviate State intervention in the costs and prices of products exported by the Asian country. The possible granting of market economy status to China in December 2016, resulting from the legal effects of the Protocol of Accession, could lead to the disappearance of anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures on Chinese products, with dramatic implications for industry and employment in Europe, especially in sectors such as the steel industry, chemistry, ceramics or mechanical engineering. Before taking any decision, the European Commission must carry out a thorough impact assessment analysing the effects of this situation on employment, consumers, investment and competitiveness of the EU and its SMEs. Coordination with our WTO trading partners is needed in order to continue implementing measures from December 2016 to ensure an equitable comparison between Chinese and European prices, without resulting in lower dumping margins than currently calculated.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. There is a frightening threat to Europe, of which the citizens of Europe know little or nothing: the recognition of China's market economy status. This is an eventuality that the European Commission is managing in an ambiguous and obscure way, on the basis of the provisions of China's Protocol of Accession to the WTO, pressed by the powerful industrial and commercial lobbies of Northern Europe, and the consequences of which would be potentially devastating for the production system, for the economy and, ultimately, for European society. To get out of it with broken bones would be above all Italy, which would suffer very heavy repercussions in sectors and production sectors in which it is a leader. The distortions in market conditions caused by the massive entry of Chinese products into Europe, the costs of which are artificially deflated by substantial State aid, would cause, in the absence of adequate trade defence measures, the loss of some 3 million jobs, of which about 400 000 in Italy alone. We cannot allow that. We have nothing against China, but we demand that trade relations should take place on an equal footing, which would not be the case if China were given market economy status that it does not actually have.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. – Our delegation today is not convinced that China should be granted effective market economy status. We note that, despite encouraging reforms, China still has many state-owned enterprises that, thanks to free capital and subsidies granted, stand in the way of fair competition. The calculation of dumping duties on the basis of internal Chinese prices will not yield market prices. There is therefore a danger for the European (manufacturing) sectors concerned if there is no competition on a level playing field, with the potential for a heavy loss of jobs and prosperity.  However, we also realise that many of our European companies have large interests in granting that market status and they do not benefit from a heavily clouded relationship with China. It is therefore an absolute prerequisite for the N-VA delegation to carry out a thorough legal analysis of china's accession protocol to the WHO as soon as possible and carry out an in-depth economic impact study that thoroughly maps the allocation of market status so that this dossier can be followed up with full knowledge.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. – China's Protocol of Accession to the WTO, signed in 2001, does not recognize China as a market economy allowing the EU and other trading partners to apply anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures to alleviate state intervention in the costs and prices of products exported by the Asian country. The possible granting of market economy status to China in December 2016, resulting from the legal effects of the Protocol of Accession, could lead to the disappearance of anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures on Chinese products, with dramatic implications for industry and employment in Europe, especially in sectors such as the steel industry, chemistry, ceramics or mechanical engineering. Before taking any decision, the European Commission must carry out a thorough impact assessment analysing the effects of this situation on employment, consumers, investment and competitiveness of the EU and its SMEs. Coordination with our WTO trading partners is needed in order to continue implementing measures from December 2016 to ensure an equitable comparison between Chinese and European prices, without resulting in lower dumping margins than currently calculated.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. China signed an accession protocol including a series of commitments to become a market economy after joining the WTO in 2001. This agreement allows other WTO members to apply non-market economy status to that country. This allows for the implementation of protective measures against Chinese imports.
