While China has met only one of the five criteria set by the EU for the recognition of its market economy status (SEM), the European Commission recently indicated that it would consider this possibility by December 2016. However, it is no secret that whole swathes of Chinese goods and services are receiving strong state aid. However, Community law strictly regulates cases of authorisation of such aid.  In these circumstances, granting the SEM to China would have a devastating impact on the European economy. Several studies show that this "dumping" permit would overwhelm the European market with chinese products at break-even prices, leading to a significant drop in EU industrial production with consequences for GDP and employment.  In the end, it is especially urgent to wait for China to reform deeply before considering conceding the SEM to it.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. "Granting China market economy country status is an important legal and economic issue. But it's not just about the money. Every day, China is blatantly and ruthlessly violating human rights. This is an undeniable fact that the EU's favoured silent diplomacy has failed to change. We've tried the money, too. Between 2002 and 2010, the EU invested almost EUR 500 million in projects aimed at supporting China's reform towards an open rule of law.  What did we get in return? We got a state that hijacks bookstores. Five publishers who had published a book critical of President Jinping recently disappeared in Hong Kong. When the matter became public, the men were found in Custody in China. However, the case is only the tip of the iceberg. In China, critics of the one-party system are routinely imprisoned and "retrained." You can't sweep these things under the carpet. I believe that human rights should also be borne in mind when discussing the granting of market economy country status to China.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. The issue of granting China market economy status will mark 2016. First of all, I would like to stress that China is not a market economy as it does not meet the five criteria set out by the European Union. Moreover, the numerous anti-dumping measures in force against China at present bear witness to this.  I take this opportunity to reiterate the need and urgency to modernize our trade defence instruments without weakening them. As we continue to seek to revive growth in Europe, granting China market economy status would be catastrophic for European jobs and industry. That is why we must continue to pursue our objectives of combating unfair competition and strengthening our businesses, especially for our SMEs.  We will be paying attention to the impact assessment to be published by the Commission in a few weeks and to its proposal this summer. We once again insist that the European Union should not be isolated and coordinate with major international trading partners and WTO members. Finally, we must already think about solutions to mitigate the effects of possible retaliatory measures.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing – Steel companies in Europe, U.S. Steel Košice, not including, in recent months, have been paying significantly for overcapacity of steel production in the world, especially in China. China's state-run and subsidised steel mills are making huge losses and are not dampening their unprofitable production in order not to jeopardise employment. China constantly and increasingly aggressively subsidises its products, which it exports at prices below their cost of production. It distorts the market and threatens production in countries that respect and respect the rules of international trade. Since its accession to the WTO in 2001 in 15 years, China has failed to take legislative and structural steps that would make it a standard market economy. If market economy status is granted to China, the European Union will lose any form of control and ability to protect itself against the disproportionately growing imports of various types of Chinese goods into the European market. The European Union should choose a common approach with other WTO Member States and agree a compromise with China in the form of partial or sectoral recognition of market economy status. However, there must be pressure to put an end to unfair practices and to improve environmental and social standards in Chinese industrial production.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. It is widely believed that China has made good progress in implementing its WTO commitments, but it must be acknowledged that there are still major shortcomings, which lead me to strongly express my opposition to the automatic granting of market economy status to China. The lack of transparency, the existence of measures discriminating against foreign companies, government intervention in the economy and not least workers' conditions are evident. China is not a market economy, and that is why we are telling the Commission that we need an independent assessment of the impact of this measure on European employment. We need effective anti-dumping instruments to tackle unfair competition. Any sectoral solution could seriously damage our industrial system. We need specific instruments, it is not protectionism, but only the application of clear rules for a fair competition policy.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. When China joined the World Trade Organisation under certain conditions in 2001, the EU decided that, at the end of 15 years, it would consider whether to grant it market economy status (ESA) and consequently lift all anti-dumping restrictions on imports of Chinese products, justified precisely by the need to defend the European economy against unfair competition with an economy that is not, in all respects, market-based. The 15 years expire in December, yet we still do not know the real intentions of the Commission, which has so far avoided any real confrontation and public debate. But the most worrying fact is that the Commission has never ruled out the fact that an ESA concession to China can take place almost automatically, among other things without proper political reflection or an effective impact study. For the 5-Star Movement, not only is there no obligation to recognise China among the market economies, which it is not really, but a decision to do so would be a real suicide for the European economy, which would obviously be exposed to unsustainable competition from Chinese products, based on artificially low or cheap prices, with huge distortions in the internal market and dramatic repercussions on employment and even on our social and environmental standards already under pressure.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on the oral issue at the Commission on the Economic Partnership Agreement between the European Union and West Africa: sustainable development provisions, by Bernd Lange and Christofer Fjellner, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade (O-000011/2016-B8-0108/2016).

name: Bernd Lange
text: Chairman of the Committee on International Trade. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which We have been negotiating with African states for a long time in order to shape the partnership agreements in such a way that they are ready for signature and are also being ratified by Parliament. We want this because we really want to strengthen the economic development of the partner countries in Africa, including regional development.  As far as West Africa is concerned, we know that many countries are also very dependent on exports and that regional value chains are not developed. In this respect, we have introduced many asymmetric aspects there, safeguard mechanisms, we have completely excluded certain sensitive areas from the agreement, and the objective of strengthening regional added value is, I believe, very clear. If you look at the fact that about 80% of the cocoa beans we consume come from West Africa in particular, but only 4% of chocolate, it is clear that there is a need to increase value creation here. However, if you look at West Africa, of course, there are also some issues of sustainable development. Once again, on cocoa, we know that child labour is the rule when harvesting cocoa beans, and I cannot imagine, however, that if we consume children's chocolate, we run the risk of promoting child labour. That is why we need to focus on the issue of sustainability, especially as far as West Africa is concerned. And that's where a special weirdness comes into play. We have already concluded a partnership agreement which is also more or less working, namely the CARIFORUM agreement; David Martin is the expert. And there we have many very positive references, especially as far as the sustainability chapter is concerned. And if you compare that now with the West Africa Agreement, Commissioner, you have to say that there are many white papers. And that is why we are asking these four questions. In other words, how we really want to ensure that the issue of human rights and workers' rights is implemented. The CARIFORUM agreement provides a clear link with ILO standards, in particular the issue of forced child labour. The second question relates to the consultative body to be set up. Here, too, the agreement lacks a clear description of tasks – also a major difference from the CARIFORUM agreement. So the questions: How are the tasks defined? What resources does this body actually have? What are the procedures? Will third parties also be involved? The CARIFORUM agreement, for example, includes the ILO and also the question of how dispute resolution is concerned: what mechanisms are working? That, too, is behind the second question, and the third question is once again a matter of principle, how the Commission as a whole, DGTRADE, and the External Action Service, want to ensure that civil society organisations and their opinions are adequately involved. And, of course, we would like to know how these three elements will be embedded in time, so that when we ratify the EPO with West Africa, we are also sure that sustainability is adequately guaranteed.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the ‘Trade for All’ communication that the Commission and I presented to you last year stresses our commitment to ensuring that trade agreements deliver concrete results, including on sustainable development, and that our values are always promoted in our trade relations. This is the case for the Economic Partnership Agreements. They are anchored in the principles and the provisions of the Cotonou Agreement. That means the overarching sustainable development objective, including its social, economic and environmental components. It also means the essential elements of the Cotonou Agreement, including human rights, and thirdly, it means specific provisions on trade and labour standards and environment. These objectives and principles will shape the implementation of the West Africa—EU EPA, from the entry into force and throughout its existence. To make sure that the EPA lives up to its ambition, the Commission will pay particular attention to monitoring it – including as regards sustainable development aspects. A jointly-agreed competitiveness observatory will monitor and assess the overall impact of the EPA, including the way in which the sustainable development objectives are achieved. As for the agreed time frame for the EPA implementation, it is a long-term agreement under which a joint review will take place every five years. This will allow the parties to regularly evaluate progress and address outstanding challenges. Let me insist that, from the Commission side, we will pay particular attention to human rights, labour standards and environmental protection in those reviews. Depending on the results of the monitoring and review, specific measures can be taken. Those measures should consist of adjudging EPA implementation or even proposing amendments to the text in close cooperation with our West African partners. In the case of issues regarding the respective commitments defined as essential elements of the partnership, including human rights and core labour rights, the Commission will use the instruments and the mechanisms that are provided for in the Cotonou Agreement. That starts with political dialogue and ends with appropriate measures, including the last-resort option of suspension of market access preferences. The EPA stakeholders and institutions have a role here in monitoring. The Commission has already started preparations with West Africa for the early constitution of a Joint Consultative Committee, foreseen under the EPA, which shall have broad civil society representation. The EPA also foresees financial support to the institution, including the Consultative Committee. The Commission has earmarked funding possibilities in this respect under the European Development Fund and the partnership instrument. The EPA clearly provides that the Consultative Committee will work in consultation with the EPA Council, or on its own initiative, and make recommendations on all issues falling under the scope and objectives of the EPA. Within the EPA Council and the implementation committee, the parties will carefully consider any EPA—related issue brought to their attention, be they concerns regarding a possible infringement or other issues. The Commission will take careful account of the civil society contribution within this institutional context and seek policy change when appropriate. The objective is to promote sustainable development consideration in all relevant areas of the EPA. Achieving the outcomes we are striving for will, of course, require partnership, cooperation, effectiveness and policy coherence and a central role for domestic actors and policies in West Africa. It would be very good if Parliament started now to engage in preparations with West Africa in order to set up the Joint Parliamentary Committee as soon as the EPA enters into force. This would be a key organ to monitor the impact and effectiveness of the EPA. It is very important to make the link with domestic reforms and to engage in a policy dialogue. It will also be a valuable tool for us in the Commission to make sure that the dialogue on the implementation is monitored. Thank you very much. I hope this answered Mr Lange’s questions.

name: Daniel Caspary
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her If you look at where, in recent weeks and months, a large number of the economic refugees who are coming to Europe are coming from, we keep looking to Africa, and at the latest it becomes clear that we must do everything we can to improve the reality of life for the people of Africa. And trade cannot do everything there. Our Economic Partnership Agreements will not be able to resolve everything either, but they can at least make a small modest contribution, and in this sense I hope that we will bring this agreement into force as quickly as possible in as many countries as possible. However, I would like to highlight a number of things that Mr Lange has already mentioned. It is above all the things that are different in this agreement than in an Economic Partnership Agreement, which is already in force. I think that is one point: why are some things different? Who inspired that? I think that is the question: was this the European negotiating position to write things in there rather softer and more non-binding – then I would also take a more critical view of some things – or were it our negotiating partners in Africa who perhaps had different ideas in these countries, which we must of course also take into account? In the end, such agreements can only enter into force if both sides agree and, accordingly, do not dominate one side over the other. Commissioner, take this week's opportunity. We have the Nigerian President here in the House this week on Wednesday; that would be a great sign if we could perhaps be signalled this week that a country would join this agreement next week or that a country would have its next support for it.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, in autumn last year, Commissioner ,you unveiled the EU’s new trade policy: Trade for All. We were told that sustainable development and human rights would be strengthened in the EU trade deals. And yet, here we are tonight debating a trade deal with West Africa in which sustainable development has undoubtedly been sidelined. When it comes to human rights, labour and the environment, implementation is absolutely key. The systematic involvement of civil society is crucial. In this agreement, we wholly lack the tools needed to make any of these rights a reality in practice rather than just rights on paper. This must be bolstered. This is what the EU has delivered in all of its trade deals over the last ten years. Our African partners want a balanced relationship with the EU, based on mutual respect. That entails holding them to the same standards and monitoring to which we hold the rest of the world. We need some improvements, please.

name: Arne Gericke
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I thank the Committee on Trade for the initiative on this question and, as a development politician, human rights politician and coordinator for the ACP countries, I can only endorse it. Hard-hitting trade politicians – and they probably exist in almost all political groups – do not like to hear this, but fair play is not a term that only exists on the football field, and the economy and trade also need fair play. We in Europe like to call ourselves a community of values. As a family man and a Christian, this is very important to me, and I am pleased that you, Commissioner Malmström, have pointed this out. My appeal, therefore, is that we are doing everything we can to ensure fair play in the agreement with West Africa and all other economic agreements, and we will create a new generation of fair trade agreements! In Germany, we like to say "we can do this". With regard to fair trade, Please, if we want this together, we will be able to do it!

name: João Ferreira
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, let us be clear: the negotiations on these agreements, called economic partnership, in fact free trade agreements, have only dragged on for more than ten years because African countries have resisted as long as they have been able to sign them. And they resisted because these agreements do not promote development, on the contrary, they compromise it. And they undermine this because they deprive African countries of fundamental tax revenues while forcing them to open their markets to European products and services, to open doors, in essence, to a new colonizing wave.  Were these agreements good for african countries and they would have welcomed them with open arms from the first hour, which did not happen. The truth is that only in the face of the unjust blackmail of the European Union and after several years have these countries found themselves in the contingency of having to give in.  What this question reveals is, first of all, the bad conscience of some. As is well in sight, with this debate, its practical effects have been few or none.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for outlining again that human rights should be at the core of the European Union trade strategy, and that is something I very much agree with. But the question is: how do we do that?  I think that in this economic partnership agreement we have not managed to have a successful inclusion of human rights with teeth. The ‘essential elements’ clause that you mentioned has hardly ever been used in the past, so how are we going to make sure that this is a possibility that will really be used? Monitoring has often not held anyone to account and has not worked towards ensuring human rights. So how are we going to make sure that we actually have a human rights clause here in this agreement that also has teeth, that can be applied, that leads to the sanctions that you are pointing out? I think there are a couple of shortcomings there still; we do not have a sustainable development chapter. I do think that this is a problem, but I am very happy to hear your suggestions about how we are really giving these human rights teeth and possibilities for sanctions.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The left and opponents of free trade often describe these negotiations as if Europe forces and pressures poor countries to accept our view of trade. What if it were so simple that we came up with our position, and then we went up and said "sign on the last page", and so it just became so.  What is fascinating now in this room is that the same left – often the same opponents of free trade – are now outraged that african countries did not want to sign up to exactly the demands they themselves are now making. The fact is that trade is probably the most important way to combat poverty and achieve sustainable development.  And that is why, when the debate is finished, there is only one question: do we think africa will be richer by negotiating with us or do we think they will be poorer? Do we think they will be richer if we let them have this agreement, which they want, or do we think they will be poorer? I believe in the beneficial effect of free trade. I hope my colleagues will too.

name: David Martin (S&D).
text: – Madam President, as Bernd Lange rightly says, I had the privilege of being the rapporteur for the CARIFORUM Economic Partnership Agreement, and so I hope I am forgiven for seeing that as a bit of a benchmark for other EPAs. If that is the benchmark, then – as others have said and as the Commissioner herself has said – ECOWAS fails this comparison. Instead of a detailed chapter on social and environmental standards such as we have in CARIFORUM, the West Africa Agreement makes heavy reference back to Cotonou. But as we know, the upcoming expiry of Cotonou leaves us wondering exactly how this EPA will be enforceable in the future. I would like to hear more about how the Commissioner sees the expiry of Cotonou in relation to the West African EPA. I slightly disagree with Ska Keller on monitoring. I accept her point that monitoring has not been successful so far, but I do welcome the Commissioner’s commitment to ensuring that the monitoring groups are properly financed, that they are able to operate and that you will act on any reports that come from them. And that is true. It has not been the history so far, but if we do have active monitoring groups, this could be progress.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Madam President, I will have three questions. The first has already been put forward by David Martin: it concerns the reference to the Cotonou agreement. This reference in the agreement with West Africa says: "We will refer to relevant provisions of Cotonou". I think that talking about relevant provisions introduces a particular legal interpretation. Moreover, when the Cotonou agreement expires, what will be the legal basis for achieving the provisions on dialogue and sanctions? The second question is about the benefit to African countries. Of the West African countries, 12 out of 16 states are LDCs, i.e. not affected by EPAs, and only 3 countries are in GSP. In January 2012, the South Centre calculated the difference between the EPA and GSP, and this study concludes that for most West African countries, tax losses are greater than gains. So where does the interest of these African countries come from? The third question concerns the situation and the position of Nigeria, which is currently fiercely opposed. We understand his position, because it is experiencing a decrease in its GDP and a decrease of 7 billion in its budgetary revenues. What do you say in Nigeria?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). –
text: Madam President, we consider it important to negotiate the European Union partnership with the west African countries, but of course there must be certain conditions. I believe that there must first of all be sustainable development and cooperation between the countries of the region must be strengthened, because that is the only way to develop and with growth we will not have large waves of economic migrants, who are now coming to Europe.  At the same time, with regional cooperation we will also have peace consolidation and thus reduce conflicts in order to have a second positive result, to limit the refugee flows that also start in this region and come to Europe.  On the other hand, however, we must take the issue of human rights violations seriously, because child labour, as it has developed, is something that is now happening all the time and I think we must be vertically opposed to it.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, trade is indeed a very important tool to fight poverty. Combined with development assistance and other foreign policy tools, it can really contribute to improving living conditions, creating jobs and possibilities for people. The economic partnership agreements (EPAs) are, as you know, asymmetrical free trade agreements. We open up for them but we do not ask the African countries or the ACP countries to open up to the same extent, because we know that some sectors are very vulnerable. They are included in very long phasing-out sections in order to help them to diversify their economy. Ms Arena, I was in Nigeria just before Christmas and I spoke to many people from Nigeria, and I think this would indeed benefit Nigeria enormously – precisely because of its economic problems – to help diversify its economy, to make sure that it can rise in the value chains, if we can help them to develop assistance so that that they can have standards and qualifications on their products , for instance in agriculture, and also to support regional integration, because that is a very important part of the EPAs: regional integration and the development dimension. Together with my colleague Neven Mimica, we are working very closely to make sure that there is a lot of development assistance in the EPAs. Sustainability and human rights are indeed key to all our trade agreements. I agree with Ms Keller that we could have done even more in this area. It is not always easy, but we are trying to find ways. You know that the way for the European Union is to start with dialogue, not with sanctions, because if you start with sanctions, those who will suffer are not the regime – the authorities; it is the ordinary people who benefit from the contacts. The EU model is to start with dialogue, try to set up different forums, engage with civil society. Then, of course, there is the sanction possibility in the end, but there are lots of steps that can be taken. Our African partners in the West African Agreement were not ready to go as far as we would have wanted them when it comes to sustainable development formulas: this is under negotiation. That is why there is a rendez-vous clause where we have agreed to see if we can pursue that even further. But anyway we will, as I said in my introduction, pay specific attention to implementing, monitoring and making sure that we follow up on labour, environmental and human rights in the different forums that we are creating here, and the European Parliament has a very important role to play here. Cotonou indeed expires, Mr Martin, and we are engaged to see what will come after Cotonou. But whatever happens to Cotonou, the provisions there are still valuable, and the principles will not be changed, whatever happens to Cotonou. Also in Cotonou we have monitoring possibilities with human rights dialogue, etc. We firmly believe, in the contacts we have had with the ACP countries – today we are talking about West Africa, but we have other ongoing or almost-closed negotiations – that this is something that has been done in partnership. There you take and give, but this is something that will be truly beneficial for, in this case, West Africa, but also for the other ACP countries in order to help them to develop, to create new possibilities, growth, jobs, and indeed possibilities to sustain their families in these countries, and also to promote a bigger impact on regional integration, which is something that is really lacking in this part of the world.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. After ten years of negotiations, we strongly support the achievement of the Economic Partnership Agreement with the West African Community of States. The Treaty is a coherent link between the European Union's trade and foreign policies. EpAs, if properly implemented, are in fact an excellent opportunity to promote sustainable growth and respect for human rights through the tools typical of trade agreements. The most delicate phase is precisely that of application. Experience with development aid and the implementation of trade treaties has shown that promises are all too often disillusioned. While recognising the fundamental contribution of the Cotonou Convention to cooperation and the active promotion of respect for fundamental rights, the lack of specific forecasts in the text is of some concern. In order to promote real development and social progress in West Africa, I believe that the political dimension of the agreement must take precedence over the trade dimension. I would therefore like to ask the Commission what mechanisms it will have in terms of the involvement of civil society and to establish a permanent and decisive dialogue with the partners in the area. I believe, in fact, that regular comparison can guarantee tangible results and avoid the conditions which, through the application of Article 96 of the Convention, would entail the suspension of the agreement.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on Mark Demesmaeker's report on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Security on the mid-term review of the European Union's biodiversity strategy (2015/2137 (INI)) (A8-0003/2016).

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Rapporteur. – Investing in nature and biodiversity must be at the heart of a smart, sustainable, inclusive Europe. On top of the overwhelming intrinsic value of nature, biodiversity offers unaffordable socio-economic benefits. One in six jobs in the European Union depends on nature. The added value of Natura 2000, the European network of top nature, is many times greater than the management costs and missing out on the biodiversity strategy will cost us EUR 50 billion a year. Biodiversity loss is therefore rightly regarded as one of the greatest global threats, and it is.  Nevertheless, we are seriously failing in the implementation of the European Biodiversity Strategy and today we are far from halfway through achieving the 2020 targets. Despite encouraging points of hope that targeted efforts do indeed produce success stories and that the objectives are achievable, the overall picture remains extremely bleak. Only 23% of species and 16% of habitats are in good condition. Without considerable additional efforts, we cannot avert a scenario such as in 2010 and we will miss the appointment again in 2020. The central message of my report is therefore that more political will is urgently needed to turn the tide and that is at all levels of policy. Better implementation, stricter enforcement and further integration of biodiversity into other policy areas are essential. In addition, all stakeholders should be involved in this story up to and including the individual citizen.  Colleagues, the bird and habitat guidelines are a crucial link in this story. My position in front of the ongoing fitness check of the nature guidelines is crystal clear. The directives should not be revised. On the contrary, they must be fully implemented. A revision of it would jeopardize the biodiversity strategy itself, would entail a long period of legal uncertainty and potentially weaken these milestones of European nature policy. Moreover, I am convinced that a revision would not provide a solution. The possible problems do not lie with the legislation itself, but above all the incomplete implementation and enforcement of the nature directives.  I'm not alone in my position. The Committee on the Environment supported my report almost unanimously. And I strongly believe that tomorrow the entire Parliament will also send a clear signal to the European Commission. Moreover, more than half a million European citizens spoke out against a review of nature guidelines through the Nature Alert Campaign. Ministers also expressed their explicit support for the nature directives at the Environment Council on 16 December and stressed above all the importance of better implementation. Finally, the initial findings of the fitness check confirm that the nature guidelines are effective, efficient and relevant when implemented properly.  I like to use an example. Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Vella, last Friday I visited the port area of Antwerp with you. We have seen in concrete terms how nature and economic development can go hand in hand through a network of core areas, of green corridors, the interests of Europe's second largest port are reconciled with the protection of fragile fauna and flora in and around the port and the Scheldt. The area-oriented and proactive Antwerp approach confirms that a revision of the nature directives is absolutely not on the agenda, but that we must make a full commitment to facilitating the process of implementation. The Commission must play a crucial role in this, in particular by proposing improved guidelines that enshrined best practice and by ensuring that these guidelines are fully recognised and fully supported. And I call on the Commission to listen to all these signals and, above all, to stop the uncertainty about the fitness check. We cannot afford to waste any more time if we are not to miss the 2020 agreement, we must do everything we can to fully implement the nature directives.  I also expect the Commission's efforts for additional actions, for additional innovative solutions to halt biodiversity loss in Europe, such as the concrete development of a trans-European network of green infrastructure, such as initiatives to prevent biodiversity loss outside the protected areas and through actions to protect pollinators.  Ladies and gentlemen, loss of biodiversity means loss for nature, for man, for the economy. In the interests of the health, well-being and prosperity of future generations, I count on your support to safeguard nature. All that remains is my colleagues, my colleagues. to expressly thank shadow rapporteurs for the very constructive cooperation. It was a privilege and an honor to work with you.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first and foremost, I would like to thank my colleague, the rapporteur, Mark Demesmaeker, for his report on the biodiversity mid-term review. It is an honour for me to contribute to this discussion on the EU’s progress towards achieving its 2020 biodiversity targets. The European Parliament’s report, which is being put forward for adoption tomorrow, delivers a strong message about the importance of biodiversity and ecosystem services for human welfare and socio-economic development, but it also delivers a message of concern about protecting this essential natural capital. I believe that this report can help steer and accelerate progress towards the difficult task of achieving our 2020 biodiversity targets. The Commission’s biodiversity mid—term review revealed that, while we are mid-term – and here I agree completely with Mr Demesmaeker – we are not mid-way to achieving our targets. We are continuing to lose biodiversity, and this has very serious implications for our ability to ensure food security, for our quality of life and sustainable socio-economic development, and for mitigating and adapting to climate change and delivering on our international commitments, including the recently-adopted Agenda 2030 for Sustainable Development. Without any doubt, the Commission will carefully consider Parliament’s recommendation for action at EU level. I agree that, in addition to completing the EU policy framework, there needs to be much strengthened implementation on the ground. We need to mobilise the efforts of actors at all levels and across many sectors in order to deliver on our biodiversity commitments. We need, in particular, to fully implement the EU nature legislation, focusing our efforts on completing the Natura 2000 network, especially for the marine environment, and on ensuring effective management and financing of Natura 2000 sites. The ongoing fitness check of the EU nature legislation provoked the highest ever number of responses – over half a million – to a Commission public consultation, demonstrating the level of importance of nature and biodiversity to European citizens. It has also generated a huge amount of evidence. Here I would like to stress that the fitness check is an opportunity to consider how we can better ensure that the nature directives, which are key instruments in achieving our biodiversity goals, are both effective and efficient. There are issues about implementation, resources, sharing of knowledge and experience, and also the issue about the engagement of all stakeholders. All these issues deserve our full attention. I would like to inform this Parliament that the Commission is on track to deliver its conclusions on the fitness check exercise in the spring and to propose follow—up action later this year. Yes, the nature directives play a central and critical role in halting biodiversity loss in Europe, but they are not enough on their own. We need to do more to effectively protect and restore biodiversity and ecosystem services both within and beyond the Natura 2000 network. Focusing on the positive economic gains through recognising and accounting for biodiversity will also be key. We must deliver on the broader goals of the EU biodiversity strategy, and this will ultimately depend on society’s commitment to sustainable production and consumption. It is very clear that we need to raise awareness about the value of nature and biodiversity, not only because nature and biodiversity are valuable in themselves and important for citizens, but also because they underpin our well-being and socio-economic development. This must be better understood and integrated into planning and decision—making. Our mid—term review particularly highlighted the importance of agriculture and forestry, which together cover no less than 80% of the EU landmass. It also highlighted the importance of marine fisheries development and trade policies. These sectors must therefore be at the heart of any solution to halting biodiversity loss. There are many excellent examples of local improvements as a direct result of good practices, and these carry an important message about the achievability of the 2020 biodiversity targets. I would like to note that the adoption of the EU Regulation on Invasive Alien Species was a very significant achievement, and its implementation will enable the launch of targeted measures on the ground. This will go a long way towards tackling one of the main causes of biodiversity loss in the European Union. As you all know, the Commission wasted no time in developing a first list of species of Union concern and is already carrying out preparatory work with a view to updating this later this year. Finally, at global level, we need to deliver on our international financial commitments whilst addressing the underlying causes of global biodiversity loss, including the impacts of EU consumption, production and trade. I hope that we can do all of this together so that by 2020 we will have a positive result, which will be a significant stepping stone towards our 2030 sustainable development goals.

name: Jordi Sebastià
text: draftser of the Opinion of the Committee on Development. – Madam President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank the author for his work. This is a very comprehensive and absolutely necessary report.  From the Committee on Development, as the author of our opinion, I would also like to congratulate the collaborators of the different groups on the text achieved. I am pleased to see that our most important demands have been introduced into the text. They had a basic point: to call for the European Union's development collaboration strategies to never support policies that would be detrimental to biodiversity. We must never finance economic strategies that harm ecological diversity.  We know that the most unprotected populations, such as indigenous peoples or peasants, suffer the most from this ill-called development. There is no development if there is no sustainability, and there is no sustainability if biodiversity is not ensured. Ecosystem degradation threatens all species, especially the human species.  The report is clear, denounces unsustainable consumption patterns and shows that it is not the legislation, but its lack of implementation that is causing biodiversity loss.  I call for a vote in favour, of course, and for this Parliament to make the defence of biodiversity one of Europe's flags on a global scale, and also against those Member States which do not fulfil their obligations and irresponsiblely drown out the future of citizens.

name: Norbert Lins
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would like to express my sincere thanks to the rapporteur for the open and fruitful cooperation. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats supports a strong and targeted parliamentary response to the mid-term review of the biodiversity strategy and also sees it as a reference to the current fitness check of the two key European nature directives. As the RAPPORTEUR for the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I am opposed to the opening up of the directives and do not criticise the legal basis as such. On the contrary, I call for political will from all 28 Member States for improved implementation. Our own-initiative report should focus on the mid-term review in the narrower sense and not want to cover the wide range of biodiversity as a whole. I represent a precise and clear answer to the Council and the Commission. That is why the GROUP has requested some split votes for tomorrow's vote. The broad acceptance and participation of all stakeholders is essential for improved biodiversity. Nature conservation must not be decided over the heads of farmers, but must be done in close coordination with all the actors involved. I think it is wrong to condemn the common agricultural policy, which has just been reformed. The new measures must be able to take effect before any consideration is given to possible adjustments. Legal requirements are not always the only instrument, and contract nature protection could also be a possibility.

name: Karin Kadenbach
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Just two messages: firstly, we must seriously promote biodiversity. Secondly, there is a very clear commitment by this European Parliament – and this will also be confirmed in the vote tomorrow – that we do not need a revision of these two nature directives. We are convinced of this, and the examples also show very clearly that these nature protection directives produce sustainability in biodiversity where they are properly implemented, where they are properly implemented. This means that everything is open, everything would change, it would lead to uncertainty and a negative effect. Commissioner, we make a clear appeal to you: we need life – organic – we need diversity and we need diversity, but we certainly do not need a revision. We need your support, the Commission's support for implementation in many Member States and, above all, in monitoring implementation. That is the big problem. A large proportion of the Member States are in default in many areas. That is where we ask us to work really hard. Organic - life, diversity - diversity - we lose 150 species in this world every day. This is something we experience in connection with the quality of our soil, with the quality of our water, with the quality of our eco-service services. Let us try together to make clear in the Member States the need to transpose these directives. The population – as all Eurobarometer surveys show us – is in favour of biodiversity. We just have to live it. We do not need tinkering, we do not need simplifications, because that only creates uncertainty and, in reality, a deterioration of the situation. Together, we can safely achieve our goals by 2020.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab There is no doubt that biodiversity must be protected and poland is a country with such rich biodiversity. Mr Demesmaeker's report points out well the issues that have been problematic in the biodiversity strategy so far. However, the shale gas extraction records reported by the Greens go too far. Their adoption would make it impossible to extract shale gas. Poland is committed to increasing energy independence from Russia. We can achieve this by extracting shale gas. This can be done without compromising biodiversity and there is no reason to believe that shale gas extraction carries a greater risk than any other type of industrial activity.

name: Catherine Bearder
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, this mid-term review could not be clearer: unless Member States step up their efforts to better deliver and enforce legislation in the EU, we will once again fail to meet our biodiversity targets for 2020 – just like we did in 2010. Given this worrying trend, we cannot afford to waste time by opening up our legislation, which is recognised globally to be the gold standard in environmental protection, as it protects our biodiversity – namely, the Birds and Habitats Directive. Thanks to the Natura 2000 sites across the EU, thousands of species enjoy protection. These sites generate environmental and socio-economic benefits worth around EUR 300 billion annually. Revising the directives now would lead to years of legal uncertainty and would further divert us from reaching our biodiversity targets. We know what we need: better enforcement and implementation of existing laws. Protecting biodiversity makes economic sense too. If we miss our overall biodiversity targets, it is estimated that this will cost EUR 50 billion per year in lost natural services, never mind the risks of destroying the biosphere and permanently damaging the life-sustaining forces on our continent. We all know that we are running out of time. There are things that you could do, Commissioner, to help us reach the 2020 targets. Will you commit here today to working with the Council to ensure better delivery of the regulations which protect our biodiversity? We know that the lack of enforcement by Member States is the big elephant in the room. Countries are refusing to accept their responsibilities, so it is very sad that the Council is not here today to take part in the debate. Will you, Commissioner, propose without delay an EU legal framework of environmental inspections and access to justice for those who are working to protect our treasured biodiversity? Citizens look to us to give them better tools to ensure that they can hold their governments to account. I understand you share this Parliament’s frustrations, but these are steps that Europe can and must take to ensure we meet our biodiversity targets.

name: La Présidente. –
text: I will not accept blue cards, ladies and gentlemen, because we are very late, it is a very long debate and we still have one minute speeches.

name: Lynn Boylan
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, biodiversity across Europe is in crisis and the European Commission’s own mid-term review admits it. No significant progress has been made on halting the degradation of our ecosystems and biodiversity loss. Pitifully, only one out of the six headline targets has shown any progress. I have listened to Commissioner Vella tonight and I have not heard him categorically rule out a revision of the nature directives. The nature directives have been shown to have tangible benefits in the protection of wildlife and ecological habitats, and I am extremely pleased that in this report we have clearly outlined that we object to any possible revision of these directives. We know it is the implementation and enforcement that remains the problem – not the legislation itself – so the European Parliament tomorrow is due to add its voice to the half-a-million citizens who responded loud and clear to the public consultation to protect these laws. The question is, Commissioner Vella: are you listening?

name: Margrete Auken
text: verts/ALE Group. Madam President! Thank you for a good report and thank you for your exemplary cooperation. Dear Commissioner Vella: If it ain't broken, don't try to fix it! That's the message you get all around here. All the fine words about everything that needs to be done also sound in our ears threatening! Because what we can hear is that the whole thing with such a powerful agenda ends up turning into nothing and uncertainty, as has been repeated so many times here today. No, don't tamper with the directives! Let them stay, but make sure they are met, that they are implemented and there will be proper checks! We know that from all the studies that have been done. That's the message we're getting around.  And you know what? I know that you are under tremendous pressure from the Commission, and I might also be afraid of Timmermans, but all of us elected, we stand with you and look after you! We will make sure that you also survive to stand firmly on the side of nature in this context; make sure we get a proper implementation, it's mentioned all around. I would also like to mention the Aarhus Convention, which must now be fully implemented, so that we also have access to appeal and review, that is, that we can go to court.  We have such good tools in this house and in this system if we really want to use them. So listen now to the elected representatives, and that is the Council, it is Parliament, and these are the regions.

name: Marco Affronte
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the report before us is an excellent one and we have worked on it as shadow rapporteur. A very good job has been done by the rapporteur; the report is complete and detailed, everything is in it and there are many proposals. We will support it and we believe, from what we have heard, that tomorrow it will have the positive vote of the whole House.  The problem is that it is a bitter vote in the mouth because, despite the support for this report, despite the positive vote, we will not be able to achieve the objectives that are in the biodiversity strategy for 2020. The medium-term ratio is disastrous and we are not even close to any of the 6 targets we are trying to target for 2020. Therefore, despite our efforts, the situation remains disastrous and it is depressing to see how the Member States do little to protect biodiversity and to implement the rules that could protect it and protect it and provide wealth, also as a result of this protection. Commissioner, like all the other Members of this House, we are calling for the Habitats Directive and the Birds Directive to be maintained without revision, but with better implementation and implementation.

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we care a lot about the protection of biodiversity. And in my country, Spain, we care a lot, because we are not in vain the country that contributes the most to the Natura 2000 Network. In recent years, in addition, we have made great contributions also to nature in the marine environment. The legislation in force , we have all told you , is very good. It has provided us with a very strong legal framework and its implementation has achieved important goals, but we must be ambitious and perfectionist. However, it should not be modified. It is necessary only to focus on strengthening and improving the implementation of existing legislation, drawing on the experience we have gained. Changing the legislation would only be a step back. The Biodiversity Strategy must be maintained and it is very good; it's being done very well. The most important task is for the Commission, with the cooperation of the Member States, to propose clear and concetive guidelines for its implementation so that controversial situations and comparative grievances can be avoided. And, by way of example, I would like to point out serious problems that occur in my country, for example, with the increase in wolf populations, which are causing many problems in the large livestock areas of northern Spain. I might also refer to bird hunting, but I'm out of time.

name: Renata Briano (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the loss of biodiversity is mainly due to human causes such as pollution, soil consumption and climate change. That is where we need to take action! Biodiversity has enormous socio-economic value in that it creates jobs – four and a half million in the Natura 2000 network. The value of pollinating insects is estimated at EUR 15 billion per year, while damage caused by invasive species costs EUR 12 billion. It is therefore clear that investing in nature has costs, but these are not comparable to those due to non-intervention. Just think of the damage caused by the floods.  We need to involve all actors, as we do in the biodiversity, hunting and rurality intergroup, where we work together with researchers, farmers, foresters, hunters and parks to find common solutions. The common fisheries policy must also involve not only fishermen, who are making enormous efforts, but also local authorities, marine protected areas, maritime transport and ports in the protection of the sea. Let us think about the problem of plastic at sea.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, after the previous European biodiversity strategy completely failed, I became rapporteur in 2011 on biodiversity, and we agreed here that this time it would be different. In this plenary hall we all emphasised the enormous importance of biodiversity for mankind. From the far left all the way to the far right, this time would be different, and yes, the reform of the fisheries policy was successful and made it much more sustainable. But what about the common agricultural policy and cohesion policy? There we failed. We did not make it more sustainable. So here we are in 2016, half way, and one conclusion stands: the EU fails seriously in achieving its biodiversity strategy. Simply muddling through is no solution any more. So, Commissioner – and the absent Council – do not let 500 million Europeans down, and please take serious steps on biodiversity.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, we in UKIP believe in the importance of preserving nature reserves and natural habitats for wildlife in Britain and Europe. In fact, I belong to the Wiltshire Wildlife Trust, which has preserved beautiful tracts of the county. Consequently we are willing to support the improvement of existing legislation on this issue. However, we believe that this task should be a national responsibility, and we therefore oppose new EU legislation in this area. The best people to decide on natural habitats in Britain are the British. We do not trust the unelected European Commission to decide on the protection of the environment and animal welfare. As for climate change, I would suggest that currently in the UK, the greatest risk to wildlife is the unprecedented demand for housing as a direct result of population growth and migration into the UK, which is seeing our beautiful green and pleasant land rapidly disappearing under tarmac and concrete.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Demesmaeker on the work he has done. Your report is positive," many speakers said tonight.  I firmly believe that the preparation of this report should serve to contribute to the analysis of the situation of environmental legislation and to position this house for future revisions to the legislation. However, this is not yet the time to push for the revision of these rules. Every thing in time: today it's time to analyze the application of them. Going further at this time could be a cause of legal uncertainty that would endanger biodiversity, precisely in the European Union. Adding, in parallel with existing threats, legislative and political stumbles would be awkward.  Among the many specific issues touched on in the report, I would like to stress the need for the Commission to draw up without delay a precise and comprehensive list of the Union's invasive alien species in order to defend precisely our biodiversity. It is necessary to ensure that those localized and dangerous invasive species, in accordance with EFSA reports, are eradicated before they expand around the Union, through the development of comprehensive implementation measures supported by appropriate means, as envisaged in the report itself.  The challenges posed to us by invasive species will be increasing and we must be prepared to be able to alleviate and contain the negative effects that may also have on European economies. The threats to diversity today are many and citizens are aware of this and require us to act. In Amposta you will see this weekend.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE).
text: – The world faces a huge challenge in producing food while reducing the pressure on our ecosystem. This is only possible if we work smartly with nature, something that farmers and gardeners naturally have in their fingers. It is precisely through new techniques and applications that we are producing more and more food, while at the same time reducing the environmental impact and improving the health of our animals.  That is why I believe that the greatest danger to our biodiversity is not agriculture and horticulture. The greatest danger is misunderstanding and lack of knowledge. There is not one solution to preserving biodiversity, but by farming modernly we are reducing the pressure on our natural resources and needing less land per kilogram of food. A rigid interpretation of European rules, such as in the Netherlands around Natura 2000, ensures that nature conservation is locked. Only by working together, using common sense and making all stakeholders think along, you create the best solutions to achieve biodiversity goals.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The loss of biodiversity means not only loss of nature, but also of ecological wealth. This House is very rarely so united when it comes to more diversity and more ecology in our nature as well. The Biodiversity Strategy 2020, with its six pillars, certainly provides the right impetus. However – and I believe that we all agree on this too – there is still a great deal of effective work to be done throughout Europe, particularly in terms of implementation, in order to achieve these objectives in the final analysis. I therefore particularly welcome the better implementation of the existing directive. A revision – and here too I am very glad that the majority of the House sees it that way – should by no means be debated, because it simply does not help in the long term. A fundamental problem – and I believe we need to focus much more on this – is that farmers are far too under-involved when it comes, for example, to the designation of Natura 2000 sites. Years of monocultures are less likely to be placed under conservation at some point, but those farmers who really work and operate very responsibly and do so in and with nature very often suddenly get a notice that more or less forces them to stop using and implementing the existing incomes they have. It is essential that we look to involve those farmers more closely and, above all, to support them more or less in doing more for biodiversity and diversity.

name: Herbert Dorfmann (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In this report, we ask ourselves whether our European approach to the conservation and promotion of biodiversity is sensible and sufficient. However, we should also ask ourselves whether all our regulations are appropriate and also effective. For example, we have stipulated that some animal species in Europe are practically unhunted and cannot be controlled elsewhere. No matter how many beavers, how many wolves and how many bears roam our waters and forests, they are definitely worth protecting, regardless of whether they really contribute to biodiversity. I come from an area in the Alps where, in recent years, wolves and bears have in fact made life difficult for farmers and increasingly made them impossible. It is becoming increasingly impossible to keep animals in the pasture. Unfortunately, we are now also experiencing very serious incidents with people, and this is far from pleasant, especially in the tourist areas. We have little insight into this, we stubbornly stick to the programmes and believe that large predators can be re-established everywhere. I think we simply need a political debate on this issue. We have to balance between sensible conservation of biodiversity, alpine mountain farming and the safety of the citizens, otherwise the bear and the wolf will eventually come, and the miner will leave. This will not be a great step forward for biodiversity, especially in the Alps.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – Preserving biodiversity is a matter for our survival. The report is clear – by prolonging past practices and dynamics, we will not achieve the objectives set. We can succeed if we tackle the problem with conceptual and strategic unity and the will to change the paradigm. What our efficiency in this regard shows the year after year of the death of the bees on which the production of more than 3/4 of food depends. Bees don't die alone. They are threatened by other species. Harmful borrowing in the environment and future generations with erroneous practices in agriculture and other sectors must be eliminated through concrete policies.  I'm sure we have the necessary knowledge to change course. We must focus the common agricultural policy on supporting a farming method that will be permanently focused on the conservation of biodiversity. Agricultural policy must have an environmental soul.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, according to the European Commission's report on the economic benefits of the European Natura 2000 Network of Protected Areas, it has been shown that success has been achieved in preserving beautiful species on the verge of extinction. In addition, investments in protected areas have ensured the direct employment of around 4.5 million people in the European Union.  To those who do not consider biodiversity conservation a problem, I must say that according to Eurobarometer surveys from September 2015, over 80% of Europeans have shown concern by reducing biodiversity. 98% of EU citizens live within 20 km of a Natura 2,000 area. Citizens need and want access to preserved, healthy nature and greenery near their homes. But nature protection must not be an obstacle for local people and their activities, but a balance must be struck.  By the coverage of the land area with the Natura 2000 network, Croatia is at the very top of the European Union and I want to keep it that way.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Thank you very much, Madam President, for the opportunity, although I did not get the signal directly here because of the interpretation, but I thank you again for the opportunity. This debate today, I think, has convinced us all that, although we think the relevant provisions and the legal background are good, we still see errors in implementation. I believe that we should point out here, first and foremost, the governments of the Member States. After all, they are the ones who always find an economic interest that will turn them away from the task of nature conservation. I believe that a change in attitude is needed, and that we must condemn the desecration of nature as much as if we condemn the desecration of human rights, whether in economic terms or otherwise.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, agriculture undoubtedly plays an important role in achieving biodiversity objectives. At the same time, however, there must be equality between Europe's farmers. The rural population of most european Union countries cannot enjoy minimum or even zero taxes on agricultural oil and energy, while at the same time in Greece the Troika and the Memorandums impose an unbearable tax increase on agricultural oil, making agricultural production less and less competitive.  At a time when Greek farmers are struggling to save the insurance sector and the OGA are still taking another stab at the back, as, Mr Vella, following a decision by the Commission and the European Parliament's Committee on International Trade, the free and duty-free import into Greece of 70 000 tonnes of oil from Tunisia is being launched for the next two years and retroactively from 1 January 2016. So we stand next to our farmers who are in the memorandum and we will fight to stop the poverty of Greek farmers.

name: Ulrike Müller (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has It is undisputed that biodiversity is a good worth protecting and that further efforts are needed to preserve it. However, we must not lose sight of the fact that we are balancing the requirements with other objectives. I am particularly concerned here with agriculture and forestry, which play an important role in the conservation of biodiversity. From a scientific point of view, the interim report does not allow an actual assessment of the status quo. It is precisely the statement that 80% of forest habitats are in an unfavourable state that is frivolous. How these statements are made without a comprehensive data base of the 28 Member States is inexplicable to me. If we really want to make progress, we need significant improvements in communication and coordination with landowners and managers, more room for basic contractual incentives and accurate data collection.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, fragmentation and habitat change, overexploitation of natural resources, the introduction and spread of invasive alien species and climate change are some of the key factors that have determined biodiversity loss. The European Union's biodiversity strategy is far from responding to the challenges we face. It is necessary not only to strengthen the means to cope with biodiversity loss, but also an indispensable modification of a set of sectoral policies that influence biodiversity, halt and reverse rural abandonment, combat the intensification and homogenisation of agricultural production, prevent and combat invasive alien species, greater accountability of the European Union for financing natura 2000 , with the creation of a specific financial instrument dedicated to its management, a substantial strengthening of the Life programme, at least 1 % of the Eu budget, here are some of the directions and measures that we have put forward in the proposals we have made to amend this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, of course I completely support the richness of biodiversity in my constituency, in the United Kingdom and indeed across Europe. From the wonder of the Washington wetlands, home of some of the world’s rarest water birds, to the grey seal colony on the Farne Islands. From the beauty of the Durham Coast to the simple need to protect our songbirds. Much of this report I agree with. I want to protect these as much as anyone else here. But then the report goes downhill. Where we need common sense, it proposes bureaucracy. Where we need to safeguard fish, it supports the wasteful common fisheries policy; and where we need localism, it proposes centralisation. You see, this place recognises the problem, but we have the solutions all wrong.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf of the Commission, I would like to thank Parliament for the very open and very strong commitment and support for the protection of our natural capital. I believe that, once adopted, this timely solution – together with the Council conclusions delivered last December – can very much help steer the EU towards achieving its biodiversity targets. The Commission’s mid-term review, the Council conclusions and Parliament’s report all send a consistent message about the critical importance of the effective integration of biodiversity objectives with, and into, all the other sectors. The European Parliament has a very important and crucial role to play in reaching EU biodiversity targets, both in raising awareness of the value of biodiversity by actually integrating biodiversity objectives into other EU policies and by actually transforming the calls for this resolution into concrete decisions on EU policies and funding. I could not agree more with the comments that we need a broader and full support of all stakeholders. This is very important. Any legislation without enough support is probably the hardest to implement. I also agree with a number of Members who expressed their opinion that the Member States have an important and most responsible role to implement. Member States, as was said by Catherine Bearder, have to step up their implementation. Ms Boylan asked me whether I can declare my position. I have to say that any position on this will not be the prerogative of only me, Commissioner Vella, but will be a collegial decision of the Commission based on the evidence gathered in the fitness check exercise. My objective is not to undermine existing legislation but to make sure we have all the necessary tools in place to achieve the 2020 target. I took note of what Ms Auken said. We have worked together in the past and I truly know how genuine she is. I can assure her that all members of the college, including First Vice-President Timmermans, are as much in favour of nature and biodiversity as are all of us. To the many comments from the honourable Members who pointed out that we have to involve farmers if biodiversity targets are to be achieved: yes, I agree. We have been talking about implementation, but let us not forget that the state of the environment report, the state of the nature report, and the mid-term review itself, identify and point to a number of causes, not simply implementation. One of the causes which all the reports have identified is not agriculture but some of the bad practices in agriculture. In the implementation of the current CAP, the emphasis in the next years should be on ensuring that the potential of biodiversity support measures is used fully at the national and local levels. Given their role in managing landscapes, farmland and nature, farmers should be supported and rewarded for protecting and restoring biodiversity, and for the services they deliver to the public. Achieving the EU biodiversity targets is, after all, as important for society at large as it is for the farming sector itself. I think, as Ms Köstinger said, farmers have to be part of the solution. I would like to finish on a positive note. The conclusions of the biodiversity mid-term strategy give grounds for both concern and optimism. While it is critical to reflect and act on the causes of insufficient progress, we should keep sight of what has been achieved. We have put in place important policy frameworks to build on. We have accumulated a true wealth of positive experiences to learn from and an increasing pool of knowledge to underpin decision-making. We have a growing network of stakeholders and citizens who are very committed to protecting and enhancing biodiversity. We need to capitalise on this to put the EU back on track to reaching our biodiversity targets. My last thought is that the directives that we have been discussing are not an end in themselves. They are a means to an end, the end being achieving our 2020 targets. Whether we review our directives or not, I believe that we have to work harder. We have to work closely together to achieve this end.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, February 2, at 12:30 p.m. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. – In an economy constantly subject to the effects of globalisation, and in the context of fierce competition and enormous pressure for efficient food production to feed the rapidly growing world population, there are very high pressures on global biodiversity and the agricultural sector, in particular, which is leading to irreversible changes that are very harmful to nature, society and the economy. At Union level, we have a considerable number of small and medium-sized and family farms that still grow diverse varieties of plants, which is a benchmark for finding solutions for different needs and uses in rural communities, but also to reduce the vulnerability of crops to weather, pests and diseases. European citizens and not only need to be aware of the significant economic costs of biodiversity decline, especially if we take into account that, so far, these costs have not been sufficiently integrated into economic and other policies, but also that biodiversity has significant potential to create new skills, jobs and business opportunities.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. – As many as a quarter of all European species are threatened with extinction and many ecosystems are at risk. Despite European nature policy, the restoration of nature is totally inadequate. The protection of nature must be strengthened for this purpose. However, nature restoration can only be successful if the causes of the loss are eliminated.  One of the biggest threats to biodiversity is intensive livestock farming. The Dutch pig sector alone is causing $34 million in damage due to natural loss. The huge emissions of nitrogen pollute surface water, air and soil, reducing biodiversity in the vicinity of livestock factories. But the destructiveness of intensive livestock farming extends to the rainforests of Latin America, which have to make way for giant maize and soybean fields. All this to feed the billions of animals in European factory farming.  A switch to sustainable agriculture and livestock farming is necessary to stop the loss of valuable nature and the extinction of thousands of animal and plant species. Brussels efforts to destroy existing conservation laws should therefore be stopped immediately. The European Birds Directive and Habitat Directive are important and should not be relaxed, but should be strengthened and better enforced in order to stop the dramatic loss of biodiversity in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. – Biodiversity ensures the survival and renewal of resources without which soil formation, nutrients and water cycles would not be possible. Biodiversity loss is a loss to both nature and the economy. We have not done enough to preserve the biodiversity that is the foundation of our existence. According to the European Commission's mid-term assessment, more than three quarters of the EU's important natural habitats are in unsatisfactory condition and several species are at risk of extinction. My amendment, co-tabled with my Austrian colleague Elisabeth Köstinger, was supported by the Environment Committee by a large majority. In order to avoid negative impacts on biodiversity, the precautionary principle should be fully applied to EU authorisation of GMOs. Pest-resistant GM crops make it impossible to apply integrated pest management, the essence of which is to intervene only when it is justified by the increase in pests. In order to protect biodiversity, we can never completely eradicate the pest population, we only reduce it below a certain level. It is also of great concern that co-production of genetically modified and conventional crops can never be fully achieved in practice. GM crops can contaminate ecologically grown areas. Finally, I would like to point out that, because of their typically large-scale monoculture production, GMOs pose a food safety risk in the countries and regions hosting such crops.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. – Europe is facing a crisis. It's a strange paradox. Unlike others, this crisis is neither a media crisis nor a priority for politicians or the subject of crisis meetings of EU Member States. This is a crisis of unprecedented proportions, which can put one in every six jobs in the EU at risk. Yet it is not part of Juncker's Vision of Europe, which is primarily intended to ensure growth and work. Experts agree on the negative effects that Europe will have to face, but European governments do not attach particular importance to the problem and implement existing legislation only to a very limited extent. Europeans themselves are convinced that there is a crisis: 80% consider its effects to be very serious, and more than 500 000 of them have expressed themselves in the consultation related to this crisis. Who or what is in danger? Nature, specifically its biodiversity. It is no secret that the European Union is not even able to meet its own biodiversity targets. The 2010 strategy has clearly failed and current trends clearly show that we are heading for an absolutely identical situation in 2020. Without the correct implementation of existing legislation, in particular nature conservation directives and regulations on invasive non-invasive species, it cannot be hoped that the situation will improve in the coming years. The protection of biodiversity must become a political priority.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Europe’s biodiversity is in decline and not due to the absence of measures but due to a poor implementation of the current legislation.
