Therefore, better implementation and enforcement of Nature directives, together with adequate funding, would represent the best way to act today; this would be a great step to achieve the 2020 biodiversity target with a positive impact on nature, people and businesses.  Clearly, for better results, we need the involvement of all stakeholders, regional and local. We need a holistic approach of biological diversity in agriculture and the environment. The role of the common agricultural policy should not be forgotten here, together with the impact of individual farmers in preserving biodiversity.  According to Eurobarometer, over 80 % of Europeans are concerned about the loss of biodiversity in Europe and therefore, it is not the time now to revise the Nature directives, as such a measure would lead to delays and uncertainty. It is time for better actions at EU and national levels.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Ladies and gentlemen, I very much welcome the report presented here on 'Mid-term review of the EU biodiversity strategy'. The issue is one of the most important issues for us human beings. The term 'biological diversity' refers to several levels of our lives: biodiversity, genetic diversity and the diversity of habitats and ecosystems. Rich biodiversity is an important basis for the preservation of natural processes that serve humans. Examples include natural pest regulation, pollination of fruit blossoms by insects and the setting and degradation processes in the soil. It is not without reason that Albert Einstein said that once the bee disappears from the earth, man has only four years left to live. No more bees, no more pollination, no more plants, no more animals, no more humans. It is important that we introduce measures that reduce the loss of biodiversity. I am very grateful to my colleague Mark Demesmaeker for having achieved this objective in an exemplary manner and for winning majorities in return. Count me among the supporters.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for one-minute interventions, according to article 163 of the regulation.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Solidarity is one of the key words of our time. At European level, this is referred to by many as a correction of a misguided decision: the redistribution of part of the migrant influx into Europe among the Member States. However, there is a more original meaning to this term: to co-ordn with those who, for some reason, are in difficulty. In Slovakia, where I come from, health nurses and teachers have been on strike for days. Their poor working conditions and low pay took them out on the streets. My dear friends, if we are serious about the future of Europe, we must also pay more attention to the voices coming from Central and Eastern Europe. Which warned months ago about the consequences of the migrant crisis, and now striking teachers and nurses are warning that the richer half of Europe should not be selfish. Brain drains, nurses, doctors, avenn themselves. Not only is the eastern half of Europe approaching a more developed Europe, but it is lagging behind on many issues. We must pay attention to this phenomenon until it causes an irreversible problem.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we need to change the way we do politics. We need to change the way we do politics in Europe, because politics is not about privileges, partisan interests or election outcomes. Politics is about what we do for people.  In my country, Romania, there is talk these days about election tours when, in fact, we need to talk about fighting poverty, about the need for development policies, about education or health, about marginalised people, about concrete projects for people. And we are speaking today in the plenary of the European Parliament, at twelve o'clock at night, in front of an almost empty hall, in the hope that tomorrow someone will hear us.  That is why it is important that we here in the European Parliament set the tone for this change of mentality and I am confident that we can do it. And for that we need to change the mechanisms, but especially the objectives. People are running out of patience and it's time to deliver. It is time to do concrete things and, in this respect, the first step is the European Strategic Investment Plan, which needs to be more transparent, reach people, it needs to involve SMEs and it needs to make it work and bring Europe's economic recovery.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – At the moment, the European Commission is taking over my country, taking Poland. Hungary has been attacked on several occasions in this Chamber, each time in the name of an alleged violation of the values of the European Union as defined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. But why does it actually serve when we see how, after the tragic New Year's Eve in Cologne, the facts that completely contradict this supposedly common estimate of the values defined in Article 2 have gradually begun to come to light day after day? What does it have to do with the right of the public to the truth, with the rule of law, with freedom of expression – what does it have to do with the police concealing information from the public, because this information could compromise official immigration policy? What does concealment of information have to do with the notorious rights of minorities, because they could right political nonconformists, those who are in the minority at the moment? It is time for us all to reflect on what this campaign really serves in the name of these purported values.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the Sestao Compact Steel Mill in the Basque Country has announced an indefinite cessation of the activity of an innovative, flexible, pioneering circular economy plant that uses constructive pacts to preserve employment in a highly skilled workforce. It is the symbol of how the 2020 development saved an industrial zone. Now Chinese dumping, but in addition, the situation of european energy and financial markets threaten the stability of thousands of families who must be at the heart of our actions and attention. Because first of all we talk about people, life, sustainability and social justice. We are talking about the origin and ultimate meaning of the European project. That is why we demand an immediate and energetic reaction to foreign products that violate our social and environmental standards. That is why we must end scandalous differences in energy prices and money in the domestic market. Thus, excellence will be the key to competitiveness and a determined commitment to re-industrialization. Because the crisis in the Basque steel sector is the symptom of a deep and general disease which threatens many businesses and jobs and needs, Commissioner, urgent and immediate responses, European responses.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I would urge the European Union to act on the situation with the Garoña nuclear power plant in the Spanish State.  It is a shame that it is even necessary to put it back into operation, extending the operating period by another fifteen years: they pose a risk of nuclear catastrophe to the European Union.  The People's Party Government is deafly hearing the European Commission's recommendation to review garoña and Cofrentes' obsolete reactors, which were diagnosed with a manufacturing failure after having to discontinue two similar ones in Belgium. Thousands of people struggling to stop him are being deaf.  We call on the Nuclear Security Council and the European Commission, within the framework of the Euratom Treaty, to stop this situation. Please remember this name, ladies and gentlemen: Garoña. And don't let it become the new European Fukushima.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, at the 28 October sitting, this plenary approved a resolution on the European Citizens’ Initiative. I worked on it as a shadow of the Verts/ALE Group, which had to abstain because the resolution did not officially tackle the main issue of an ECI, which is the follow-up. Indeed, in the last years only three out of nearly 50 proposed ECIs succeeded, and none led to legislative change. That is why a proper follow-up is so important. In addition to that, we now get extremely bad news, according to which the Commission labels the ECI as a threat. I firmly protest against this and wish that such a negative attitude will soon be rectified. With this opinion, the Commission backs and reinforces Euroscepticism. The Commission itself attacks the European project. Unbelievable.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in Sicily, as in so many regions of the Mediterranean, agriculture produces extraordinary excellence. Think pachino tomatoes, ribera oranges or piana di catania, or this wonderful extra virgin olive oil. Yet what does the European Union do? Instead of protecting excellent products, the European Union is thinking of devastating them. Thus, in view of the devastating experience of the EU-Morocco Treaty on the agri-food sector, it was well thought that a further 35 000 tonnes of olive oil from Tunisia would be increased. Now, the question I want to ask is very simple and is addressed to members from the Mediterranean countries who are mainly in the large groups in this Parliament, with particular reference also to the Italians and the Democratic Party. So you, if you are not able to defend our typical features, if you are not able to block these obscenities, it means that here you only come to do number, only for the allowance.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF).
text: – Madam President, it is clear that we must all be united in order to fight effectively against the threat of terrorism and to protect our external borders. Austria has temporarily suspended the Schengen agreement. Greeks risk being suspended from the Schengen area due to the management of the refugee flow, and Sweden recently decided to expel illegal immigrants en masse. All these events are jeopardising the Schengen area, and in the coming months, as shown, I believe that other states will take a decision similar to Austria. In view of this situation, Romania, which has fulfilled all the conditions for accession, has been categorically refused, together with Bulgaria, and is obliged to accept the quotas imposed by the Union. It's a more than contradictory situation. What is the European Union doing for the two countries? What attitude should the two countries adopt now? We have fought for so many years to join the Schengen area, and now, when it is in total decline, entry will continue to be denied on the same grounds which, in the current context, are just meaningless pretexts.  So can anyone answer whether or not Romania will be received in the Schengen area?

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We are to talk about the situation of the European Union. The best illustration of this situation is that, in this House, a dozen minutes ago, someone suggested that the European Union show the Chinese how to develop quickly, and no one in this House should get an attack of laughter when they heard such a proposal.  Ladies and about, after all, the Chinese know foreign languages and the Chinese race, the yellow race has an intelligence quotient a few points higher than we do. If they read, they hear these kinds of statements, if they watch – if someone wants to watch the deliberations of this Parliament – they have to laugh at us. I would ask that we finally speak at this level during the deliberations so that someone can read some economics manual before speaking out on this subject.  More besides, I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on 19 January, without prior notice or apparent cause to justify it, the Riojan company Altadis announced the closure of its factory in the El Sequero polygon on 30 June. This unjustified decision, since Altadis is not in deficit, leaves 471 people on the street directly, and indirectly many more: freelancers and contractors and services companies to the company itself.  I urge the European Commission and the honourable Members of the European Parliament to prevent this closure from being consumed.  From here I am in the cry of Riojan society as a whole which, over the past two weeks, has expressed in a clear and direct way the unanimous rejection of this absolutely unjustified closure. I join the efforts of the Government of La Rioja, the Business Committee and the Riojans in general to avoid the closure of this factory, so that together we can prevent the relocation of an industrial plant that has been creating jobs and wealth in my region for more than a hundred years, and whose closure also poses a severe risk to more than 10,000 farming families.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it appears that a few hundred terrorists have managed to paralyse the European Union by creating fear and dissension among its Member States. This fear has intensified disunity between European governments, many of which are now seriously repressing the rights and freedoms of citizens. They are doing this on the ground as if this were the most efficient way to fight terrorism. They could not be more wrong. Disintegration is clearly not an adequate way to lower the terror threat in Europe. However, it is a great tool to concentrate too much uncontrolled power in the hands of certain governments. The Hungarian Government knows this well, as it has recently proposed a so-called constitutional amendment to introduce the notion of a state of terrorist threat. The proposal would allow Prime Minister Orbán to rule without control by decree for 60 days, or even more, but avoids giving a definition of ‘terrorist threat’, leaving it to the Government to identify.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the proud farmers of my country, Greece, are on their feet, they are at the roadblocks and they are fighting for their own survival. The Troika and the lenders, with their memorandum policy, implemented by the SYRIZA/ANEL co-government, dissolve the primary sector, impose tax resalto on farmers' pockets, savagely tax the land they cultivate, impose seizures on Community subsidies, put their hands on farmers' bank accounts and dissolve their insurance system. But farmers and ranchers resist and escalate their fair fight. On their side is the whole of Greek society, the self-employed, the retired, the workers. It is about forming a new social, anti-monumental alliance that is determined to close the road to the Troika. A new social alliance that will be expressed en masse, democratically and racing in the general strike of 4 February next Thursday. Because all Greeks are fighting together to throw the Troika out of our homeland and get Greece back.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, one hundred years ago the Irish Republic was declared. As a nation, we should be celebrating our centenary and celebrating the brave men and women who fought for Irish freedom, but instead, the Irish Government, whose Fine Gael members sit across this Chamber, would like to see our history erased – not just figuratively, but literally. They want to demolish the site where the leaders of the 1916 Easter Rising spent their last hours before their execution. They want to demolish a site that the National Museum of Ireland has declared is the most important historic site in modern Irish history. They want to demolish the site that the Imperial War Museum in London has declared as the most intact city battlefield in the whole of Europe. They want to deny the future generations of Ireland in Europe their historical heritage and instead replace it with a shopping centre, like some sort of crass, shining beacon to their neo-liberal agenda. I want to put it on this Parliament’s record that this will not be tolerated. Our heritage belongs to everyone, and tomorrow I take the fight to the Council of Europe.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Commission has accused the Polish Government of attacking the freedom of the media and pluralism. This is because under the new law the Treasury Minister has the power to appoint and dismiss the top management of public television companies. So why does the Commission not also accuse the Italian Government? The Commission may not know that Prime Minister Renzi has given himself the power to appoint and choose the super CEO of RAI, inauguraing a public television system worthy of a fascist regime. Perhaps the Commission is not aware that in Italy the parties choose network directors, news directors and television programme hosts, especially political ones, and that journalists who are not welcome are being kicked out. I could give, among others, the most resounding example, that of Enzo Biagi who was expelled with the Bulgarian edict. Ladies and gentlemen, you now know everything, you can no longer remain silent. We in the 5 Star Movement demand that the Commission intervene in Italy as well as in Poland. I repeat: you can no longer remain silent!

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Madam President, the insurance bill is part of the third memorandum signed by the SYRIZA/ANEL government with the European Union and the International Monetary Fund and voted for by all other urban parties. It is a cheque for large capital. It implements strategic guidelines of the European Union which provide for the abolition of the social nature of insurance, its treatment as an individual matter, by loading unbearable contributions on the backs of workers, reducing pensions, raising retirement age to the very old age.  The conversion of the pension into a workhouse allowance, together with the incorporation of the European Solvency II Directive, paves the way for an increase in the pie of private insurance groups. Small and medium-sized farmers are burdened with huge increases in contributions which, together with the terms of the new CAP, eliminate them, by rewarding large farmers and groups.  The government here and now withdraw the guillotine bill. On Thursday, 4 February, in the strike, workers with small and medium-sized farms and their roadblocks, and the self-employed, can give a massive decisive answer.

name: Andor Deli (PPE).
text: – The development, planning and financialability of trans-European infrastructure has been significantly improved and rationaled by defining ten-t transport corridors. Thanks to last summer's vienna negotiations, the ten-t corridor routes have now been laid not only for EU member states but also for candidates from the Western Balkans, which meant the extension of three existing TEN-T lines and the finally drawing of a map over the entire continent. However, in order to achieve positive transport and economic impacts across the entire corridor and to create the so-called corridor effect, the corridor effect, it is necessary to rethink the funding mechanisms provided by the EU. After all, it differs greatly between Member States and candidates, so that bottlenecks remain with all goodwill. I call on the Commission to establish the appropriate legal and financial framework for the review of the TEN-T corridors in order to ensure that the corridor effect can be successfully achieved.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – The Member spoke in Latgale.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the flow of refugees is not evenly distributed among the Member States. A fairer burden-sharing is now required. All right, let's be fair and start here: Finland has suffered more from trade sanctions against Russia than others. EUR 400 million, this is how much the trade war has inoculated Russian exports of Finnish agricultural products. Who's going to make it up to you?  No, I am not in favour of lifting sanctions now. It would send the wrong message to the Kremlin. However, I am in favour of a fairer burden-sharing. If the flow of refugees is to be equalised, the burden of trade sanctions should also be shared among the Member States. What, then, could be the appropriate mechanism for this? That is what I would like to discuss.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, we all heard about the shocking situation in Cologne and elsewhere, where women were assaulted and harassed by groups of migrant and refugee men. How have we let this happen? The EU expanding the meaning of the 1951 Geneva Convention is at the heart of it. The Geneva Convention is the only international definition of a refugee: someone who is genuinely in fear of persecution due to race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion. However, the EU has expanded this and created its own definition through the Qualification Directive. This now includes anyone fleeing situations of international or internal armed conflict and not just those in legitimate fear of persecution. So the EU has opened the door to countless millions, and in 2015 this led to over one million people arriving in Europe, the majority of them men. This open-door policy to countries and cultures that treat women as second—class citizens has put us all at very great risk.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Madam President, local units often have good ideas and prepare excellent innovative projects that want to ensure a better quality of life for citizens at more affordable prices. Green urban transport, renewables, digitalisation and new smart services are only part of the projects they are preparing.  A big problem in the realization is the lack of sources of funding and the lack of information about the programmes from which the projects could be financed. I call on the European Commission, in cooperation with member states, to introduce new ways of communicating and informing them that will bring the Union's programmes, the new European Fund for Strategic Investments, eib, EBRD and other European financial institutions programmes closer to local units.  Most often we hear from representatives that there are funds, but there are no well-structured projects. That is why, at least for those projects we have, we need to make the path to funding easier by better information.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am intervening in the plenary session of the European Parliament and before the European Commission to denounce the recent approval in Spain by the government in office of the People's Party of the Ebro Basin Hydrological Plan. The Ebro Basin Hydrological Plan puts the Ebro Delta and its large and important ecosystem at serious risk and also means a socio-economic attack on the territory. An approved plan without dialogue with catalan or local administrations. A plan that has not taken into account citizen participation or the opinion of the Platform for defence of l'Ebre and a plan that also violates European legislation and regulations, such as directives in defence of the protection of habitat, water or birds. There are major mobilizations this weekend. A delegation from the European Parliament will visit the Delta next Monday and continue to defend l'Ebre there on ens calgui.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – After a failed 20-year period, when dealers in Slovenian state forests took care of their pockets, the centre-left Slovenian government decided to set up a state-owned company to employ foresters, incisors, buy tractors, commercial equipment, build logistics centres with state money and sell timber on the market. The establishment of the company Slovenian state forests is a great danger to systemic risks when the operations of the state enterprise will be influenced by interest groups, cross-party struggles and failed personnel solutions. At the same time, there is a threat to systemic corruption. Unfortunately, we already have many such cases in Slovenia. A State-owned company will compete with other bidders on the market with State money and a State guarantee. The country thus enters the thin ice of interference in the free market, in the area of competitiveness, and thus may find itself under the microscope of the European Commission. The expiration of concessions in state forests could be used to better manage state forests, but unfortunately it could become a sinkhole for taxpayers' money.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the North Sea has the potential to become a central plank of the EU’s Energy Union: a real northern powerhouse. Offshore wind and other renewables, better interconnection through a meshed electricity grid, and joint research cooperation around the North Sea could help ensure low-cost, secure and clean energy, while creating and maintaining thousands of high-quality jobs – including in my constituency in the North-East of England. The Dutch Presidency of the Council is an excellent opportunity to turn this potential into reality. Last month, colleagues from five political groupings and I presented the Dutch Minister for the Economy with an action plan for energy for the North Sea. That is ahead of a high-level meeting that is happening this Thursday, and I would like to call on them to take this opportunity to make the North Sea a clean powerhouse for Europe.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Cooperation in the economic field can, over time, lead to historical reconciliation between countries and the overrea soreness. This principle has led the founding Member States of the EU in Western Europe and this principle can help the EU's Central and Eastern European member states today. However, EU accession alone did not override the mistrust that has developed organically over the past decades or centuries. Economic partnership is important, the enforcement of common interests is even more important, but sooner or later it will have to come to speak honestly about sensitive issues and to name the way forward to solve problems. This is the protection of national minorities living in each other's territory, which means the right of these communities to identity, to thrive, to strengthen them, to their equality of rights and, ultimately, to the long-term survival of the community. Unfortunately, there are still states in the region – Slovakia, Romania – that are not interested in the recognition of indigenous minorities as state-forming communities, but see them as a potential threat and consider their slow assimilation desirable.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the infamous Norwegian social service Barnevernet continues to apply its unscrupulous approach to families originating, inter alia, in several Member States of the European Union, including the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Romania. More and more cases of children being taken for completely dubious reasons are coming to light, and many people are asking how this is possible in civilised Norway, in this democratic country. I am glad that people are not indifferent to this injustice, and demonstrations against barnevernet practices have taken place in a number of places in the Countries of the European Union and around the world in recent weeks. EU citizens must now say a clear 'no' to unauthorised interference in family matters, as the European Commission should say, Commissioner.

name: La Présidente. –
text: This closes the interventions by one minute.
